This approach involves training the family member to use positive reinforcement, allow natural consequences, and improve their own well-being while working toward engaging the resistant loved one in treatment.
questions.question: Which evidence-based intervention is the psychologist describing?

options.A: Al-Anon Family Groups
options.B: Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT)
options.C: Motivational Interviewing (MI)
options.D: Johnson Intervention Model

option_explanations.A: Al-Anon is a mutual support group for family members of individuals with alcohol use disorder, but it is not a structured, professionally delivered, evidence-based training program that teaches specific behavioral strategies to engage a treatment-refusing loved one in care.
option_explanations.B: CRAFT is the evidence-based intervention designed precisely for family members of adults who have a substance use problem but refuse treatment. It trains family members to use reinforcement strategies, allow natural consequences, and improve their own functioning while systematically working to move the resistant individual toward treatment engagement.
option_explanations.C: Motivational Interviewing is an evidence-based counseling style delivered directly to the person with the substance use disorder to enhance their own intrinsic motivation for change. It is not designed for training family members of treatment-refusing individuals.
option_explanations.D: The Johnson Intervention Model involves a confrontational, organized meeting in which family members collectively present consequences of the individual's substance use to pressure them into treatment. It is not the structured family training program described and has less empirical support than CRAFT.

questions.source_summary: Community reinforcement and family training (CRAFT) is an evidence-based intervention designed for families that include an adult who has a substance use problem but refuses to seek treatment.
questions.vignette: A psychologist at a community mental health center begins working with a 52-year-old woman whose adult son has been using methamphetamine for three years. The son has refused every attempt by the family to discuss his drug use, and he has no current legal involvement or crisis that might compel him to seek help. The woman reports significant depression and social withdrawal stemming from her distress over her son's situation. The psychologist recommends a manualized approach that simultaneously addresses the mother's emotional well-being, teaches her to strategically reinforce her son's sober behaviors, and coaches her on allowing natural consequences when he uses substances — all with the explicit goal of moving her son toward voluntarily entering treatment.
questions.question: Which intervention is the psychologist most likely implementing?

options.A: Behavioral Couples Therapy (BCT)
options.B: Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT)
options.C: Multidimensional Family Therapy (MDFT)
options.D: Strengthening Families Program (SFP)

option_explanations.B: CRAFT is the manualized program designed for concerned significant others of treatment-refusing adults with substance use disorders. It explicitly addresses the family member's well-being alongside teaching reinforcement and natural-consequence strategies to move the resistant individual toward treatment — matching every feature described.
option_explanations.A: Behavioral Couples Therapy is an evidence-based intervention delivered jointly to both the person with a substance use disorder and their partner, requiring that the person with the disorder already be engaged in treatment. It does not apply here because the son refuses to seek help and BCT is not designed for unilateral use by one family member.
option_explanations.C: Multidimensional Family Therapy is an evidence-based treatment for adolescent substance use that involves multiple family members in active sessions together with the adolescent. It requires the identified patient's participation and is designed for youth, not treatment-refusing adults.
option_explanations.D: The Strengthening Families Program is a prevention-oriented family skills training program designed to reduce risk factors for substance use in youth, not an intervention for engaging a treatment-refusing adult with an established substance use disorder.

questions.source_summary: Community reinforcement and family training (CRAFT) is an evidence-based intervention designed for families that include an adult who has a substance use problem but refuses to seek treatment.
questions.vignette: A psychologist works with a 45-year-old woman whose husband has been drinking heavily every evening for five years and categorically refuses any form of counseling or medical evaluation. The woman recently attended a weekend Al-Anon retreat and found it helpful for coping, but she tells the psychologist she wants to do more than simply accept the situation — she wants her husband to eventually get help. The psychologist notes that the woman has been inadvertently shielding her husband from the negative consequences of his drinking by calling in sick on his behalf and managing social fallout. Over the next several weeks, the psychologist works with the woman on systematically using reinforcement of sober behavior, withdrawing inadvertent rewards for drinking, and carefully planning how she will present the option of treatment at a moment when her husband is most likely to be receptive.
questions.question: Which intervention best describes what the psychologist is implementing with this client?

options.A: Johnson Intervention Model
options.B: Unilateral Family Therapy (UFT)
options.C: Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT)
options.D: Contingency Management (CM)

option_explanations.A: The Johnson Intervention Model involves organizing a structured confrontational meeting in which prepared family members and significant others directly confront the individual with substance use disorder en masse. It does not involve systematic training in reinforcement strategies or strategic timing of treatment invitations, and it is not consistent with the individually coached, gradual approach described.
option_explanations.B: Unilateral Family Therapy is a research-based approach for families of treatment-refusing individuals that focuses primarily on the family member's own change and coping, and on modifying the interactional patterns that maintain drinking. While it shares some conceptual overlap with CRAFT, it does not include the structured reinforcement training, natural consequences framework, and optimally timed treatment-invitation coaching that are CRAFT's defining features.
option_explanations.C: CRAFT is the intervention being described. Its three core components — improving the family member's own well-being, training in positive reinforcement of sober behavior coupled with withdrawal of enabling behaviors, and coaching on presenting treatment options at an optimal moment — are all explicitly represented in the vignette, making this the best match.
option_explanations.D: Contingency Management is an evidence-based intervention delivered directly to the person with a substance use disorder, using systematic tangible rewards to reinforce abstinence or treatment attendance. It is not a family-based intervention and is not appropriate here because the husband is not engaged in any treatment.

questions.source_summary: Community reinforcement and family training (CRAFT) is an evidence-based intervention designed for families that include an adult who has a substance use problem but refuses to seek treatment.
questions.vignette: A graduate-level practicum student is reviewing the clinical notes of a supervisor who has been meeting weekly for two months with a 38-year-old woman. The identified focus of the sessions is the client herself: her anxiety, her sleep disruption, and the social isolation she has experienced over the past year. The supervisor's notes reveal that sessions have also included structured role-play in which the client practices specific conversational responses when her partner comes home intoxicated, rehearses ways to express appreciation when he attends a family dinner sober, and plans the precise timing and wording of a future conversation in which she will suggest he speak with a professional. The partner has never attended any session. The student wonders whether this is simply supportive therapy for the client's adjustment difficulties.
questions.question: Which intervention framework best accounts for the full scope of what the supervisor is doing with this client?

options.A: Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy (IBCT)
options.B: Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT)
options.C: Unilateral Family Therapy (UFT)
options.D: Al-Anon Facilitation Therapy

option_explanations.B: Although the vignette is structured so the work appears to be individual therapy for the client's own distress, the specific techniques — role-playing responses to intoxicated behavior, expressing appreciation for sober behavior, and strategically planning a treatment invitation — are the defining procedural components of CRAFT. CRAFT explicitly works with the concerned significant other alone (the partner never attends) and addresses the family member's well-being as one of three core modules alongside behavioral strategies and treatment invitation planning.
option_explanations.A: Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy is delivered to both partners jointly, targeting acceptance and behavior change within the couple relationship. Because the partner never attends, IBCT cannot be the framework in use; it also does not include the structured coaching on reinforcing sober behavior or strategically timing a treatment invitation.
option_explanations.C: Unilateral Family Therapy shares the feature of working exclusively with the non-using partner and does address interactional patterns around drinking. However, UFT focuses primarily on the family member's own change and the couple's systemic patterns rather than providing structured behavioral training in reinforcement of sobriety, management of enabling behaviors, and a coached treatment-invitation module — elements that are central to CRAFT and specifically present here.
option_explanations.D: Al-Anon Facilitation Therapy is a structured intervention that helps individuals engage with Al-Anon principles, emphasizing detachment, acceptance of what cannot be controlled, and peer support. It does not involve role-play for strategic reinforcement of sober behavior or planning a treatment invitation, making it inconsistent with the active behavioral coaching described in the supervisor's notes.

questions.source_summary: Community reinforcement and family training (CRAFT) is an evidence-based intervention designed for families that include an adult who has a substance use problem but refuses to seek treatment.
questions.vignette: A therapist has been seeing a 50-year-old woman individually for ten weeks. The woman's adult daughter has not attended any appointment. Sessions appear to focus on the woman's own emotional health: she describes years of walking on eggshells, canceling plans with friends, and lying awake worrying about her daughter's nightly behavior. In each session, however, the therapist spends considerable time on very specific rehearsal: the woman practices what to say when her daughter is in a calm, good mood versus when she first walks through the door after work; she learns to vocally notice the evenings when her daughter seems clearer and more present, and she stops quietly handling the fallout — explaining things to grandchildren, covering missed obligations — that had previously made it easier for her daughter to continue unchanged. Near the end of the ten weeks, the therapist helps the woman script and rehearse a brief, specific conversation she intends to initiate on a Saturday morning.
questions.question: Which approach most precisely describes the framework the therapist is using?

options.A: Unilateral Family Therapy (UFT)
options.B: Al-Anon Facilitation Therapy
options.C: Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT)
options.D: Behavioral Activation with a Systems Focus

option_explanations.A: Unilateral Family Therapy is the most plausible distractor because it also works exclusively with the non-using family member and targets interactional patterns that maintain substance use. However, UFT does not include the structured module of coaching the family member on reinforcing sober behavior by verbally acknowledging it, nor does it include a formal treatment-invitation module with scripted rehearsal — both of which are hallmark procedural elements of CRAFT and are clearly described here.
option_explanations.B: Al-Anon Facilitation Therapy guides family members toward the Al-Anon philosophy of detachment, acceptance, and finding peace regardless of whether the loved one changes. The vignette explicitly shows the opposite orientation: the therapist is actively coaching the woman to influence her daughter's behavior and to bring her daughter toward professional help — goals that are inconsistent with Al-Anon's emphasis on releasing control over the loved one's choices.
option_explanations.C: Every procedural element in the vignette maps onto a specific CRAFT module: addressing the concerned significant other's own well-being, systematically reinforcing sober or positive behavior (verbally acknowledging the 'clearer' evenings), withdrawing enabling behaviors (no longer managing the daughter's fallout), and culminating in a coached, scripted, optimally timed treatment invitation on a calm Saturday morning. The daughter's complete non-attendance is entirely expected within CRAFT, which is designed for precisely this scenario.
option_explanations.D: Behavioral Activation is an evidence-based intervention for depression that increases engagement with rewarding activities to improve mood, sometimes extended to a systems context. While the woman's social isolation might suggest depression, Behavioral Activation does not involve training a client to strategically modify how a third party is reinforced or to plan a formal invitation to treatment — distinguishing features of CRAFT that are unmistakably present in the vignette.

questions.source_summary: Moffitt's "maturity gap" is most useful for understanding the etiology of adolescent-onset conduct disorder.
questions.vignette: A developmental psychologist is lecturing on Terrie Moffitt's taxonomy of antisocial behavior. She explains that some youth develop conduct disorder only during adolescence because of the 'maturity gap' — the disparity between biological maturity and the social autonomy granted by society. These adolescents mimic the delinquent behavior of life-course-persistent peers as a way to signal adult status, and their antisocial behavior typically remits as they gain legitimate adult roles. The professor notes that this adolescent-onset pathway is distinct from early-onset trajectories rooted in neuropsychological deficits.
questions.question: According to Moffitt's developmental taxonomy, which etiological concept BEST explains why adolescent-onset conduct disorder emerges and typically desists?

options.A: The maturity gap, in which the lag between biological development and socially sanctioned adult autonomy motivates adolescents to adopt antisocial behavior as a proxy for adult status
options.B: Neuropsychological deficits accumulated across early childhood that disrupt executive functioning and increase impulsivity throughout the lifespan
options.C: Coercive family process, in which inconsistent parental discipline reinforces oppositional and aggressive behavior beginning in the preschool years
options.D: Negative affectivity and low constraint temperament traits that interact with adverse environmental conditions to produce stable antisocial patterns

option_explanations.A: This is correct. Moffitt's maturity gap specifically describes the developmental window in which biological maturity outpaces social recognition of adulthood, driving adolescent-limited offenders to temporarily adopt antisocial behavior as a means of claiming adult privileges; this behavior resolves when legitimate adult roles become accessible.
option_explanations.B: This is incorrect. Neuropsychological deficits characterize Moffitt's life-course-persistent pathway, not the adolescent-limited pathway. Life-course-persistent offenders show early neurodevelopmental vulnerabilities that produce antisocial behavior beginning in childhood and continuing across the lifespan.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. Coercive family process is Patterson's model, which describes how reinforcement of coercive behavior in early parent-child interactions produces early-starting conduct problems — the opposite of the adolescent-onset pattern Moffitt's maturity gap explains.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. Negative affectivity and low constraint are temperament dimensions from Moffitt's own work associated with the life-course-persistent pathway, not the adolescent-limited pathway. The maturity gap, not temperament, is the key etiological construct for adolescent-onset cases.

questions.source_summary: Moffitt's "maturity gap" is most useful for understanding the etiology of adolescent-onset conduct disorder.
questions.vignette: A 15-year-old male with no prior behavioral problems and a history of above-average academic performance begins skipping school, shoplifting, and vandalizing property with a new peer group. His parents report that he recently started puberty relatively early for his age cohort and has been frequently complaining that he is 'treated like a kid.' His elementary school records show no conduct problems, no learning disabilities, and positive teacher ratings. A consultant reviewing the case notes that the adolescent-onset pattern and his preoccupation with adult status are theoretically consistent with a well-known developmental framework.
questions.question: Which theoretical concept BEST accounts for the emergence of this adolescent's conduct problems?

options.A: Social learning theory's emphasis on observational learning from deviant peers as the primary mechanism for acquiring antisocial behavior
options.B: The maturity gap, whereby the disparity between biological maturity and socially sanctioned autonomy motivates adolescent-limited antisocial behavior
options.C: Oppositional defiant disorder escalating into conduct disorder through a developmental sequence of increasingly severe noncompliance
options.D: Strain theory's proposition that blocked access to legitimate means of achieving culturally valued goals produces delinquent adaptations

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The combination of adolescent onset, no prior history, early biological maturity, peer affiliation with delinquents, and a stated grievance about being 'treated like a kid' precisely maps onto Moffitt's maturity gap construct, in which biologically mature adolescents act out to claim adult status before society grants it.
option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. Social learning theory and observational learning from deviant peers are relevant to understanding behavioral acquisition but do not explain why this particular adolescent — with no prior history — began engaging in antisocial behavior specifically at adolescence. The maturity gap explains the developmental timing that social learning theory alone does not.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. An ODD-to-conduct disorder escalation pathway typically involves earlier childhood onset of oppositional behavior; the vignette explicitly states no prior behavioral problems, making this developmental sequence inconsistent with the case presentation.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. Strain theory (Merton) addresses sociological-level explanations for delinquency in terms of blocked economic goals and is not a psychological developmental framework explaining why conduct problems emerge at adolescence specifically for youth with previously normal behavioral histories.

questions.source_summary: Moffitt's "maturity gap" is most useful for understanding the etiology of adolescent-onset conduct disorder.
questions.vignette: A forensic psychologist is reviewing two adolescent case files for a juvenile court consultation. The first involves a 16-year-old male with a clean early childhood record, recent onset of theft and trespassing, strong peer involvement in the offenses, and expressed frustration that his parents 'treat him like he's 12.' The second involves a 16-year-old male with a documented history of aggression, cruelty to animals, fire-setting, and poor academic functioning since age 6. The psychologist notes that only the first youth's antisocial behavior reflects the theoretical mechanism involving the lag between biological development and social role attainment, and that his prognosis is substantially more favorable.
questions.question: The psychologist's differentiation of the first youth's presentation from the second youth's presentation is MOST consistent with which etiological framework?

options.A: Patterson's coercive family process model, which distinguishes early-starter and late-starter pathways based on parenting quality during the preschool years
options.B: Loeber's three-pathway model, which differentiates authority conflict, covert, and overt antisocial developmental trajectories
options.C: Moffitt's developmental taxonomy, in which the maturity gap drives adolescent-limited antisocial behavior that is distinct in etiology and prognosis from life-course-persistent antisocial behavior
options.D: Dodge's social information processing model, which attributes adolescent aggression to hostile attribution biases acquired through early victimization experiences

option_explanations.C: This is correct. Moffitt's taxonomy explicitly contrasts adolescent-limited offenders (driven by the maturity gap, no childhood history, peer-mimicry, good prognosis) with life-course-persistent offenders (early onset, neuropsychological deficits, poor prognosis), which maps directly onto the contrast between the two youth in the vignette.
option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. Patterson's model does distinguish early-starter and late-starter pathways, but it attributes these differences to differential parenting quality rather than to the biological-social autonomy gap. Patterson's late starters are also driven by peer deviance in adolescence, making this a plausible but less precise fit than Moffitt's framework, which uniquely names the maturity gap mechanism.
option_explanations.B: This is incorrect. Loeber's three-pathway model describes the escalating sequence of antisocial behaviors within an individual (from less to more serious) rather than distinguishing between different developmental onset trajectories based on etiology and prognosis. It does not involve the maturity gap construct.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. Dodge's social information processing model focuses on cognitive mechanisms — particularly hostile attribution bias — that mediate aggression, and while it addresses development, it does not provide a taxonomic distinction between adolescent-limited and life-course-persistent trajectories, nor does it invoke the maturity gap.

questions.source_summary: Moffitt's "maturity gap" is most useful for understanding the etiology of adolescent-onset conduct disorder.
questions.vignette: A clinical researcher studying delinquency prevention is presenting findings at a conference. She describes a subgroup of youth whose rule-breaking appears almost entirely contingent on social context: the behavior clusters around peer groups, peaks in mid-adolescence, and declines markedly once the individuals enter the workforce or form stable romantic relationships. Neuropsychological testing on these youth reveals largely intact executive functioning, and retrospective parent reports indicate unremarkable early childhood behavioral histories. The researcher argues that this pattern is poorly explained by trait-based or learning-history models and is better understood through the lens of a developmental discontinuity between biological status and socially sanctioned autonomy.
questions.question: The researcher's explanatory framework for this subgroup is MOST consistent with which theoretical construct?

options.A: Patterson's late-starter pathway, in which inadequate parental monitoring during adolescence allows peer deviance to override prosocial behavioral repertoires established in childhood
options.B: Moffitt's maturity gap, in which biologically mature adolescents engage in time-limited antisocial behavior to signal adult status because society has not yet granted them corresponding autonomy
options.C: Arnett's emerging adulthood framework, in which identity exploration and role instability during the late teens and early twenties produces normative risk-taking that is not pathological
options.D: The dual systems model of adolescent risk-taking, in which an imbalance between early-maturing socioemotional incentive systems and later-maturing cognitive control systems drives impulsive peer-oriented behavior

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The described pattern — intact neuropsychology, no early childhood behavioral problems, socially contingent and peer-clustered antisocial behavior, desistance upon entry into adult roles — precisely matches Moffitt's adolescent-limited trajectory explained by the maturity gap. The researcher's explicit framing as a 'developmental discontinuity between biological status and socially sanctioned autonomy' is a paraphrase of the maturity gap mechanism.
option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. Patterson's late-starter pathway also describes adolescent-onset antisocial behavior without a troubled early childhood, making it a strong distractor. However, Patterson's model attributes the onset to failures in parental monitoring rather than a biological-autonomy discontinuity, and it does not predict desistance specifically tied to attainment of adult social roles. The researcher's framing does not invoke parenting variables.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. Arnett's emerging adulthood framework addresses normative identity exploration and risk-taking in late adolescence/early adulthood (roughly ages 18–25) and frames this period as a distinct developmental stage, not as a function of a gap between biological maturity and social recognition. It also does not specifically predict conduct problems that cluster in mid-adolescence and resolve upon entering adult roles.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. The dual systems model (Steinberg) attributes adolescent risk-taking to neurobiological imbalance — heightened reward sensitivity preceding maturation of prefrontal inhibitory control — which is a neurobiological explanation. The vignette explicitly notes intact neuropsychological functioning and emphasizes a social-structural discontinuity, making the dual systems model a poor fit despite its surface plausibility for adolescent peer-oriented behavior.

questions.source_summary: Moffitt's "maturity gap" is most useful for understanding the etiology of adolescent-onset conduct disorder.
questions.vignette: A 14-year-old girl who began menstruating at age 11 has recently started breaking curfew, stealing cosmetics with friends, and talking back to teachers. Her elementary school teachers described her as cooperative, sociable, and academically motivated. Psychological testing reveals no deficits in attention, memory, or problem-solving. Her mother, who works long hours, worries she is not home enough to supervise her daughter, and notes that the girl's new friends are two years older and frequently in trouble. The girl tells her counselor, 'I'm basically an adult — I just want to be treated like one for once.' Her behavior has not escalated to physical aggression, and her grades, though recently declining, have not collapsed.
questions.question: The etiological mechanism MOST strongly supported by this case is:

options.A: Deficient parental monitoring during a critical developmental window, in which reduced supervision allows exposure to deviant peers who model and reinforce antisocial behavior
options.B: A developmental gap between the attainment of biological maturity and access to socially legitimate adult roles and autonomy, which motivates time-limited rule-breaking as a proxy for adult status
options.C: Neurobiological imbalance between a sensitized reward system and still-maturing inhibitory control, producing heightened susceptibility to peer influence and impulsive decision-making in adolescence
options.D: An emerging oppositional pattern driven by resentment of authority figures, reflecting a developmental precursor to a more pervasive disruptive behavior syndrome

option_explanations.B: This is correct. Every specific detail in the vignette maps onto Moffitt's maturity gap explanation for adolescent-limited conduct problems: early biological maturity (menarche at 11), intact cognition (no neuropsychological deficits), no early behavioral history, peer-dependent offense pattern, expressed grievance about not being treated as an adult, and behavior that is petty rather than escalating — all hallmarks of the adolescent-limited trajectory driven by the maturity gap.
option_explanations.A: This is incorrect and is the primary red herring. The mother's long work hours and the older deviant peer group make inadequate parental monitoring (Patterson's model) highly compelling. However, Patterson's model emphasizes that monitoring failures are the proximate cause, whereas the girl's own explicit statement about wanting adult treatment, her early biological maturity, and the absence of any escalation toward violence point to the maturity gap as the more precise explanatory mechanism. Monitoring deficits may be a contributing context but do not constitute the primary etiological mechanism Moffitt's taxonomy identifies.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. The dual systems neurobiological model is also a strong distractor given the peer-oriented impulsivity and adolescent timing. However, the vignette specifies intact neuropsychological functioning and the girl's peer-influenced behavior is non-impulsive theft with friends rather than reactive aggression — and critically, her self-report centers on social status rather than reward-seeking or thrill. The maturity gap better accounts for the social-structural dimension explicitly voiced by the client.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. An oppositional pattern escalating toward a pervasive disruptive behavior syndrome would be expected to have shown earlier signs of defiance and would be predicted to worsen rather than remit. The vignette provides no early childhood behavioral history suggesting oppositional defiant disorder, and the behavior pattern — socially contingent, peer-dependent, non-aggressive — is inconsistent with a pervasive oppositional trajectory.

questions.source_summary: Based on the symptoms presented, the most likely diagnosis for 16-year-old Sam, who started complaining about hearing voices two weeks ago after his father was diagnosed with lung cancer, is brief psychotic disorder.
questions.vignette: A 16-year-old male presents to an outpatient clinic after his mother noticed he had been acting strangely for the past ten days. He reports hearing voices that comment on his actions, which began shortly after learning that his father had been diagnosed with a terminal illness. The clinician notes that this hallucination emerged in direct temporal relation to this marked psychosocial stressor and that the patient had no prior psychiatric history. The patient's symptoms are expected to fully resolve within a month.
questions.question: Based on the DSM-5, which diagnosis best fits this clinical presentation?

options.A: Schizophreniform disorder
options.B: Brief psychotic disorder
options.C: Adjustment disorder with anxious mood
options.D: Schizophrenia

option_explanations.A: Schizophreniform disorder requires the presence of schizophrenia-spectrum symptoms lasting between one and six months. This patient's symptoms have been present for only ten days and are expected to resolve within a month, falling well short of the minimum duration required.
option_explanations.B: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of at least one positive psychotic symptom (such as hallucinations) lasting more than one day but less than one month, and it may be specified as occurring with marked stressor. This patient's auditory hallucinations began in direct response to a significant psychosocial stressor and are of short duration, fitting this diagnosis precisely.
option_explanations.C: Adjustment disorder with anxious mood involves emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor, but it does not include psychotic features such as hallucinations. Psychotic symptoms like those described here exceed the diagnostic threshold for adjustment disorder.
option_explanations.D: Schizophrenia requires at least two characteristic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, or grossly disorganized behavior) for a significant portion of a one-month period, along with continuous signs of disturbance for at least six months. This patient's presentation is too brief and lacks the duration and chronicity required.

questions.source_summary: Based on the symptoms presented, the most likely diagnosis for 16-year-old Sam, who started complaining about hearing voices two weeks ago after his father was diagnosed with lung cancer, is brief psychotic disorder.
questions.vignette: A 16-year-old male is brought to a crisis evaluation center by his parents after they noticed he had been talking to himself and appeared frightened for the past two weeks. He reports hearing a man's voice telling him he is to blame for his father's illness, which was diagnosed with lung cancer three weeks ago. He also endorses mild sleep disturbance and has been missing school, though his teachers describe him as a previously high-functioning honors student. No substance use is found on toxicology screening, and his pediatrician confirms no medical conditions that could account for his symptoms.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis most accurately accounts for this adolescent's full clinical picture?

options.A: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
options.B: Schizophreniform disorder
options.C: Brief psychotic disorder
options.D: Reactive attachment disorder

option_explanations.A: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features requires that psychotic symptoms occur exclusively within the context of a major depressive episode, including depressed mood or anhedonia persisting for at least two weeks along with multiple neurovegetative symptoms. While this patient has sleep disturbance and school avoidance, he does not meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode; his primary presentation is the hallucination, not a sustained depressive syndrome.
option_explanations.B: Schizophreniform disorder requires a symptomatic period of at least one month but fewer than six months, inclusive of positive psychotic symptoms. This patient has only been symptomatic for two weeks, which does not satisfy the minimum duration threshold for this diagnosis.
option_explanations.C: Brief psychotic disorder is the correct diagnosis. The patient has at least one prominent positive psychotic symptom — an auditory hallucination — that emerged abruptly in direct response to a severe identifiable stressor (his father's cancer diagnosis) and has lasted less than one month. The sleep disturbance and school avoidance are secondary, stress-related features that do not alter the primary diagnosis.
option_explanations.D: Reactive attachment disorder is a childhood condition characterized by a consistent pattern of inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior toward adult caregivers, typically arising from severe social neglect or abuse early in life. It does not involve psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations and is not applicable here.

questions.source_summary: Based on the symptoms presented, the most likely diagnosis for 16-year-old Sam, who started complaining about hearing voices two weeks ago after his father was diagnosed with lung cancer, is brief psychotic disorder.
questions.vignette: A 16-year-old male with no psychiatric history is referred for evaluation after his school counselor grew concerned about a sudden change in his behavior over the past two weeks. The boy reports hearing voices that accuse him of causing his father's illness, which was recently diagnosed as terminal. His mother notes he has seemed emotionally numb and withdrawn, and she worries he may be developing a serious, long-term mental illness. A thorough medical workup is negative, and a structured interview reveals no history of mood episodes, but the boy does admit he smoked marijuana once at a party approximately six weeks ago.
questions.question: Which diagnosis best accounts for this presentation when all available clinical information is considered?

options.A: Substance-induced psychotic disorder
options.B: Schizophreniform disorder
options.C: Schizophrenia
options.D: Brief psychotic disorder

option_explanations.A: Substance-induced psychotic disorder requires that hallucinations or delusions develop during or shortly after substance intoxication or withdrawal and would not be better explained by a primary psychotic disorder. This patient's single marijuana use occurred six weeks before symptom onset — well outside the window of expected intoxication or withdrawal — making substance induction implausible. The temporal gap is the key detail that rules this out.
option_explanations.B: Schizophreniform disorder applies when schizophrenia-spectrum symptoms persist for at least one month but fewer than six months. This patient has been symptomatic for only two weeks, which does not meet the minimum one-month duration threshold for schizophreniform disorder, even though this diagnosis might seem plausible given the mother's concern about chronicity.
option_explanations.C: Schizophrenia requires at least six months of continuous disturbance and at least one month of active-phase symptoms, along with significant functional decline. The two-week duration of symptoms and acute onset tied to a clear stressor do not support this diagnosis. The emotional numbing and withdrawal are stress-reactive features rather than evidence of the persistent negative symptoms required.
option_explanations.D: Brief psychotic disorder is correct. The patient has an auditory hallucination (hearing voices) that began abruptly in temporal association with a severe psychosocial stressor (his father's terminal diagnosis) and has lasted fewer than one month. The negative-appearing symptoms are likely grief- and stress-related rather than true negative symptoms. The isolated prior marijuana use does not account for the current presentation given the temporal gap.

questions.source_summary: Based on the symptoms presented, the most likely diagnosis for 16-year-old Sam, who started complaining about hearing voices two weeks ago after his father was diagnosed with lung cancer, is brief psychotic disorder.
questions.vignette: A 16-year-old male is evaluated after a two-week period in which he began believing that voices he heard were revealing hidden truths about his responsibility for his father's serious illness. His presentation is acute, with a clear precipitating event identified in the recent medical crisis within his family. He scores in the clinical range on a depression inventory, and his parents report that he had a maternal uncle who was diagnosed with schizophrenia in his early twenties. Mental status examination reveals a euthymic baseline punctuated by intense moments of distress, intact orientation, and no formal thought disorder. Medical and toxicological workup is unremarkable.
questions.question: Considering all of the clinical evidence, including factors that may suggest alternative diagnoses, which DSM-5 diagnosis is most appropriate?

options.A: Schizophrenia, first episode
options.B: Brief psychotic disorder
options.C: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
options.D: Schizophreniform disorder

option_explanations.A: Schizophrenia, first episode requires at least six months of continuous signs of the disturbance, including at least one month of active-phase symptoms. Despite the family history of schizophrenia in a first-degree relative of the prior generation, which increases genetic risk, the patient's total symptom duration is only two weeks, making this diagnosis premature and inconsistent with DSM-5 duration criteria.
option_explanations.B: Brief psychotic disorder is the most accurate diagnosis. The symptoms — including what appear to be referential or persecutory auditory perceptions — began acutely in direct association with a severe stressor, have lasted fewer than one month, and occur in the absence of a full mood episode or chronic course. The elevated depression inventory score reflects understandable grief and distress, not a primary depressive episode. The family history and the single-item depression score elevation are red herrings that must be weighed against the defining temporal and duration criteria.
option_explanations.C: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features requires that the psychotic symptoms occur exclusively during a full major depressive episode, defined by at least five neurovegetative or affective symptoms persisting for two weeks. While the patient scores in the clinical range on a depression measure, his mental status reveals a euthymic baseline, and the vignette does not describe the pervasive depressed mood or anhedonia necessary to anchor a major depressive episode.
option_explanations.D: Schizophreniform disorder requires that the full syndromal criteria for schizophrenia — including at least one month of active psychotic symptoms — be met before the six-month threshold. At two weeks of symptoms, this patient does not meet even the minimum one-month duration of active symptoms required for schizophreniform disorder, though the family history might lead a student to consider this trajectory.

questions.source_summary: Based on the symptoms presented, the most likely diagnosis for 16-year-old Sam, who started complaining about hearing voices two weeks ago after his father was diagnosed with lung cancer, is brief psychotic disorder.
questions.vignette: A 16-year-old male who had been consistently earning high grades and participating in team sports began, approximately twelve days ago, telling his parents that he was receiving messages through the sounds in his room. This onset coincided with the day he accompanied his mother to the hospital to receive news about his father's prognosis for a serious illness. His pediatrician notes that his paternal grandmother was treated for a condition involving persistent unusual beliefs throughout her adult life, and his current depression screening score is elevated. He does not appear globally confused, he recognizes his family members, and within the same appointment he is able to discuss his father's situation with appropriate sadness and some tearfulness before again mentioning the messages.
questions.question: Which diagnosis best accounts for this adolescent's presentation when the full clinical picture is carefully analyzed?

options.A: Schizophreniform disorder
options.B: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
options.C: Brief psychotic disorder
options.D: Delusional disorder

option_explanations.A: Schizophreniform disorder requires that active-phase psychotic symptoms persist for at least one month (up to six months). This adolescent has been experiencing symptoms for only twelve days — well below the minimum one-month duration threshold. Although the grandmother's history of persistent unusual beliefs may suggest a schizophrenia-spectrum vulnerability, family history alone cannot satisfy the duration criterion, and this diagnosis is premature.
option_explanations.B: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features is a compelling distractor because of the elevated depression score and the recent traumatic family news. However, this diagnosis requires the presence of a full major depressive episode, meaning at least five characteristic depressive symptoms persisting for two weeks. The vignette describes appropriate sadness tied to a specific event and an elevated screening score — neither of which constitutes a full major depressive episode. Additionally, the 'messages' appear to be the primary feature, not secondary to a sustained depressive syndrome.
option_explanations.C: Brief psychotic disorder is the correct diagnosis. The patient is experiencing a perceptual disturbance (interpreting sounds as carrying personal messages, a form of ideas of reference or hallucination) that began abruptly — identifiable to a specific day — in direct response to an overwhelming psychosocial stressor, and symptoms have persisted for fewer than one month. The absence of confusion, intact recognition of others, and preserved capacity for emotionally appropriate discussion all indicate that this is a circumscribed, stress-precipitated psychotic episode rather than a neurodegenerative or mood-anchored process.
option_explanations.D: Delusional disorder involves one or more delusions lasting at least one month in the absence of other prominent psychotic symptoms (such as hallucinations). The twelve-day duration does not meet the one-month minimum, and the patient's experience involves perceptual phenomena (messages through sounds) rather than a fixed belief system characteristic of delusional disorder. Additionally, delusional disorder is rare in adolescents and typically does not present with such clear acute onset tied to a recent stressor.

questions.source_summary: Exposure with response prevention is considered a research-supported treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder.
questions.vignette: A licensed psychologist is designing a treatment plan for a 34-year-old man diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder who spends up to four hours daily washing his hands due to contamination fears. The psychologist explains that the treatment will involve deliberately touching objects the patient perceives as contaminated — a procedure called exposure — while refraining from the hand-washing ritual, which constitutes response prevention. The psychologist notes that this combination is considered the gold-standard behavioral intervention for his condition. The patient's intrusive thoughts are ego-dystonic, and he experiences significant distress when unable to complete his rituals.
questions.question: Which treatment approach is the psychologist describing for this patient's obsessive-compulsive disorder?

options.A: Systematic desensitization
options.B: Exposure with response prevention (ERP)
options.C: Acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT)
options.D: Habit reversal training

option_explanations.A: Systematic desensitization involves pairing graduated exposure to feared stimuli with relaxation techniques to reduce anxiety. It does not include the explicit instruction to refrain from performing compulsive rituals, which is the defining feature of response prevention in ERP.
option_explanations.B: Exposure with response prevention (ERP) is the empirically supported behavioral treatment for OCD that combines deliberate confrontation of feared stimuli (exposure) with refraining from compulsive rituals (response prevention). The vignette explicitly describes both components and identifies OCD as the target condition.
option_explanations.C: Acceptance and commitment therapy uses mindfulness and psychological flexibility strategies to change the client's relationship to unwanted thoughts rather than directly exposing them to feared stimuli and blocking rituals. While used adjunctively with OCD, it is not the primary behavioral technique described.
option_explanations.D: Habit reversal training is an empirically supported treatment for tic disorders and trichotillomania, not OCD. It involves awareness training and competing response procedures rather than exposure to feared stimuli combined with ritual prevention.

questions.source_summary: Exposure with response prevention is considered a research-supported treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder.
questions.vignette: A 28-year-old graduate student presents to a university counseling center reporting persistent, unwanted fears that she has left her stove on, even after repeatedly checking. She describes performing checking compulsions up to 30 times before leaving her apartment, making her chronically late to class. Her therapist notes that she also experiences moderate generalized worry about academic performance and social situations, but the ritualistic checking is the primary functional impairment. The therapist proposes a structured treatment in which the client will practice leaving her apartment without returning to check, beginning with shorter durations and gradually extending them, while refraining from any checking behavior during and after exposure trials.
questions.question: What evidence-based treatment is the therapist implementing for this client's primary presenting problem?

options.A: Cognitive restructuring with behavioral experiments
options.B: Exposure with response prevention (ERP)
options.C: Worry postponement with applied relaxation
options.D: Graduated exposure with relaxation training

option_explanations.B: ERP is the first-line behavioral treatment for OCD and is precisely what is described: structured, graduated confrontation with feared situations (leaving without checking) while explicitly preventing the compulsive response (checking). The co-occurring generalized worry is a neutral distractor and does not change the primary diagnosis or treatment selection.
option_explanations.A: Cognitive restructuring with behavioral experiments targets maladaptive beliefs through Socratic questioning and hypothesis-testing experiments. While cognitive techniques are sometimes combined with ERP for OCD, the vignette describes a purely behavioral protocol focused on response prevention, not belief restructuring.
option_explanations.C: Worry postponement and applied relaxation are techniques associated with the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder, which is relevant here as a distracting detail. These approaches do not include the explicit ritual-prevention component that defines ERP and distinguishes OCD treatment from GAD treatment.
option_explanations.D: Graduated exposure with relaxation training describes systematic desensitization, in which each exposure step is paired with a relaxation response to reduce anxiety. The critical distinction is that ERP explicitly instructs the client to refrain from rituals and tolerate anxiety rather than neutralizing it with relaxation.

questions.source_summary: Exposure with response prevention is considered a research-supported treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder.
questions.vignette: A 41-year-old accountant seeks treatment after his wife insists he 'get help' for his need to arrange items on his desk in a precise order before he can begin working. He reports that failing to complete this ritualistic sequence leads to severe distress and a conviction that 'something bad will happen,' though he acknowledges his fears are irrational. He has tried simply 'powering through' the distress on his own, but always eventually returns to the sequence to reduce his anxiety. His therapist, noting the ego-dystonic nature of his symptoms, proposes a structured behavioral protocol in which the client will intentionally leave items disarranged and remain in that state without reordering them, with session length and distress levels carefully tracked.
questions.question: Which treatment approach does the therapist's proposed protocol most closely represent?

options.A: Flooding
options.B: Cognitive processing therapy (CPT)
options.C: Exposure with response prevention (ERP)
options.D: Behavioral activation

option_explanations.C: The therapist's protocol involves deliberately confronting the feared stimulus (disarranged items) while explicitly withholding the compulsive response (reordering), which precisely defines ERP. The graduated, tracked approach and the ego-dystonic symptom presentation confirm this is OCD being treated with its first-line behavioral intervention.
option_explanations.A: Flooding involves prolonged, intense exposure to feared stimuli without gradual hierarchy progression. While flooding is a form of exposure, the vignette's emphasis on tracking distress levels and using a structured, measured approach suggests a graduated ERP protocol rather than ungraded flooding; moreover, flooding does not specifically include a response-prevention component for compulsive rituals.
option_explanations.B: Cognitive processing therapy is an evidence-based treatment specifically developed for PTSD, focusing on identifying and modifying trauma-related stuck points. Although the client has intrusive cognitions, there is no trauma history mentioned, and CPT does not include exposure-and-ritual-prevention procedures.
option_explanations.D: Behavioral activation is an empirically supported treatment for depression that works by scheduling rewarding or meaningful activities to counteract withdrawal and avoidance. The client's presentation involves ritualistic sequencing driven by anxiety and feared consequences, not motivational deficits or anhedonia consistent with depression.

questions.source_summary: Exposure with response prevention is considered a research-supported treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder.
questions.vignette: A psychologist conducting a treatment outcome study is comparing two active conditions for patients with contamination-related fears and neutralizing behaviors. In Condition A, patients are instructed to touch feared objects and then engage in progressive muscle relaxation immediately afterward to manage distress. In Condition B, patients touch the same feared objects but are explicitly instructed to remain in contact and tolerate their anxiety without engaging in any neutralizing strategy, with the goal of inhibitory learning — demonstrating to the patient that the feared outcome does not occur and that anxiety naturally diminishes. Post-treatment assessments show significantly greater reductions in ritual frequency and overall symptom severity in Condition B. The psychologist argues that the mechanism of change in Condition B is fundamentally different from that in Condition A.
questions.question: Which established treatment protocol does Condition B most precisely represent?

options.A: Systematic desensitization
options.B: Exposure with response prevention (ERP)
options.C: Acceptance-based exposure therapy
options.D: Prolonged exposure therapy

option_explanations.B: Condition B defines ERP: deliberate contact with feared stimuli combined with explicit prevention of neutralizing responses, allowing anxiety to habituate and inhibitory learning to occur. The psychologist's emphasis on tolerating anxiety without any neutralizing strategy — and the focus on ritual frequency as the outcome — directly maps to ERP's core mechanism and target population.
option_explanations.A: Systematic desensitization describes Condition A, not Condition B. Condition A pairs exposure with relaxation (a competing response), which is the defining feature of systematic desensitization. Systematic desensitization does not include a response-prevention component and is not considered the first-line treatment for OCD.
option_explanations.C: Acceptance-based exposure therapy emphasizes psychological flexibility and non-judgmental awareness of distressing internal experiences during exposure. While it shares with ERP the instruction to tolerate anxiety without avoidance, it focuses on changing the client's relationship to internal states rather than specifically blocking external neutralizing rituals. The vignette's emphasis on inhibitory learning and ritual prevention is more characteristic of standard ERP.
option_explanations.D: Prolonged exposure therapy is an evidence-based protocol for PTSD that includes imaginal and in vivo exposure to trauma-related stimuli. While it shares the 'exposure without escape' logic, it does not target compulsive rituals or neutralizing behaviors, and the patients in the vignette have contamination fears and neutralizing behaviors consistent with OCD, not PTSD.

questions.source_summary: Exposure with response prevention is considered a research-supported treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder.
questions.vignette: A clinician is working with a 38-year-old woman who experiences intense unease when she perceives that everyday objects around her home are not arranged symmetrically. She reports that she has tried to stop herself from acting on this unease but cannot — she describes the urge to act as 'not coming from who I really am.' Her previous therapist had encouraged her to use deep breathing and visualize a calm place whenever she felt this unease, which provided temporary relief but did not reduce how often the urge arose or how strongly she felt compelled to act on it. Her current clinician proposes a new approach: the client will deliberately place objects asymmetrically and then remain in the room without touching them, for progressively longer periods, until the unease decreases on its own. The clinician explains that the goal is for the client to learn, through direct experience, that the unease is tolerable and that the feared consequence does not materialize.
questions.question: Which treatment approach does the current clinician's protocol most precisely represent?

options.A: Systematic desensitization
options.B: Acceptance and commitment therapy
options.C: Exposure with response prevention (ERP)
options.D: Dialectical behavior therapy skills training

option_explanations.C: The current clinician's protocol is ERP: deliberate, graduated confrontation with the feared stimulus (asymmetrical objects) paired with explicit prevention of the neutralizing response (touching/rearranging), with the goal of demonstrating that distress is tolerable and feared consequences do not occur. The client's description of urges as alien to her identity signals the ego-dystonic quality of OCD, and the prior treatment's failure (relaxation provided only temporary relief without reducing urge frequency) distinguishes ERP from approaches that pair exposure with relaxation.
option_explanations.A: Systematic desensitization is precisely what the previous therapist was doing: pairing the anxiety-provoking stimulus with a relaxation response (deep breathing, calm imagery) to counteract anxiety. The current clinician's approach differs fundamentally by removing the relaxation component and instructing the client to tolerate anxiety without neutralizing it, which disqualifies systematic desensitization.
option_explanations.B: Acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) would emphasize mindful awareness, values-based action, and defusion from distressing thoughts rather than a structured behavioral protocol of deliberately inducing distress and tracking its natural diminishment. While ACT encourages tolerating internal discomfort, the vignette's specific focus on blocking a behavioral response to an external trigger and waiting for anxiety to naturally subside is more characteristic of ERP's habituation and inhibitory learning model.
option_explanations.D: Dialectical behavior therapy skills training focuses on teaching emotional regulation, distress tolerance, interpersonal effectiveness, and mindfulness skills — primarily developed for borderline personality disorder and related problems of emotional dysregulation. It does not involve structured, repeated confrontation with a specific feared stimulus paired with the explicit blocking of a behavioral ritual.

questions.source_summary: Pregnant women with pica consume clay, coffee grounds, and other nonnutritive, nonfood substances, as the DSM-5 diagnosis of pica requires the persistent consumption of such substances that is inappropriate for the person's developmental level and is not part of a socially or culturally sanctioned practice.
questions.vignette: A 28-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy is referred to a psychologist after her obstetrician notices she has been persistently consuming clay and coffee grounds. The patient reports that this behavior has been ongoing for several weeks and that she finds these nonnutritive, nonfood substances irresistible. She is aware that her consumption is unusual and is not part of any culturally sanctioned practice in her community. A full assessment confirms the behavior is not better explained by another medical condition or developmental disability.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis BEST accounts for this patient's presentation?

options.A: Pica
options.B: Rumination disorder
options.C: Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID)
options.D: Binge-eating disorder

option_explanations.A: Correct. Pica is defined by the persistent ingestion of nonnutritive, nonfood substances that is inappropriate for the individual's developmental level and is not culturally sanctioned. This patient's repeated consumption of clay and coffee grounds during pregnancy fits all DSM-5 criteria precisely.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Rumination disorder involves the repeated regurgitation of food — bringing previously swallowed food back up to re-chew, re-swallow, or spit out — rather than consuming nonnutritive, nonfood substances. The patient does not report any regurgitation behavior.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. ARFID is characterized by restricted food intake based on sensory features, fear of choking, or lack of interest in eating, resulting in nutritional deficiency. It involves avoidance of food, not the addition of nonfood substances, and does not describe craving for items like clay or coffee grounds.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Binge-eating disorder involves recurrent episodes of consuming large quantities of food in a discrete period with a sense of loss of control, not the ingestion of nonfood substances. Clay and coffee grounds are not foods consumed in a binge episode.

questions.source_summary: Pregnant women with pica consume clay, coffee grounds, and other nonnutritive, nonfood substances, as the DSM-5 diagnosis of pica requires the persistent consumption of such substances that is inappropriate for the person's developmental level and is not part of a socially or culturally sanctioned practice.
questions.vignette: A 31-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester presents to her obstetrician reporting strong urges to eat ice, cornstarch, and dirt. She states that these urges have been present for about two months and that she acts on them daily. Her iron levels are found to be low, and her physician initially attributes the behavior solely to her anemia; however, the patient clarifies that she also craves and consumes these nonfood items between iron supplementation doses and that the behavior predates the anemia diagnosis. The behavior is not practiced in her cultural community and is not consistent with any developmental delay.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis BEST explains this patient's eating behavior?

options.A: Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID)
options.B: Rumination disorder
options.C: Pica
options.D: Other specified feeding or eating disorder (OSFED)

option_explanations.C: Correct. Pica requires persistent ingestion of nonfood, nonnutritive substances that is not developmentally appropriate and not culturally sanctioned. Although anemia may co-occur with pica, DSM-5 specifies that if pica occurs in the context of another medical condition (such as iron deficiency), it still warrants a separate diagnosis when it is severe enough to merit clinical attention — which it clearly does here.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. ARFID involves restricted intake of food due to sensory sensitivity, fear of adverse consequences, or lack of interest in eating. It does not involve the ingestion of nonfood substances such as ice, cornstarch, or dirt, which is the defining feature of this patient's presentation.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Rumination disorder is characterized by the repeated regurgitation and re-chewing or spitting out of previously swallowed food, not by cravings for or consumption of nonfood substances. This patient reports actively seeking and consuming nonfood items, which is inconsistent with rumination.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. OSFED is a residual category used when a clinician judges that a patient's feeding or eating disturbance causes significant impairment but does not fully meet criteria for a more specific disorder. Because this patient's presentation meets full DSM-5 criteria for pica, OSFED is not the appropriate diagnosis.

questions.source_summary: Pregnant women with pica consume clay, coffee grounds, and other nonnutritive, nonfood substances, as the DSM-5 diagnosis of pica requires the persistent consumption of such substances that is inappropriate for the person's developmental level and is not part of a socially or culturally sanctioned practice.
questions.vignette: A 26-year-old woman who is 18 weeks pregnant is brought in by her partner, who reports that she has been eating laundry starch and raw rice flour for the past six weeks. The patient becomes defensive and notes that her grandmother 'always did this during pregnancy' in their home country, but further inquiry reveals that this practice is not common in her extended family or local immigrant community and is not endorsed by any cultural healer or tradition she can specifically identify. Her partner is concerned because she recently ate a small piece of drywall. A developmental history is unremarkable, and she has no prior psychiatric diagnoses.
questions.question: What is the MOST appropriate DSM-5 diagnosis for this patient?

options.A: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
options.B: Pica
options.C: Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID)
options.D: Specific phobia, other type

option_explanations.B: Correct. Pica requires persistent ingestion of nonfood, nonnutritive substances that is inappropriate given the individual's developmental level and is not part of a culturally sanctioned practice. Although the patient attempts to normalize the behavior by referencing her grandmother, she cannot identify a recognized cultural or community practice that sanctions it, and the behavior is developmentally inappropriate for an adult — meeting all DSM-5 pica criteria.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. OCD involves intrusive, ego-dystonic obsessions and compulsive rituals performed to reduce distress, and while some OCD presentations can involve ingestion of unusual items, the patient here does not describe distressing intrusive thoughts or rituals aimed at anxiety reduction. Her consumption appears driven by craving, not compulsion to neutralize an obsession.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. ARFID involves restricted or selective eating patterns related to sensory aversion, fear of aversive consequences, or low interest in food. Critically, ARFID involves avoidance of certain foods — not active craving and consumption of nonfood substances such as laundry starch and drywall.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Specific phobia involves marked fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation, leading to avoidance behavior. This patient is consuming nonfood substances — the opposite of avoidance — and there is no indication that a phobic stimulus is driving her behavior.

questions.source_summary: Pregnant women with pica consume clay, coffee grounds, and other nonnutritive, nonfood substances, as the DSM-5 diagnosis of pica requires the persistent consumption of such substances that is inappropriate for the person's developmental level and is not part of a socially or culturally sanctioned practice.
questions.vignette: A 34-year-old woman who recently immigrated from West Africa is 24 weeks pregnant and is seen in prenatal care. Her midwife notes that the patient mentions eating clay tablets purchased from a local market, a practice she says is common among pregnant women in her home village and is believed to provide minerals for the fetus. A community health worker who speaks the patient's language is consulted and reports that while clay eating exists in some regions of the patient's country of origin, it is not a recognized practice in the specific ethnic community to which this patient belongs. The patient has no intellectual disability, has a graduate education, and reports consuming the clay daily for the past two months with no intention to stop.
questions.question: Which of the following diagnoses is MOST warranted in this case?

options.A: No diagnosis; this represents a culturally normative practice
options.B: Pica
options.C: Obsessive-compulsive and related disorder, unspecified
options.D: Other specified feeding or eating disorder (OSFED)

option_explanations.B: Correct. DSM-5 explicitly states that pica should not be diagnosed when ingestion of nonfood substances is part of a culturally sanctioned practice. However, the community health worker's consultation establishes that this behavior is NOT part of the patient's specific cultural community's recognized practices — it is a generalized, unverified belief she holds individually. Therefore, the cultural exclusion criterion does not apply, and all remaining DSM-5 pica criteria are met.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. While clay eating does occur in certain cultural contexts and DSM-5 does include a cultural exemption for pica, this exemption requires that the behavior be a recognized, sanctioned practice within the patient's specific community. The community health worker's report directly refutes that this behavior is culturally sanctioned for this patient's ethnic group, making a 'no diagnosis' determination inaccurate.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. OCD and related disorders involve repetitive behaviors driven by intrusive thoughts, obsessions, or perceived threats requiring neutralization. The patient describes a deliberate, belief-driven consumption behavior with no reported ego-dystonic obsessions or distress associated with not performing the behavior, which does not align with OCD-spectrum phenomenology.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. OSFED applies when a clinician determines that a feeding or eating disturbance causes clinically significant impairment but does not meet full criteria for a specified disorder. Because this patient's presentation meets all DSM-5 pica criteria once the cultural exemption is ruled out, pica is the appropriate specific diagnosis rather than the residual OSFED category.

questions.source_summary: Pregnant women with pica consume clay, coffee grounds, and other nonnutritive, nonfood substances, as the DSM-5 diagnosis of pica requires the persistent consumption of such substances that is inappropriate for the person's developmental level and is not part of a socially or culturally sanctioned practice.
questions.vignette: A 29-year-old woman who is six months pregnant presents to her primary care provider after her partner expresses concern about her eating habits. For the past ten weeks, she has been regularly consuming small amounts of baking soda, chalk, and dried coffee grounds, insisting she 'just needs them.' She reports no anxiety, no distressing intrusive thoughts, and no sense of loss of control — she simply finds these substances appealing and seeks them out deliberately each day. She grew up in a household where her mother occasionally ate chalk during pregnancies and believed it was 'traditional,' but the patient cannot identify any elder, religious leader, or community group that formally endorses or practices this. Her intake of regular meals is entirely normal, and her weight gain is appropriate for gestation.
questions.question: Which of the following diagnoses BEST accounts for this patient's presentation?

options.A: Binge-eating disorder
options.B: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
options.C: Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID)
options.D: Pica

option_explanations.D: Correct. Pica requires persistent ingestion of nonnutritive, nonfood substances that is inappropriate for the individual's developmental level and is not part of a formally recognized cultural or community practice. Despite the patient's reference to her mother's behavior, she cannot identify a recognized cultural authority or group that sanctions it, which rules out the cultural exemption. The absence of meal restriction, ego-dystonic obsessions, or bingeing episodes distinguishes pica from the distractors.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Binge-eating disorder involves recurrent episodes of consuming large quantities of food in a discrete time period accompanied by a subjective sense of loss of control and marked distress. The patient here reports no loss of control, no distress, and is consuming nonfood substances — not food in excessive quantities — making binge-eating disorder inconsistent with this presentation.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. OCD involves intrusive, unwanted, ego-dystonic thoughts that produce distress, and compulsions are performed to reduce that distress. This patient explicitly denies intrusive thoughts, anxiety, or distress and describes her consumption as simply appealing and deliberate. The craving-driven, ego-syntonic nature of her behavior does not fit OCD phenomenology.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. ARFID is characterized by restriction or avoidance of food intake due to sensory aversion, fear of choking or vomiting, or low interest in eating, leading to nutritional deficiency or significant weight loss. This patient maintains normal meals and appropriate gestational weight gain and is not avoiding food — she is adding nonfood substances to her intake, which is the opposite pattern ARFID describes.

questions.source_summary: The DSM-5 diagnosis of intermittent explosive disorder cannot be assigned to individuals under the chronological age of six years or the equivalent developmental level.
questions.vignette: A child psychologist is evaluating a 5-year-old boy who has been referred for episodic outbursts of rage, during which he throws objects, screams uncontrollably, and strikes family members. The outbursts are brief, disproportionate to any identifiable provocation, and occur approximately twice per week. The psychologist notes that the child's chronological age is five years and that there is no evidence of a developmental delay that would place his developmental level above six years. After reviewing the DSM-5 criteria for intermittent explosive disorder, the psychologist determines that a formal diagnosis cannot be assigned at this time.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 requirement most directly explains why the psychologist cannot diagnose intermittent explosive disorder in this case?

options.A: The DSM-5 requires that explosive outbursts be preceded by a subjective sense of tension, which cannot be reliably assessed in children this young.
options.B: The diagnosis of intermittent explosive disorder cannot be assigned to individuals whose chronological age or developmental level is below six years.
options.C: The outbursts must persist for at least twelve months before intermittent explosive disorder can be formally diagnosed.
options.D: Intermittent explosive disorder requires the presence of physical aggression toward others in at least three separate incidents, which has not yet been documented.

option_explanations.A: Although tension build-up is associated with intermittent explosive disorder, the DSM-5 does not require it as a criterion, and the inability to assess it does not constitute the diagnostic exclusion criterion referenced in the vignette.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The DSM-5 explicitly states that intermittent explosive disorder should not be diagnosed in individuals under the chronological age of six years or whose developmental level is equivalent to below six years, which directly applies to this five-year-old child.
option_explanations.C: While intermittent explosive disorder does require a pattern of recurrent outbursts, a twelve-month duration requirement is associated with other disorders (e.g., oppositional defiant disorder requires some symptoms for six months); this is not the reason the diagnosis is excluded here.
option_explanations.D: The DSM-5 does describe recurrent behavioral outbursts involving physical aggression as a criterion for intermittent explosive disorder, but the specific threshold described here is not accurate as stated, and the primary barrier in this vignette is the age exclusion criterion, not an insufficient count of aggressive incidents.

questions.source_summary: The DSM-5 diagnosis of intermittent explosive disorder cannot be assigned to individuals under the chronological age of six years or the equivalent developmental level.
questions.vignette: A pediatric neuropsychologist is conducting an evaluation of a 5-year-old girl with a known intellectual disability. Her parents report frequent, severe outbursts of aggression that are clearly disproportionate to minor frustrations, occurring multiple times per week. Cognitive testing places her developmental level at approximately 4 years. Despite the similarity of her outbursts to those described in a disruptive impulse-control disorder, the neuropsychologist concludes that this particular diagnosis cannot be assigned. Notably, the parents mention that a maternal uncle received the same diagnosis as an adult, raising questions about a familial pattern.
questions.question: What is the most accurate explanation for why this diagnosis cannot be applied to this child?

options.A: The presence of an intellectual disability is an exclusionary criterion that automatically precludes diagnoses within the disruptive, impulse-control, and conduct disorders category.
options.B: Intermittent explosive disorder cannot be diagnosed when aggressive outbursts are better explained by a neurodevelopmental disorder such as intellectual disability.
options.C: Intermittent explosive disorder requires that both the chronological age and the developmental level meet or exceed six years, and this child meets neither criterion.
options.D: The diagnosis cannot be made because the child's outbursts have not been observed in more than one setting, as is required by DSM-5 criteria.

option_explanations.A: Intellectual disability does not automatically exclude all diagnoses within the disruptive, impulse-control, and conduct disorders category. The relevant exclusion here is specifically age- and developmental-level-based, not a blanket prohibition linked to the presence of a neurodevelopmental disorder.
option_explanations.B: While differential diagnosis considerations involving neurodevelopmental disorders are important, this option misrepresents the DSM-5 rule.
