questions.vignette: A public health department is reviewing outcomes data for two ongoing programs targeting adults who repeatedly try and fail to stop a daily habit that carries significant long-term health risk. Program A involves weekly face-to-face meetings with a trained facilitator and has a one-year success rate of 18%. Program B involves automated, brief check-in messages delivered to participants' phones and costs a fraction of Program A; its one-year success rate is 17%. A third arm — participants who enrolled in Program A and also received Program B's messages — achieved a one-year success rate of 26%. A budget committee, impressed by Program B's near-identical outcomes at lower cost, proposes replacing Program A entirely with Program B to expand reach. A program evaluator objects, arguing that the data do not support full replacement and that the department would be foregoing a reliable and meaningful performance gain.
questions.question: The evaluator's objection most closely reflects which of the following evidence-based conclusions?

options.A: Low-cost digital programs should be scaled broadly before investing in face-to-face programming, because their population-level reach offsets their marginally lower individual efficacy.
options.B: Automated brief contact interventions are effective standalone approaches for habitual health-risk behaviors and produce superior outcomes when combined with structured facilitated programs compared to either modality alone.
options.C: Face-to-face facilitated programs retain clinical superiority over automated contact interventions and should not be replaced despite cost pressures, because therapeutic alliance drives long-term behavioral change.
options.D: Program evaluation data from non-randomized naturalistic settings cannot reliably inform clinical resource allocation decisions and require replication in controlled trial designs before policy changes are warranted.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect because it echoes the budget committee's flawed reasoning. The evaluator's objection is specifically that full replacement sacrifices the demonstrated additive benefit of combining both programs — a gain that is lost if Program A is discontinued regardless of Program B's scalability.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The data show Program B alone is comparable in effectiveness to Program A alone, while the combined condition outperforms Program A alone by a meaningful margin. This is precisely the evidence pattern that supports automated brief contact (text messaging) as both an effective standalone and a superior adjunctive intervention for habitual health-risk behavior cessation.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect because the data do not show Program A to be superior to Program B as a standalone intervention — their outcomes are nearly identical. The evaluator's argument is not about Program A's superiority but about the loss of the additive benefit that combination produces.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect because the evaluator's objection is not methodological skepticism about the data quality. The evaluator accepts the data and uses them to argue against replacement — an argument grounded in the specific outcome pattern, not in concerns about study design limitations.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of cyclothymic disorder requires the presence of characteristic symptoms for at least two years for adults and one year for children and adolescents.
questions.vignette: A 34-year-old woman presents to a community mental health clinic describing a persistent pattern of mood fluctuations she has experienced for the past two years. She reports numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms — elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, and increased goal-directed activity — that do not meet full criteria for a hypomanic episode. These alternate with periods of depressive symptoms that fall short of a major depressive episode. She has never been free of these mood shifts for more than two months at a time, and the cyclothymic pattern has been present continuously throughout this period. Her clinician notes that the symptoms have caused moderate impairment in her occupational functioning.
questions.question: Based on the DSM-5 duration criterion described in this vignette, which diagnosis is most consistent with this presentation?

options.A: Cyclothymic disorder
options.B: Bipolar II disorder
options.C: Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia)
options.D: Bipolar I disorder

option_explanations.A: This is correct. Cyclothymic disorder requires at least two years (in adults) of numerous periods with hypomanic and depressive symptoms that do not meet full criteria for hypomanic or major depressive episodes, with no symptom-free period lasting more than two months — all of which are explicitly described here.
option_explanations.B: Bipolar II disorder requires at least one full hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode. This patient's mood states do not meet the threshold for either a full hypomanic or a full major depressive episode, ruling out bipolar II.
option_explanations.C: Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) involves a chronically depressed mood for at least two years but does not include the alternating hypomanic symptom periods described here. The presence of recurrent hypomanic-like elevations makes cyclothymic disorder the more accurate diagnosis.
option_explanations.D: Bipolar I disorder requires the presence of at least one full manic episode. This patient has never experienced manic symptoms of sufficient severity or duration to meet that threshold, so bipolar I is not appropriate.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of cyclothymic disorder requires the presence of characteristic symptoms for at least two years for adults and one year for children and adolescents.
questions.vignette: A 14-year-old male is referred to an adolescent outpatient clinic by his school counselor after teachers noted that he cycles between periods of unusually high energy — staying up late finishing projects and talking rapidly — and periods of low motivation and sadness. His parents confirm these mood swings have been ongoing for about 14 months, with no stretch longer than five weeks where he seemed emotionally stable. He has also recently been diagnosed with ADHD, which his psychiatrist considers separately. Neither his elevated nor his low periods are severe enough to qualify as full episodes of mania, hypomania, or major depression.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis best accounts for this adolescent's mood symptom presentation, taking into account the relevant duration criterion?

options.A: Bipolar II disorder
options.B: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder
options.C: Cyclothymic disorder
options.D: Persistent depressive disorder

option_explanations.A: Bipolar II disorder requires a full hypomanic episode and a full major depressive episode. This adolescent's elevated and depressive periods do not reach the threshold for full episodes, making bipolar II an inappropriate diagnosis here.
option_explanations.B: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) is characterized by severe, recurrent temper outbursts and persistently irritable or angry mood, not alternating periods of elevated energy and low mood. The cycling pattern described here does not fit DMDD's profile.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. DSM-5 requires that cyclothymic disorder symptoms persist for at least one year in children and adolescents (versus two years in adults). This 14-year-old has had 14 months of sub-threshold hypomanic and depressive periods with no symptom-free interval exceeding two months, satisfying the adolescent duration criterion.
option_explanations.D: Persistent depressive disorder requires at least one year of chronically depressed mood in children and adolescents, but it does not include the alternating periods of elevated energy and reduced sleep described here. The hypomanic-like features point away from this diagnosis.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of cyclothymic disorder requires the presence of characteristic symptoms for at least two years for adults and one year for children and adolescents.
questions.vignette: A 29-year-old graduate student seeks therapy after her academic advisor expressed concern about her inconsistent performance. She describes an episodic pattern of feeling 'on top of the world' for weeks at a time — sleeping only five hours and feeling fully rested, generating ambitious research plans — followed by weeks of feeling flat, unmotivated, and withdrawn. She was previously treated for depression in college and still takes a low-dose antidepressant, which her psychiatrist had prescribed empirically. She denies any history of hospitalization, psychotic symptoms, or periods when her behavior was so extreme that others intervened. These ups and downs have characterized most of the past 26 months, with no stable period exceeding six weeks.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most accurately captures this patient's clinical presentation, particularly given the duration and severity of her mood pattern?

options.A: Bipolar II disorder
options.B: Cyclothymic disorder
options.C: Major depressive disorder with mixed features
options.D: Borderline personality disorder

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The patient has over two years of alternating sub-threshold hypomanic symptoms (decreased sleep, elevated mood, goal-directed behavior) and depressive symptoms that do not meet full episode criteria, with no symptom-free interval exceeding two months. This precisely satisfies DSM-5 criteria for cyclothymic disorder in an adult.
option_explanations.A: Bipolar II disorder requires at least one full hypomanic episode (lasting at least four consecutive days with a distinct change in functioning) and at least one major depressive episode. The patient's elevated periods appear sub-threshold in both duration and severity, and her depressive periods also fall short of major depression, ruling out bipolar II.
option_explanations.C: Major depressive disorder with mixed features specifies that the dominant presentation is a major depressive episode accompanied by sub-threshold hypomanic symptoms. Because this patient's mood shifts are bidirectional and neither pole meets full episode criteria, MDD with mixed features does not capture the overall pattern.
option_explanations.D: Borderline personality disorder involves pervasive instability in affect, identity, and relationships, often with impulsive behavior and fears of abandonment. While mood lability can appear in BPD, the relatively organized cycling pattern here — with defined elevated and depressive phases sustained over 26 months — is more characteristic of a mood disorder than a personality disorder.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of cyclothymic disorder requires the presence of characteristic symptoms for at least two years for adults and one year for children and adolescents.
questions.vignette: A 38-year-old attorney presents for an evaluation after her spouse insisted she seek help. Over the past 28 months, she has intermittently described herself as 'finally hitting my stride' — during these stretches she bills unusually high hours, sleeps six hours without fatigue, and initiates multiple side projects. Her colleagues have noticed these periods but attribute them to her professional ambition. Between these phases, she becomes withdrawn, describes herself as 'uninspired,' and has missed client deadlines on two occasions. She reports that in college she experienced a three-week period of extreme elation and almost no sleep that resulted in a significant interpersonal conflict, though she minimizes this now. A prior therapist had diagnosed her with recurrent depression.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most precisely accounts for this patient's longitudinal presentation, and what makes that diagnosis the best fit over the alternatives?

options.A: Bipolar I disorder
options.B: Bipolar II disorder
options.C: Cyclothymic disorder
options.D: Persistent depressive disorder with hypomanic features

option_explanations.C: This is correct. Despite the distracting college episode, the patient's current and longitudinal mood pattern — 28 months of sub-threshold elevated and depressive phases with no symptom-free period exceeding two months — satisfies the DSM-5 criteria for cyclothymic disorder. The college incident, while suggestive, is historical and may not have met full criteria, and the current pattern remains sub-threshold.
option_explanations.A: Bipolar I disorder requires at least one full manic episode (lasting at least seven days or requiring hospitalization). The college period, though elevated, is described vaguely and involved no hospitalization or intervention; the current 28-month pattern is sub-threshold. Without confirmed mania, bipolar I cannot be diagnosed.
option_explanations.B: Bipolar II disorder requires at least one confirmed full hypomanic episode (at least four consecutive days with a clear functional change) and at least one major depressive episode. While the current elevated phases are suggestive, they appear sub-threshold in duration and severity, and the depressive episodes do not meet full MDD criteria, making bipolar II an overreach.
option_explanations.D: Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) with hypomanic features is not a standard DSM-5 specifier in the way described here. PDD is defined by chronic depressed mood and does not accommodate the bidirectional, cycling pattern that includes periods of elevated energy as a central feature alongside depressive phases.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of cyclothymic disorder requires the presence of characteristic symptoms for at least two years for adults and one year for children and adolescents.
questions.vignette: A 16-year-old girl is brought to a pediatric psychologist by her parents, who describe her as 'impossible to predict.' Over roughly the past 14 months, she has gone through stretches lasting several weeks when she stays up past midnight doing art projects, texts friends at all hours, and speaks about ambitious plans for her future with unusual intensity. These stretches are followed by weeks during which she sleeps excessively, withdraws from her friend group, and tells her parents she sees no point in her schoolwork. Her pediatrician recently began treating her for a thyroid condition, which has been medically stabilized for the past six months; her mood swings predate and have continued beyond the thyroid diagnosis. At no point have her parents needed to intervene to prevent her from harming herself or engaging in dangerous behavior, and a review of her most energized and most withdrawn periods suggests neither has been severe enough to substantially disrupt her daily functioning beyond what is described.
questions.question: Which diagnosis best accounts for this adolescent's presentation across the full 14-month period?

options.A: Bipolar II disorder
options.B: Cyclothymic disorder
options.C: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder
options.D: Mood disorder due to another medical condition

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The DSM-5 requires only one year of the characteristic cycling pattern for children and adolescents to meet the duration threshold for cyclothymic disorder. This 16-year-old has had 14 months of alternating sub-threshold elevated and depressive periods, the mood disturbance predates and persists beyond the medically stabilized thyroid condition, and neither pole meets criteria for a full episode — precisely fitting cyclothymic disorder.
option_explanations.A: Bipolar II disorder requires at least one full hypomanic episode (at least four consecutive days with a distinct, observable change in functioning) and at least one major depressive episode. The review explicitly indicates that neither the elevated nor the withdrawn periods have been severe enough or functionally impairing enough to constitute full episodes, ruling out bipolar II.
option_explanations.C: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is defined by severe, recurrent temper outbursts and persistently irritable or angry mood between outbursts, not alternating multi-week periods of energized behavior and withdrawal. The organized cycling pattern here does not match DMDD's chronic irritability profile.
option_explanations.D: Mood disorder due to another medical condition would be appropriate if the mood disturbance were the direct physiological consequence of the medical condition. However, the vignette specifies that the mood swings predated the thyroid diagnosis and continued after stabilization, making a direct causal link implausible and ruling out this diagnosis.

questions.source_summary: A child with dyslexia whose reading problems significantly interfere with his academic performance and have not substantially improved with appropriate intervention would receive a DSM-5 diagnosis of specific learning disorder.
questions.vignette: A 9-year-old boy is referred for a psychoeducational evaluation because of persistent difficulties with reading accuracy and fluency. His teacher reports that despite targeted reading intervention over the past year, his academic performance in reading-based subjects remains significantly below grade level. Testing reveals a pattern consistent with dyslexia, with particular weakness in phonological decoding and word recognition. His intellectual functioning falls in the average range, and there is no evidence of sensory impairment or neurological disorder. The evaluating psychologist notes that these reading difficulties are pervasive and interfere substantially with his schoolwork.
questions.question: Based on this presentation, which DSM-5 diagnosis best accounts for this child's difficulties?

options.A: Intellectual Disability (Intellectual Developmental Disorder)
options.B: Specific Learning Disorder, with impairment in reading
options.C: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, predominantly inattentive presentation
options.D: Communication Disorder, language disorder subtype

option_explanations.A: Intellectual Disability is characterized by deficits in both intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior across multiple domains, not a circumscribed deficit in reading. This child's average intellectual functioning rules out this diagnosis.
option_explanations.B: Specific Learning Disorder with impairment in reading (which encompasses dyslexia as a specifier) is the correct diagnosis. The DSM-5 requires persistent difficulties in reading that are not accounted for by intellectual, sensory, or neurological factors and that have not responded adequately to intervention — all of which are present here.
option_explanations.C: ADHD, inattentive presentation, involves pervasive inattention across settings and is not characterized primarily by phonological decoding deficits. Although ADHD can co-occur with learning disorders, it does not explain isolated reading deficits in the absence of described attention symptoms.
option_explanations.D: Language Disorder involves difficulties in the acquisition and use of spoken or written language across multiple modalities (e.g., vocabulary, grammar, discourse), which is broader than the specific phonological decoding and word-recognition profile described here.

questions.source_summary: A child with dyslexia whose reading problems significantly interfere with his academic performance and have not substantially improved with appropriate intervention would receive a DSM-5 diagnosis of specific learning disorder.
questions.vignette: A 10-year-old girl has struggled with reading since first grade. Her parents report that she frequently avoids homework and becomes frustrated when asked to read aloud, and her teacher notes she is fidgety during reading tasks. A school-based evaluation confirms persistent deficits in phonological processing and word decoding despite two years of structured literacy intervention. Her cognitive ability is in the average range, her hearing is normal, and there is no history of acquired neurological injury. The evaluating psychologist is careful to note that the fidgety behavior appears to occur specifically during reading-related tasks and has not been reported in other settings.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis most accurately captures this child's primary presentation?

options.A: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, combined presentation
options.B: Specific Learning Disorder, with impairment in reading
options.C: Adjustment Disorder with disturbance of conduct
options.D: Intellectual Disability (Intellectual Developmental Disorder)

option_explanations.A: ADHD combined presentation requires hyperactive-impulsive and inattentive symptoms that are pervasive across multiple settings and contexts. The fidgety behavior described here is situationally confined to reading tasks, making this a red herring rather than a reliable indicator of ADHD.
option_explanations.B: Specific Learning Disorder with impairment in reading is correct. The child shows persistent deficits in phonological processing and word decoding that have failed to respond to structured intervention, the hallmark criteria for this diagnosis. The task-specific behavioral frustration is consistent with secondary emotional response to the learning difficulty.
option_explanations.C: Adjustment Disorder with disturbance of conduct is characterized by emotional or behavioral responses to an identifiable stressor, emerging within three months of onset, and is not appropriate when a neurodevelopmental condition better explains the presentation. The long-standing, neurobiologically based reading deficit is not consistent with adjustment disorder.
option_explanations.D: Intellectual Disability requires deficits in both general intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior across multiple domains. This child's average cognitive ability and circumscribed reading difficulties do not meet that profile.

questions.source_summary: A child with dyslexia whose reading problems significantly interfere with his academic performance and have not substantially improved with appropriate intervention would receive a DSM-5 diagnosis of specific learning disorder.
questions.vignette: An 11-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric neuropsychologist after years of poor performance in school, particularly in subjects requiring written material. His parents mention that he was late to speak his first words and that he occasionally mixes up words in conversation, leading the referral source to wonder whether a language-based condition is driving his academic struggles. Standardized testing reveals that his verbal comprehension and oral vocabulary are solidly average, but his word decoding skills fall in the bottom fifth percentile. He has received two years of structured reading support without meaningful gains, and his difficulties are confined to processing written text rather than spoken language.
questions.question: What DSM-5 diagnosis most accurately describes this child's condition?

options.A: Language Disorder
options.B: Speech Sound Disorder
options.C: Specific Learning Disorder, with impairment in reading
options.D: Intellectual Disability (Intellectual Developmental Disorder)

option_explanations.A: Language Disorder is characterized by persistent difficulties in the acquisition and use of language across multiple modalities, including reduced vocabulary, limited sentence structure, and impaired discourse. This child's average verbal comprehension and oral vocabulary argue against a Language Disorder as the primary diagnosis, even though his early speech history is a red herring.
option_explanations.B: Speech Sound Disorder involves difficulties in speech production, including articulation and phonological errors in spoken output. While the mention of occasional word mix-ups in conversation may suggest this, the core deficit here is written word decoding, not spoken sound production, ruling out Speech Sound Disorder.
option_explanations.C: Specific Learning Disorder with impairment in reading is correct. The child demonstrates severely impaired word decoding confined to written text, average oral language functioning, and failure to respond to structured literacy intervention — the defining constellation for this DSM-5 diagnosis.
option_explanations.D: Intellectual Disability would require deficits across intellectual domains and adaptive functioning, not a selective deficit in written word decoding alongside average verbal comprehension. The neuropsychological profile described is inconsistent with global intellectual impairment.

questions.source_summary: A child with dyslexia whose reading problems significantly interfere with his academic performance and have not substantially improved with appropriate intervention would receive a DSM-5 diagnosis of specific learning disorder.
questions.vignette: A 12-year-old boy is referred to a child psychologist after his parents express concern that he is 'not trying hard enough' in school. He earns passing grades through diligent effort and with significant parental support at home but continues to struggle to read assigned texts independently. Neuropsychological testing reveals a significant weakness in phonological processing relative to his otherwise average cognitive profile. His teachers report that he frequently guesses at unfamiliar words rather than sounding them out, and he has used private tutoring services for three consecutive years without meaningful improvement in his reading independence. His parents note that he has always been well-behaved, socially engaged, and emotionally regulated, and his pediatrician has suggested that he may simply be a 'slow reader' who will catch up with maturation.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis best accounts for this child's clinical presentation?

options.A: Borderline Intellectual Functioning
options.B: Specific Learning Disorder, with impairment in reading
options.C: Unspecified Neurodevelopmental Disorder
options.D: Academic Problem (V62.3)

option_explanations.A: Borderline Intellectual Functioning (IQ roughly 71–84) refers to a global limitation in cognitive ability across domains, not a specific profile of intact cognition with a circumscribed phonological processing weakness. This child's otherwise average cognitive profile and selective deficit do not fit this characterization.
option_explanations.B: Specific Learning Disorder with impairment in reading is correct. Despite a misleading framing of motivational insufficiency and a pediatric suggestion of developmental lag, the child shows persistent phonological processing weaknesses, failure to improve after three years of intensive tutoring, and functional impairment in reading — all of which satisfy DSM-5 diagnostic criteria. The 'catching up with maturation' framing is a clinical red herring.
option_explanations.C: Unspecified Neurodevelopmental Disorder is used when a clinician chooses not to specify the reason criteria for a neurodevelopmental disorder are not met, or when there is insufficient information. Given the comprehensive neuropsychological testing and documented history here, a specific diagnosis is supported and preferred over an unspecified category.
option_explanations.D: Academic Problem (V62.3) is a Z-code used when academic difficulties are the focus of attention but are not attributable to a mental disorder. It is not appropriate when a DSM-5 disorder, such as Specific Learning Disorder, fully explains the academic difficulties — which is the case here.

questions.source_summary: A child with dyslexia whose reading problems significantly interfere with his academic performance and have not substantially improved with appropriate intervention would receive a DSM-5 diagnosis of specific learning disorder.
questions.vignette: A 10-year-old boy is described by his parents as bright, curious, and highly verbal — he excels at storytelling and oral discussions and has a rich vocabulary when speaking. Despite these strengths, he has never been able to read independently at the level of his peers, and written homework requires hours of parental support each evening. His second-grade teacher initially attributed his struggles to immaturity, and he has since received two and a half years of one-on-one reading support with a specialist. His intellectual testing shows solidly average scores across most areas, with a notable and isolated weakness in tasks requiring him to break words into their smallest sound components. His parents are told by his pediatrician that he seems anxious about school and wonder whether worry is the root cause of his reading difficulties.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis most precisely accounts for the totality of this child's presentation?

options.A: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
options.B: Specific Learning Disorder, with impairment in reading
options.C: Language Disorder
options.D: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, predominantly inattentive presentation

option_explanations.A: Generalized Anxiety Disorder is characterized by excessive, difficult-to-control worry across multiple domains of functioning, not by a circumscribed neuropsychological deficit in sound segmentation. While school-related anxiety can be a secondary consequence of learning difficulties, it cannot produce the specific phonological segmentation weakness described, nor explain the failure to progress with sustained, targeted reading intervention.
option_explanations.B: Specific Learning Disorder with impairment in reading is the correct diagnosis. The distinguishing detail is the isolated, persistent deficit in breaking words into their smallest sound components (phoneme segmentation) alongside otherwise average cognitive functioning and failure to respond to over two years of specialist reading intervention. The child's strong oral-verbal abilities and anxiety are red herrings that distract from the underlying reading-specific neurodevelopmental pattern.
option_explanations.C: Language Disorder involves broad difficulties across multiple language modalities, including oral vocabulary, grammar, and discourse. This child's rich oral vocabulary, strong storytelling, and superior verbal expression directly contradict a Language Disorder diagnosis; his deficit is narrowly confined to the written decoding domain.
option_explanations.D: ADHD, predominantly inattentive presentation, involves pervasive difficulties sustaining attention, organizing tasks, and following through across settings — not a circumscribed phonological segmentation deficit. The child's described verbal strengths and absence of reported attentional problems in non-reading contexts do not support this diagnosis as the primary explanation.

questions.source_summary: Neurocognitive disorder with Parkinson's disease begins after a history of motor symptoms, while neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies begins with cognitive symptoms or a combination of cognitive and motor symptoms.
questions.vignette: A 72-year-old man was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease eight years ago, presenting initially with resting tremor, bradykinesia, and postural instability. Over the past two years, he has developed progressive memory impairment, executive dysfunction, and visuospatial difficulties that significantly interfere with his daily functioning. His neurologist notes that his motor symptoms clearly preceded the onset of any neurocognitive disorder by several years. A full workup confirms the presence of a major neurocognitive disorder.
questions.question: Based on the DSM-5 temporal sequencing of motor and cognitive symptom onset, which diagnosis best fits this presentation?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Parkinson's disease
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies
options.D: Major neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Alzheimer's disease–related neurocognitive disorder is characterized by a gradual decline in memory and other cognitive domains, but it is not linked to antecedent Parkinson's motor symptoms. The defining feature here — established Parkinson's disease preceding cognitive decline — is not consistent with an Alzheimer's etiology.
option_explanations.B: Correct. DSM-5 specifies that major neurocognitive disorder due to Parkinson's disease requires a well-established diagnosis of Parkinson's disease to precede the onset of cognitive decline. This patient's eight-year history of motor symptoms clearly predates his cognitive impairment, satisfying this temporal criterion.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies presents with cognitive symptoms either before or concurrent with motor symptoms — not after a prolonged period of established Parkinson's disease. Because this patient's motor symptoms preceded cognitive decline by many years, Lewy body dementia does not fit.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Vascular neurocognitive disorder is caused by cerebrovascular disease and typically follows a stepwise or fluctuating course tied to vascular events such as strokes. There is no mention of cerebrovascular pathology or vascular risk factors driving this patient's cognitive decline.

questions.source_summary: Neurocognitive disorder with Parkinson's disease begins after a history of motor symptoms, while neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies begins with cognitive symptoms or a combination of cognitive and motor symptoms.
questions.vignette: A 69-year-old retired teacher presents to a memory clinic after her family noticed she began experiencing recurring, well-formed visual hallucinations of small children in her home approximately 18 months ago. Around the same time, her family observed increasing forgetfulness and difficulty planning meals. Her primary care physician notes that she has since developed a mild shuffling gait and some rigidity, but her family insists the memory and perceptual problems came first. She has a longstanding history of well-controlled hypertension, which her neurologist considers an incidental finding.
questions.question: Which diagnosis is most consistent with the temporal relationship between this patient's cognitive and motor symptoms?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Parkinson's disease
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies
options.D: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease with psychotic features

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Major neurocognitive disorder due to Parkinson's disease requires that a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease and its motor features clearly precede the cognitive decline. In this case, cognitive and perceptual symptoms appeared before motor signs, which rules out a Parkinson's disease etiology.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Vascular neurocognitive disorder is associated with cerebrovascular disease, often presenting with focal neurological signs and a stepwise course. While this patient has hypertension, that alone does not establish a vascular etiology, and the prominent visual hallucinations and Lewy body–consistent symptom sequence are not characteristic of vascular disease.
option_explanations.C: Correct. DSM-5 criteria for major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies specify that cognitive symptoms, which may include prominent visual hallucinations and fluctuating cognition, emerge before or concurrently with parkinsonism. This patient's cognitive and perceptual difficulties preceded her motor symptoms, fitting the Lewy body profile.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Although Alzheimer's disease can occasionally present with psychotic features, well-formed recurrent visual hallucinations are not a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease. Moreover, Alzheimer's disease does not explain the subsequent development of parkinsonian motor signs, which better fits a Lewy body etiology.

questions.source_summary: Neurocognitive disorder with Parkinson's disease begins after a history of motor symptoms, while neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies begins with cognitive symptoms or a combination of cognitive and motor symptoms.
questions.vignette: A 74-year-old man is referred for neuropsychological evaluation after two years of progressive cognitive decline, including marked difficulty with attention and visuospatial tasks, as well as episodes in which family members describe him as 'not quite there.' His wife reports that about six months after these cognitive changes began, he developed a slow, shuffling walk and occasional freezing episodes. Notably, he was never formally diagnosed with any movement disorder prior to the cognitive changes, and his neurologist reports alpha-synuclein pathology on autopsy-based literature review is consistent with his imaging findings. His son mentions that the patient's father had Alzheimer's disease, raising concern about familial risk.
questions.question: Which diagnosis best accounts for the full clinical picture, including the sequence of symptom onset?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Parkinson's disease
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies
options.D: Major neurocognitive disorder due to frontotemporal lobar degeneration

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Major neurocognitive disorder due to Parkinson's disease requires that Parkinson's disease, with its characteristic motor syndrome, be well established before cognitive symptoms emerge. This patient had no prior movement disorder diagnosis, and his motor symptoms followed the cognitive changes — the reverse of what Parkinson's disease etiology demands.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Alzheimer's disease is a plausible distractor given the family history and the progressive cognitive decline, and it is a genuine consideration. However, Alzheimer's disease does not explain the subsequent development of parkinsonism or the fluctuating attention, and it lacks the alpha-synuclein pathology that characterizes the Lewy body spectrum.
option_explanations.C: Correct. DSM-5 criteria for major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies include cognitive symptoms (especially fluctuating attention and visuospatial impairment) that precede or coincide with parkinsonism, and the underlying pathology involves alpha-synuclein–positive Lewy bodies. The absence of a prior Parkinson's diagnosis and the temporal precedence of cognitive over motor symptoms confirm this diagnosis over a Parkinson's disease etiology.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Frontotemporal neurocognitive disorder is characterized primarily by prominent behavioral disinhibition, apathy, or language dysfunction, and it does not typically involve parkinsonism as a co-occurring feature in the same manner. The visuospatial difficulties and fluctuating attention in this case are more consistent with Lewy body pathology.

questions.source_summary: Neurocognitive disorder with Parkinson's disease begins after a history of motor symptoms, while neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies begins with cognitive symptoms or a combination of cognitive and motor symptoms.
questions.vignette: A 77-year-old woman is brought to a geriatric psychiatry clinic by her daughter, who reports that three years ago her mother began acting out her dreams at night — thrashing, shouting, and occasionally falling out of bed. Within one year of these nocturnal episodes, she began making frequent errors when managing her finances, losing track of conversations, and misidentifying objects. Her neurologist recently documented mild rigidity and a subtle resting tremor. Because her motor findings are currently mild, a colleague suggests that she should receive a Parkinson's disease diagnosis first, then revisit the cognitive diagnosis later. The neuropsychologist notes that her prodromal sleep disturbance preceded both the cognitive and motor changes.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most accurately reflects the DSM-5 classification of this patient's condition?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Parkinson's disease
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease
options.D: Major neurocognitive disorder due to prion disease

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. This option is tempting because the patient now has documented parkinsonism. However, DSM-5 requires that a formal diagnosis of Parkinson's disease clearly precede cognitive decline for the Parkinson's disease etiology to apply. Here, cognitive symptoms emerged before the motor signs became clinically prominent, and no prior Parkinson's diagnosis was established — making a Parkinson's disease designation inappropriate regardless of current motor findings.
option_explanations.B: Correct. DSM-5 specifies that major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies is the appropriate diagnosis when cognitive symptoms precede or co-occur with the motor features of parkinsonism, and there is no well-established prior Parkinson's disease diagnosis. REM sleep behavior disorder is recognized as a prodromal feature of the Lewy body spectrum, and its occurrence before both cognitive and motor symptoms further supports this diagnosis. The colleague's suggestion to defer the Lewy body diagnosis is inconsistent with DSM-5 criteria.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Alzheimer's disease does not account for the REM sleep behavior disorder, the subsequent development of parkinsonian motor signs, or the fluctuating cognitive pattern implied by the presentation. While memory and financial management difficulties overlap with Alzheimer's disease, the full constellation of features fits the Lewy body spectrum.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Prion disease (e.g., Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) can produce rapidly progressive dementia and occasional motor abnormalities, but it is characterized by an extremely rapid decline over weeks to months rather than the gradual three-year progression described here. The prodromal REM sleep behavior disorder and parkinsonism are not hallmarks of prion disease.

questions.source_summary: Neurocognitive disorder with Parkinson's disease begins after a history of motor symptoms, while neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies begins with cognitive symptoms or a combination of cognitive and motor symptoms.
questions.vignette: A 71-year-old retired engineer is evaluated after his wife notices that for the past year he has become increasingly forgetful, has trouble finding his way around familiar neighborhoods, and occasionally stares blankly for minutes at a time before resuming normal conversation. His wife also mentions that for the past three months he has started walking more slowly and his arms do not swing normally when he moves. A review of his medical records shows he saw a sleep specialist two years ago for episodes of vigorous movement during sleep, though no formal diagnosis was ever assigned at that time. His son, who accompanied him, emphasizes that the memory problems began well before the walking changes, and that their family's main worry is Alzheimer's disease because his maternal uncle had it.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most accurately captures the nature of this patient's condition according to established diagnostic classification?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Parkinson's disease
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies
options.D: Major neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. The family history of Alzheimer's disease and the progressive memory impairment make this a compelling distractor. However, Alzheimer's disease does not explain the subsequent emergence of parkinsonian motor features (reduced arm swing, slowed gait), the episodic blank staring suggestive of fluctuating cognition, or the prior history of abnormal movements during sleep — a recognized early marker of the Lewy body spectrum.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. The eventual appearance of motor slowness and reduced arm swing may suggest Parkinson's disease, but the critical diagnostic rule is that Parkinson's disease must be formally diagnosed and established before cognitive symptoms develop. In this case, cognitive and perceptual difficulties clearly preceded the motor changes, and no formal movement disorder diagnosis was ever made — both of which are disqualifying for the Parkinson's disease etiology.
option_explanations.C: Correct. The diagnostic classification for this condition requires cognitive symptoms to emerge before or alongside parkinsonian motor features, with no prior formal diagnosis of a movement disorder. The episodic staring (fluctuating cognition), visuospatial difficulty, cognitive onset before motor onset, and the earlier sleep study finding — consistent with a well-established early symptom of this pathological spectrum — collectively distinguish this diagnosis from Alzheimer's disease and the Parkinson's disease etiology.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Vascular neurocognitive disorder typically follows cerebrovascular events and presents with focal neurological deficits or a stepwise course of decline. There is no mention of stroke, transient ischemic attack, or other vascular events in this patient's history, and the combination of fluctuating cognition, subsequent parkinsonism, and prior sleep disturbance is not characteristic of a vascular etiology.

questions.source_summary: According to L. Y. Abramson, G. I. Metalsky, and L. B. Alloy, the tendency to attribute negative life events to stable and global factors produces hopelessness, which then leads to a specific type of depression referred to as "hopelessness depression".
questions.vignette: A researcher is presenting a cognitive model of depression to a graduate seminar. She explains that when individuals experience negative life events and attribute them to causes that are stable (i.e., unlikely to change) and global (i.e., affecting many areas of life), they develop a pervasive sense of hopelessness. According to this model, this hopelessness is not merely a symptom but the proximal cause of a distinct depressive subtype. The researcher credits Abramson, Metalsky, and Alloy as the originators of this framework, distinguishing it from earlier learned helplessness models.
questions.question: The researcher is describing which theoretical model of depression?

options.A: Hopelessness theory of depression
options.B: Learned helplessness theory of depression
options.C: Beck's cognitive triad model of depression
options.D: Behavioral activation model of depression

option_explanations.A: This is correct. Abramson, Metalsky, and Alloy's hopelessness theory specifically posits that attributing negative events to stable and global causes generates hopelessness, which is the direct cause of 'hopelessness depression' — a specific depressive subtype.
option_explanations.B: Learned helplessness theory, developed by Seligman, holds that uncontrollable negative events lead to passive resignation and depression. While it is a predecessor to hopelessness theory and shares the concept of attributional style, it does not specifically designate hopelessness as the proximal cause of a distinct depressive subtype.
option_explanations.C: Beck's cognitive triad model describes negative views of the self, world, and future as the cognitive core of depression. Although hopelessness about the future is implicated, Beck's model does not center on stable and global attributions generating hopelessness as the proximal causal mechanism for a specific subtype.
option_explanations.D: The behavioral activation model focuses on increasing engagement with rewarding activities to reduce depression, drawing from Lewinsohn's work on response-contingent positive reinforcement. It is primarily behavioral rather than cognitive-attributional and does not address stable/global attributions or hopelessness as a causal mechanism.

questions.source_summary: According to L. Y. Abramson, G. I. Metalsky, and L. B. Alloy, the tendency to attribute negative life events to stable and global factors produces hopelessness, which then leads to a specific type of depression referred to as "hopelessness depression".
questions.vignette: A 34-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic following the loss of his job. He reports feeling certain that he will never find stable employment again because he believes he is 'fundamentally incompetent as a person,' a flaw he sees as affecting every domain of his life. He has developed passive suicidal ideation, significant fatigue, and a belief that nothing he does will improve his situation. His clinician notes that the patient's attributions about the job loss appear to be driving his current affective state, and the patient also mentions a history of moderate alcohol use, though he denies current use.
questions.question: Based on Abramson, Metalsky, and Alloy's theoretical framework, which concept best explains the mechanism by which this patient's job loss led to his depressive symptoms?

options.A: Negative automatic thoughts activating the cognitive triad
options.B: Stable and global attributions generating hopelessness
options.C: Learned helplessness resulting from uncontrollable negative events
options.D: Ruminative response style amplifying depressive affect

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The patient attributes his job loss to being 'fundamentally incompetent as a person' — an internal, stable, and global attribution — which Abramson et al.'s hopelessness theory identifies as the cognitive pathway through which hopelessness (and ultimately hopelessness depression) develops.
option_explanations.A: Beck's negative automatic thoughts and cognitive triad involve distorted thinking about self, world, and future, which superficially resembles this case. However, Beck's model does not specifically emphasize stable and global attributional style as the mechanism generating hopelessness, nor does it propose a distinct 'hopelessness depression' subtype.
option_explanations.C: Seligman's learned helplessness theory also involves perceptions of uncontrollability, and the patient does express futility. However, learned helplessness theory does not specifically identify stable and global attributions as the key mediating variable producing a discrete depressive subtype; hopelessness theory was developed partly to correct this gap.
option_explanations.D: Nolen-Hoeksema's ruminative response style theory suggests that repetitive focus on distress amplifies and prolongs depression. Although rumination could co-occur here, it is not the mechanism described by Abramson et al. and does not involve stable/global attributional style as the proximal cause of hopelessness depression.

questions.source_summary: According to L. Y. Abramson, G. I. Metalsky, and L. B. Alloy, the tendency to attribute negative life events to stable and global factors produces hopelessness, which then leads to a specific type of depression referred to as "hopelessness depression".
questions.vignette: A 28-year-old graduate student sought therapy after failing her qualifying examination. She reports that she 'has always been this way' — someone who cannot handle intellectual challenges — and that this failure confirms she will never succeed in any professional or academic domain. Her therapist notes that she does not exhibit elevated anxiety, racing thoughts, or periods of elevated mood, but instead presents with psychomotor retardation, passive suicidal ideation, and a profound conviction that her future is sealed regardless of any action she takes. Notably, she has an extensive history of high academic achievement and her academic advisor has offered her a second attempt at the examination.
questions.question: The therapist conceptualizes this patient's depression as arising from a specific cognitive-attributional mechanism. Which theoretical framework most precisely accounts for this presentation?

options.A: Beck's cognitive model, in which the negative cognitive triad maintains depressive affect through schema-driven distortions
options.B: Abramson, Metalsky, and Alloy's hopelessness theory, in which stable and global attributions function as a proximal cause of a distinct depressive subtype
options.C: Seligman's reformulated learned helplessness theory, in which perceived lack of control over outcomes generates depressive passivity
options.D: Nolen-Hoeksema's response styles theory, in which ruminative coping amplifies and maintains negative affect following setbacks

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The patient attributes her failure to a stable ('always been this way') and global ('any professional or academic domain') characteristic, and the resulting belief that her future is sealed regardless of her actions reflects the hopelessness that Abramson et al. identify as the proximal cause of hopelessness depression — a discrete subtype characterized by passive suicidality and psychomotor retardation.
option_explanations.A: Beck's cognitive model would emphasize negative automatic thoughts and schema-driven distortions across self, world, and future, which partially overlaps with this case. However, Beck's model does not specifically name stable/global attributional style as the mechanism, nor does it predict a distinct subtype called 'hopelessness depression'; it is a more general model of depression.
option_explanations.C: Seligman's reformulated learned helplessness model does involve attributional style and the perception that outcomes are uncontrollable, and the patient's resignation could suggest this. However, the reformulated model does not posit hopelessness as a proximal, independent causal construct producing a defined depressive subtype — that refinement is the specific contribution of Abramson et al.'s hopelessness theory.
option_explanations.D: Nolen-Hoeksema's response styles theory proposes that ruminative focus on symptoms and their causes worsens and prolongs depression. While the student is dwelling on her failure, the vignette's central mechanism is attributional (stable, global causal beliefs), not response style. This theory does not account for the specific hopelessness mechanism described.

questions.source_summary: According to L. Y. Abramson, G. I. Metalsky, and L. B. Alloy, the tendency to attribute negative life events to stable and global factors produces hopelessness, which then leads to a specific type of depression referred to as "hopelessness depression".
questions.vignette: A cognitive psychologist is reviewing therapy notes from a patient who recently ended a long-term relationship. The patient repeatedly states that 'people like me are just unlovable — it never works out and it never will,' extending this belief to friendships, professional relationships, and his sense of self-worth. His presenting symptoms include markedly diminished interest in activities, significant fatigue, and psychomotor retardation, but he denies anhedonia when asked about specific enjoyable activities, reporting only that 'there's no point in doing them.' His therapist observes that the patient's pervasive sense of futility about all relationships and the future preceded the onset of his other symptoms and appears to be organizing his entire clinical picture.
questions.question: Which theoretical account most precisely explains the mechanism by which this patient's cognitive response to the relationship loss produced his current depressive symptoms?

options.A: Beck's schema activation model, in which a negative self-schema triggered by the relationship loss drives systematic cognitive distortions
options.B: Seligman's reformulated learned helplessness model, in which internal, stable, and global attributions for the relationship loss produce depression
options.C: Abramson, Metalsky, and Alloy's hopelessness theory, in which attributing the negative event to stable and global causes generates hopelessness as the proximal sufficient cause of depression
options.D: Nolen-Hoeksema's response styles theory, in which a ruminative response style to the relationship loss amplifies and maintains depressive symptoms

option_explanations.C: This is correct. The patient attributes the relationship loss to a stable ('never will') and global ('unlovable' across all relationships and domains of life) factor. The therapist's observation that the futility — i.e., hopelessness — preceded and organized the other symptoms precisely mirrors Abramson et al.'s claim that hopelessness is the proximal sufficient cause of hopelessness depression, not merely a co-occurring symptom.
option_explanations.A: Beck's schema activation model is highly plausible here: the patient's belief that he is 'unlovable' resembles a core negative self-schema. However, Beck's model treats schema-driven distortions as maintaining depression across domains, rather than designating hopelessness as a temporally proximal, independent causal variable that precedes and generates the full symptom picture — the specific mechanistic claim of hopelessness theory.
option_explanations.B: Seligman's reformulated learned helplessness model is very similar to hopelessness theory and would predict that internal, stable, and global attributions produce depression — and the patient does make such attributions. The critical distinction is that Seligman's model does not isolate hopelessness as a discrete, proximal sufficient cause; Abramson et al. refined the model specifically to give hopelessness this mechanistic status and to define a unique depressive subtype.
option_explanations.D: Nolen-Hoeksema's response styles theory focuses on ruminative coping — repeatedly focusing on symptoms and their causes — as an amplifier of depression. The vignette's patient does appear to dwell on his situation, but the organizing feature is the stable/global attributional content and its temporal priority over other symptoms, not the style of cognitive response. Rumination theory does not specify stable/global attributions as the mechanism.

questions.source_summary: According to L. Y. Abramson, G. I. Metalsky, and L. B. Alloy, the tendency to attribute negative life events to stable and global factors produces hopelessness, which then leads to a specific type of depression referred to as "hopelessness depression".
questions.vignette: A 41-year-old accountant enters therapy six weeks after losing a major client account. He reports that he has not been sleeping well, has lost interest in cooking — a lifelong passion — and rarely leaves his apartment. He tells his therapist, 'I made a mistake in the presentation, and honestly, I've never been sharp enough for this kind of work. Losing clients is just what happens to someone with my limitations, across every part of my career.' When the therapist probes whether things might improve, the patient replies flatly, 'There's nothing to do. That's just the way things are going to be.' His therapist notes that the patient's wife left him two years prior, that he has struggled with moderate social anxiety since adolescence, and that his sense of permanent inadequacy across professional and personal life appears to have crystallized immediately after the client loss and now precedes any discussion of mood.
questions.question: Which theoretical model most precisely identifies the mechanism linking this patient's response to the client loss with the onset of his depressive symptoms?

options.A: Beck's cognitive model, in which a loss event reactivates a pre-existing negative self-schema that then drives and maintains depressive cognition across domains
options.B: Abramson, Metalsky, and Alloy's hopelessness theory, in which attributing a negative event to stable and global causes generates hopelessness as the direct cause of a distinct depressive syndrome
options.C: Seligman's reformulated learned helplessness model, in which the perception that outcomes are uncontrollable regardless of effort leads to motivational and cognitive deficits characteristic of depression
options.D: Nolen-Hoeksema's response styles theory, in which a ruminative coping pattern following the stressor amplifies negative affect and prolongs the depressive episode

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The patient attributes the client loss to a cause he characterizes as stable ('never been sharp enough,' 'that's just the way things are going to be') and global ('across every part of my career'), and this crystallized sense of permanent, pervasive inadequacy — which preceded rather than followed his mood decline — maps precisely onto Abramson et al.'s hopelessness theory, in which such attributions generate hopelessness as the proximal cause of hopelessness depression.
option_explanations.A: Beck's schema activation model is a strong competitor here: the patient's long-standing self-perception of inadequacy and the triggering role of the career loss closely resemble schema reactivation. However, Beck's model treats depressive cognition as maintaining depression rather than assigning hopelessness the role of a discrete, causally prior mechanism; the vignette specifically notes that the sense of permanence and futility preceded mood symptoms, which is the hallmark of hopelessness theory's mechanistic claim.
option_explanations.C: Seligman's reformulated learned helplessness model is easily confused with hopelessness theory because both involve attributional style. The patient's statement that 'there's nothing to do' could suggest perceived uncontrollability. However, Seligman's model does not separate hopelessness as a distinct mediating variable that is the proximal sufficient cause of a specific depressive subtype; that separation is precisely what distinguishes Abramson et al.'s contribution, and it is the most mechanistically precise fit for the observed temporal sequence.
option_explanations.D: Nolen-Hoeksema's response styles theory could be invoked because the patient is clearly dwelling on the loss — he repeatedly returns to his inadequacy. The history of social anxiety and the wife's departure could be interpreted as rumination-amplifying stressors. However, the theory centers on the style of cognitive engagement (repetitive, passive focus on symptoms), not on the content of stable/global causal attributions, and it does not account for why hopelessness appeared before the mood episode rather than as a consequence of rumination.

questions.subdomain: Trauma/Stressor-Related, Dissociative, and Somatic Symptom Disorders
questions.vignette: Lisa, a 24-year-old graduate student, presents with an intense preoccupation with what she believes is a grossly asymmetrical nose. Objective examination and photographs confirm that her nose falls well within normal variation and that any asymmetry is barely perceptible. She engages in repetitive behaviors such as mirror checking and camouflaging with makeup for several hours each day. Her preoccupation with this perceived flaw has caused her to withdraw from social activities and miss academic deadlines. She reports significant distress and states that she cannot stop thinking about her appearance.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis BEST accounts for Lisa's clinical presentation?

options.A: Illness anxiety disorder
options.B: Body dysmorphic disorder
options.C: Obsessive-compulsive disorder
options.D: Social anxiety disorder

option_explanations.A: Illness anxiety disorder involves preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious illness, not with a perceived defect in physical appearance. Lisa's concern is specifically about a cosmetic feature of her nose, not a belief that she is medically ill.
option_explanations.B: Body dysmorphic disorder requires preoccupation with one or more perceived flaws in physical appearance that are minor or not apparent to others, accompanied by repetitive behaviors (e.g., mirror checking, camouflaging) and significant distress or functional impairment — all of which are present here.
option_explanations.C: Obsessive-compulsive disorder involves recurrent obsessions and compulsions that are not limited to appearance-related concerns. While BDD and OCD share overlapping features and are classified in the same DSM-5 chapter, BDD is the more specific diagnosis when the preoccupation is exclusively focused on a perceived physical flaw.
option_explanations.D: Social anxiety disorder involves fear of negative evaluation in social situations, and while Lisa avoids social activities, her avoidance stems from shame about a specific perceived physical defect rather than a broad fear of scrutiny or embarrassment in performance or social situations.

questions.source_summary: The DSM-5 diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder requires preoccupation with one or more perceived flaws in physical appearance that appear to be minor or are not apparent to others, accompanied by repetitive behaviors and significant distress or impaired functioning, which Lisa's symptoms meet.
questions.subdomain: Trauma/Stressor-Related, Dissociative, and Somatic Symptom Disorders
questions.vignette: Marcus, a 30-year-old accountant, was referred by his dermatologist after repeatedly requesting skin-resurfacing procedures for scarring on his cheek that the dermatologist rates as minimal and nearly invisible. Marcus spends roughly three hours daily examining his reflection and picking at his skin, behaviors he finds distressing but difficult to stop. He recently began working from home exclusively because he fears colleagues will stare at his face. Although Marcus has a history of mild depression treated successfully with antidepressants two years ago, he reports that his concerns about his skin are entirely separate from his mood and have persisted independent of depressive episodes.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis MOST accurately captures Marcus's primary presenting problem?

options.A: Body dysmorphic disorder
options.B: Excoriation (skin-picking) disorder
options.C: Obsessive-compulsive disorder
options.D: Major depressive disorder with somatic features

option_explanations.A: Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by preoccupation with a perceived physical flaw that is minor or not apparent to others, along with repetitive behaviors (here, mirror checking and skin picking) driven by appearance-related concerns, and significant functional impairment. All core criteria are met, and the history of resolved depression does not account for the current presentation.
option_explanations.B: Excoriation disorder involves recurrent skin picking that causes lesions and is not primarily motivated by appearance-related preoccupation. Marcus's skin picking is driven by his belief that his skin is defective in appearance, making BDD the more encompassing and accurate diagnosis; DSM-5 notes that skin picking in the context of BDD is better captured under BDD.
option_explanations.C: Obsessive-compulsive disorder features obsessions and compulsions that are not restricted to concerns about physical appearance. While Marcus's mirror checking and skin picking resemble compulsions, when such behaviors occur exclusively in the context of appearance-focused preoccupation, BDD is the appropriate diagnosis rather than OCD.
option_explanations.D: Major depressive disorder with somatic features involves prominent physical complaints (e.g., fatigue, pain, changes in appetite) arising in the context of a depressive episode. Marcus's concern is specifically cosmetic, persists independently of mood episodes, and is not a somatic symptom of depression.

questions.source_summary: The DSM-5 diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder requires preoccupation with one or more perceived flaws in physical appearance that appear to be minor or are not apparent to others, accompanied by repetitive behaviors and significant distress or impaired functioning, which Lisa's symptoms meet.

questions.vignette: Danielle, a 27-year-old woman, seeks therapy after her boyfriend expressed concern about how much time she spends getting ready each morning. She insists her hair is thinning dramatically and shows her boyfriend dozens of photographs she has taken of her scalp under bright light to document the progression. Her dermatologist examined her scalp twice and found hair density entirely within normal limits. Danielle acknowledges that others do not see the problem but maintains that they simply are not looking closely enough. She has stopped swimming and attending social gatherings because she fears people will notice her hair, and she frequently wears hats even indoors, behavior that has begun to strain her relationship and her performance at work.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis BEST explains Danielle's presentation?

options.A: Delusional disorder, somatic type
options.B: Body dysmorphic disorder
options.C: Generalized anxiety disorder
options.D: Illness anxiety disorder

option_explanations.A: Delusional disorder, somatic type, involves fixed false beliefs about bodily function or appearance held with delusional certainty, typically with no insight. Danielle acknowledges that others do not perceive the problem, preserving a degree of insight that is more consistent with BDD; DSM-5 notes that BDD with absent insight is specified separately but is still diagnosed as BDD, not as a separate delusional disorder.
option_explanations.B: Body dysmorphic disorder requires preoccupation with a perceived physical flaw not apparent to others, accompanied by repetitive behaviors (photographing her scalp, wearing hats to camouflage) and significant distress or functional impairment. Danielle meets all of these criteria, and her partial insight — acknowledging others do not see the problem while still insisting it is real — is consistent with the BDD specifier for poor insight.
option_explanations.C: Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive, difficult-to-control worry across multiple life domains rather than preoccupation focused on a specific perceived physical defect. Danielle's anxiety is narrowly and specifically tied to one aspect of her appearance, which does not fit the broad, free-floating worry pattern characteristic of GAD.
option_explanations.D: Illness anxiety disorder centers on fear of having or developing a serious medical disease, not on a cosmetic or aesthetic defect in appearance. Danielle is not worried that her hair loss signals systemic illness; she is distressed purely by the perceived aesthetic imperfection, placing her presentation within BDD rather than illness anxiety disorder.
