questions.vignette: A 32-year-old male software engineer is referred to a psychologist by his psychiatrist, who notes that the patient has recently demanded a referral for rhinoplasty after two surgeons declined to operate, citing no objective abnormality. During the intake interview the patient describes spending approximately four hours each day reviewing forum posts by people who have had nasal surgery, measuring his nose with calipers, and photographing himself from multiple angles, activities he states he cannot stop despite recognizing they worsen his distress. He reports that his insight fluctuates — some days he wonders if others might be right, but on most days he is convinced his nasal bridge is malformed. He has not left his apartment in three weeks, has stopped video calls with family, and reports that his only significant prior psychiatric history is a single major depressive episode that resolved four years ago.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis MOST accurately accounts for the full clinical picture?

options.A: Obsessive-compulsive disorder with poor insight
options.B: Delusional disorder, somatic type
options.C: Body dysmorphic disorder with poor insight/delusional beliefs specifier
options.D: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

option_explanations.C: Body dysmorphic disorder with the poor insight/delusional beliefs specifier is the correct diagnosis. The patient's preoccupation is exclusively with a perceived physical flaw in appearance, accompanied by characteristic repetitive behaviors (measuring, photographing, forum checking), significant functional impairment, and fluctuating but predominantly poor insight. DSM-5 provides this specifier precisely for presentations in which the BDD belief is held with delusional intensity, distinguishing it from delusional disorder.
option_explanations.A: Obsessive-compulsive disorder with poor insight involves recurrent obsessions and compulsions not restricted to appearance concerns. While the patient's behaviors resemble compulsions, DSM-5 specifies that when obsessions and compulsions are exclusively focused on perceived appearance defects, BDD supersedes OCD as the diagnosis. The poor insight specifier exists within BDD, not within OCD, for this type of presentation.
option_explanations.B: Delusional disorder, somatic type, would apply only if the appearance-related belief were the sole psychopathology and were always held with complete delusional certainty and no insight. The patient demonstrates fluctuating insight (some days he wonders if others are right), characteristic repetitive BDD behaviors, and marked functional impairment beyond a circumscribed delusion, all of which align more precisely with BDD than with delusional disorder.
option_explanations.D: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features involves mood-congruent or mood-incongruent psychotic symptoms (hallucinations or delusions) arising within a major depressive episode. The patient's prior depressive episode resolved four years ago, his current presentation is not mood-episode-driven, and his preoccupation with appearance is not a feature of psychotic depression, making this diagnosis inconsistent with the clinical picture.

questions.source_summary: The DSM-5 diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder requires preoccupation with one or more perceived flaws in physical appearance that appear to be minor or are not apparent to others, accompanied by repetitive behaviors and significant distress or impaired functioning, which Lisa's symptoms meet.
questions.subdomain: Trauma/Stressor-Related, Dissociative, and Somatic Symptom Disorders
questions.vignette: A 29-year-old woman is brought to an outpatient clinic by her mother, who reports that her daughter has not left the house in six weeks. The patient is initially reluctant to speak but eventually confides that she has been spending five or more hours each day photographing the left side of her jaw under different lighting conditions and comparing the images side by side. She has consulted three oral surgeons who all told her there was nothing to correct; she found each consultation frustrating and is saving money to seek a fourth opinion abroad. When asked what worries her most, she says quietly, 'Nobody believes me, but I can see it — and it controls my whole life.' She denies any recent loss, any periods of elevated mood, any belief that the asymmetry is caused by an internal disease, and any experience of hearing voices or seeing things that others cannot see.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis MOST accurately captures this patient's primary condition?

options.A: Obsessive-compulsive disorder
options.B: Illness anxiety disorder
options.C: Body dysmorphic disorder
options.D: Delusional disorder, somatic type

option_explanations.A: Obsessive-compulsive disorder involves intrusive obsessions and neutralizing compulsions that span multiple content domains or are not exclusively tied to a specific physical feature. The patient's entire symptom picture — repetitive checking, reassurance seeking through repeated consultations, and functional impairment — is organized exclusively around the appearance of one facial feature, which DSM-5 classifies under BDD rather than OCD even when the behaviors are compulsive in character.
option_explanations.B: Illness anxiety disorder centers on preoccupation with the fear of having or developing a serious illness based on physical sensations or minor bodily signs. This patient explicitly seeks cosmetic correction rather than medical diagnosis of a disease, and her distress is purely about aesthetic appearance; she does not fear that her jaw asymmetry signals systemic pathology, ruling out illness anxiety disorder.
option_explanations.C: Body dysmorphic disorder is the correct diagnosis. The patient is preoccupied with a perceived cosmetic flaw in her jaw that multiple specialists confirm is not objectively significant, she engages in extensive repetitive checking (photography and comparison) and reassurance-seeking (multiple surgical consultations), she has severe functional impairment (housebound for six weeks), and she denies symptoms of mood episodes, psychosis, or illness-focused anxiety. Taken together, this pattern precisely meets DSM-5 BDD criteria.
option_explanations.D: Delusional disorder, somatic type, would require the belief to be held with complete and unshakeable certainty, typically without the elaborate behavioral rituals seen here, and the belief would constitute the entirety of the psychopathology without the broader functional collapse described. The patient's statement that the asymmetry 'controls my whole life' and the extensive ritualistic checking suggest a behavioral and distress profile broader than a circumscribed somatic delusion, and DSM-5 instructs clinicians to diagnose BDD (with a poor insight specifier if needed) rather than delusional disorder when the preoccupation is appearance-focused and accompanied by BDD-characteristic behaviors.

questions.source_summary: The course of vascular neurocognitive disorder depends on the nature and severity of the cerebrovascular disease, the areas of the brain that are affected, and other factors, and it may involve an acute onset of symptoms or a stepwise or fluctuating decline in functioning.
questions.vignette: A 74-year-old man with a long history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to a neuropsychologist after his family noticed that his memory and executive functioning seemed to worsen in distinct episodes. Neuroimaging reveals multiple small infarcts consistent with cerebrovascular disease. His family describes a stepwise decline in his functioning, with periods of relative stability followed by sudden drops after each apparent ischemic event. His physician notes that the affected brain regions correspond closely to the cognitive deficits observed on testing.
questions.question: Which neurocognitive disorder best accounts for this patient's presentation, including its characteristic course?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Lewy body disease
options.D: Major neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury

option_explanations.A: Alzheimer's disease typically presents with an insidious onset and gradual, continuous decline — not the stepwise deterioration tied to discrete ischemic events that is described here. It is also not primarily associated with cerebrovascular pathology on imaging.
option_explanations.B: Vascular neurocognitive disorder is characterized by cognitive decline linked directly to cerebrovascular disease, and its course often involves acute onset after strokes or a stepwise pattern of deterioration following successive ischemic events, precisely as described in this vignette.
option_explanations.C: Lewy body neurocognitive disorder is associated with fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, and REM sleep behavior disorder — not a pattern of stepwise decline tied to identifiable cerebrovascular events or infarcts on neuroimaging.
option_explanations.D: Neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury results from head trauma rather than cerebrovascular disease. While it can have an acute onset, the patient's history of hypertension, diabetes, and multiple infarcts points away from a traumatic etiology.

questions.vignette: A 68-year-old retired schoolteacher is referred for neuropsychological evaluation after her husband reports that her ability to manage finances and remember appointments has worsened noticeably over the past two years. Interestingly, she also experiences periods of relative clarity between episodes of confusion, and her husband reports that each downturn seemed to follow what he described as 'small strokes.' She has a history of atrial fibrillation and hypercholesterolemia, and MRI confirms multiple lacunar infarcts in regions associated with executive function. She denies vivid visual experiences or problems with movement, and her sleep history is unremarkable.
questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, and what feature of her course is most diagnostically significant?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Lewy body disease with fluctuating cognition
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease with amnestic predominance
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease with a stepwise or fluctuating course tied to cerebrovascular events
options.D: Major neurocognitive disorder due to frontotemporal lobar degeneration with executive dysfunction

option_explanations.A: Lewy body neurocognitive disorder also features fluctuating cognition, which makes it a plausible distractor. However, this diagnosis requires core features such as recurrent visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, or REM sleep behavior disorder — none of which are present here. The fluctuation in this case is directly tied to identifiable cerebrovascular events.
option_explanations.B: Alzheimer's disease commonly presents with memory impairment and executive dysfunction, but its course is typically insidious and continuously progressive rather than fluctuating or stepwise. The neuroimaging findings of multiple lacunar infarcts and the association with atrial fibrillation point specifically to a vascular etiology.
option_explanations.C: Vascular neurocognitive disorder is directly supported by the confirmed lacunar infarcts, the cardiovascular risk factors, and the fluctuating or stepwise course tied to apparent ischemic events. DSM-5 identifies this pattern as a hallmark of vascular neurocognitive disorder, distinguishing it from other neurodegenerative causes.
option_explanations.D: Frontotemporal neurocognitive disorder can present with executive dysfunction, but it primarily involves behavioral disinhibition or language deterioration and is not characterized by infarct-associated stepwise decline or by the cardiovascular risk profile described here.

questions.vignette: A 71-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension is brought to a psychologist by his daughter, who reports that he has seemed 'like a different person' since a hospitalization three months ago. Before that hospitalization, he was fully independent; afterward, he struggled significantly with attention, planning, and word retrieval. She adds that he seemed to improve slightly over the following weeks but then experienced another sudden drop in functioning after a second brief hospitalization last month. His mood is notably flat and he appears apathetic, which his daughter attributes to depression following retirement. Cerebrovascular disease is confirmed on imaging, though the exact extent is still being evaluated.
questions.question: Which diagnosis best explains this patient's presentation, and what feature most clearly distinguishes it from a primary mood disorder?

options.A: Major depressive disorder with cognitive symptoms secondary to psychomotor slowing
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease with acute onset and stepwise decline
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease with comorbid depression
options.D: Mild neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease with stable course

option_explanations.A: Major depression can cause significant cognitive difficulties ('pseudodementia'), and the flat affect and apathy described here are plausible depressive features — making this a genuine red herring. However, the acute onset tied to a hospitalization, the confirmed cerebrovascular pathology on imaging, and the second discrete drop in functioning cannot be explained by depression alone.
option_explanations.B: Vascular neurocognitive disorder can present with acute onset following a cerebrovascular event and may follow a stepwise decline as successive events occur. The patient's abrupt functional deterioration after two separate hospitalizations, confirmed cerebrovascular disease on imaging, and relative stability between events all fit this pattern precisely.
option_explanations.C: Alzheimer's disease can co-occur with depression and can present with cognitive decline, but its course is characteristically gradual and insidious rather than acute or stepwise. The discrete hospitalization-linked drops and confirmed vascular pathology are not consistent with a primary Alzheimer's diagnosis.
option_explanations.D: Mild neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease would not adequately account for the severity described — the patient moved from fully independent to significantly impaired after each event. Additionally, the stepwise pattern across two episodes supports a major rather than mild classification.

questions.vignette: A 77-year-old woman is evaluated by a neuropsychologist after her primary care physician expressed concern about cognitive changes over the past 18 months. Her daughter describes her mother as having good days and bad days, but concedes that overall she is clearly less capable than before. The patient herself minimizes any difficulties and attributes her forgetfulness to normal aging. Neuroimaging shows white matter changes and evidence of prior ischemic events in areas associated with processing speed and attention. During the interview, she demonstrates mild word-finding difficulties but performs within normal limits on delayed recall tasks. Her primary care physician had suspected early Alzheimer's disease, and the patient's daughter mentions that her mother has been sleeping poorly and seems more irritable than before.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most accurately characterizes this patient's condition, and what feature of the clinical course is most critical to the diagnosis?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease in the amnestic presentation
options.B: Mild neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease with insidious progression
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease with a fluctuating course
options.D: Mild neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease with a stepwise or fluctuating course tied to cerebrovascular events

option_explanations.A: Alzheimer's disease in the amnestic presentation typically involves prominent impairment in delayed recall — a feature that is specifically absent here, as the patient performs normally on delayed recall tasks. The physician's initial suspicion of Alzheimer's and the minimization of symptoms are red herrings designed to pull toward this option.
option_explanations.B: Mild neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's would involve a gradually insidious course primarily affecting episodic memory. While the patient's self-minimization and the physician's prior suspicion support this read, the preserved delayed recall and the neuroimaging evidence of prior ischemic events specifically contraindicate a primary Alzheimer's etiology.
option_explanations.C: A major neurocognitive disorder diagnosis requires that the cognitive deficits substantially interfere with everyday independence. While the patient is clearly less capable, the description of word-finding difficulty with preserved recall, combined with the 'good days and bad days' pattern, does not definitively establish major-level impairment, making the mild classification more accurate.
option_explanations.D: The neuroimaging evidence of prior ischemic events, the domain-specific deficits (processing speed and attention rather than memory), the fluctuating day-to-day course, and the overall functional decline that does not yet reach the threshold for major impairment all converge on mild neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease. The fluctuating pattern linked to cerebrovascular pathology is the key distinguishing feature of the vascular subtype.

questions.vignette: A 79-year-old man is brought in by his son, who reports that his father 'keeps going up and down.' The son describes a period three years ago when his father had what seemed like a bad flu and afterward never quite returned to his prior level of sharpness. He managed reasonably well for about a year, but then following a brief hospitalization for a cardiac procedure, he again lost noticeable ground. Between these events, he has had stretches of relative stability. He sometimes confuses names but can still recall important personal events from decades past without much difficulty. He denies any unusual visual experiences or problems walking. His sleep has been restless, but his son attributes this to anxiety about his health, and the patient's mood appears somewhat low but not severely depressed.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most precisely accounts for this patient's overall presentation and the distinctive pattern of his functional decline over time?

options.A: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Lewy body disease with fluctuating cognition
options.B: Major neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease with late-onset depression
options.C: Major neurocognitive disorder due to vascular disease with stepwise decline following discrete events
options.D: Major neurocognitive disorder due to another medical condition with a variable course

option_explanations.A: Lewy body neurocognitive disorder is a strong distractor here because it is explicitly characterized by fluctuating cognition, and the restless sleep could suggest REM sleep behavior disorder. However, Lewy body disease requires core features such as recurrent visual hallucinations or parkinsonism, neither of which is present. Critically, the fluctuation in this case is tied to discrete medical events rather than being spontaneous and unpredictable as in Lewy body disease.
option_explanations.B: Alzheimer's disease with depression is plausible given the low mood, the word-finding difficulty, and the gradual overall worsening. However, Alzheimer's disease is characterized by an insidious, continuously progressive course — it does not produce the episodic, event-linked drops with stable intervals between them that are described here. Preserved recall of personal events also argues against the amnestic profile typical of Alzheimer's.
option_explanations.C: The defining feature of vascular neurocognitive disorder is that its course is tied to the nature and location of cerebrovascular events and may involve acute onset, stepwise decline, or fluctuation. This patient experienced two discrete events — one following an apparent illness and one after a cardiac procedure — after each of which he permanently lost functional ground, with stability in between. This pattern, absent hallucinations or prominent amnesia, is the hallmark of vascular neurocognitive disorder.
option_explanations.D: Neurocognitive disorder due to another medical condition is a legitimate DSM-5 category, but it is a residual diagnosis used when a specific etiology cannot be identified. The pattern of event-linked stepwise decline following cardiac-related hospitalizations provides sufficient clinical evidence to specify a vascular etiology rather than leaving the cause unspecified.

questions.vignette: A 9-year-old child has expressed persistent discomfort with their assigned sex at birth and a strong desire to be treated as a different gender. The child's parents report that these feelings have been present for approximately eight months and are causing significant distress at school and at home. A psychologist is reviewing the DSM-5 criteria to determine whether the minimum duration requirement for a formal diagnosis of gender dysphoria has been met.
questions.question: According to DSM-5, what is the minimum duration of symptoms required to diagnose gender dysphoria, regardless of the patient's age?

options.A: Three months
options.B: Six months
options.C: Twelve months
options.D: Two years

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. A three-month minimum duration is not specified for gender dysphoria in the DSM-5. Some other DSM-5 diagnoses use shorter duration thresholds, but gender dysphoria requires at least six months of symptoms.
option_explanations.B: Correct. The DSM-5 specifies a minimum symptom duration of six months for the diagnosis of gender dysphoria, and this six-month requirement applies uniformly regardless of the patient's age, including children, adolescents, and adults.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. A twelve-month duration is required for certain other DSM-5 diagnoses, such as persistent depressive disorder, but it is not the threshold for gender dysphoria. Applying a twelve-month requirement would be overly restrictive and inconsistent with DSM-5 criteria.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. A two-year duration requirement is found in diagnoses such as persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) in adults, not in gender dysphoria. The DSM-5 sets the gender dysphoria minimum at six months, not two years.

questions.vignette: A 14-year-old adolescent has been referred to an outpatient mental health clinic after consistently expressing that their felt gender differs from the sex they were assigned at birth. The referring pediatrician notes that the adolescent has also shown signs of depression and social withdrawal, which began roughly four months ago following a school transition. The clinician conducting the diagnostic evaluation is careful to determine how long the gender-related distress specifically has been present and notes from the family interview that these gender-related feelings have persisted for seven months. The clinician must decide whether the DSM-5 duration requirement for gender dysphoria has been satisfied.
questions.question: Which of the following best reflects the DSM-5 duration requirement the clinician is evaluating in this case?

options.A: The diagnosis cannot be made in adolescents because the duration requirement is waived until adulthood
options.B: The diagnosis requires that symptoms have been present for at least twelve months to ensure they are not transient developmental changes
options.C: The diagnosis requires a minimum of six months of symptoms, which has been met in this case
options.D: The diagnosis requires only three months of symptoms in adolescents because their gender identity is considered less stable

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. The DSM-5 does not restrict or waive the gender dysphoria diagnosis based on developmental stage; the same diagnostic criteria, including the six-month duration requirement, apply to children, adolescents, and adults alike.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. A twelve-month minimum is not required by DSM-5 for gender dysphoria. While clinicians should exercise developmental sensitivity, the formal DSM-5 duration threshold is six months, not twelve, regardless of the patient's age.
option_explanations.C: Correct. The DSM-5 specifies a six-month minimum duration of symptoms for the diagnosis of gender dysphoria, applicable at all ages. Because this adolescent's gender-related distress has been present for seven months, the duration criterion is met. The comorbid depression and social withdrawal are clinically relevant but do not alter the gender dysphoria duration requirement.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. The DSM-5 does not specify a shorter or longer duration requirement based on age group. The six-month minimum applies uniformly across developmental stages, and there is no separate, abbreviated criterion for adolescents.

questions.vignette: A 7-year-old child is brought to a child psychologist after the parents noticed over the past five months that the child strongly prefers clothing, toys, and playmates typically associated with a gender different from the child's sex assigned at birth. The parents note that the child has begun expressing distress when required to wear gender-typical clothing and has told them repeatedly, 'I'm not a boy—I'm a girl.' The psychologist is aware that the presentation is compelling but must carefully weigh whether all required diagnostic criteria are currently satisfied before rendering a formal DSM-5 diagnosis.
questions.question: What is the most clinically accurate statement about whether this child currently meets full DSM-5 criteria for gender dysphoria?

options.A: The child meets full criteria because the presentation is clinically convincing and symptoms are causing significant distress
options.B: The child does not yet meet full criteria because the DSM-5 requires at least six months of symptoms, and the current duration of five months falls short
options.C: The child does not meet criteria because gender dysphoria cannot be diagnosed before age 10
options.D: The child meets criteria because the DSM-5 applies a shorter duration standard for prepubertal children than for adolescents or adults

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Clinical convincingness and the presence of distress are necessary but not sufficient for diagnosis; the DSM-5 also requires that symptoms have been present for a minimum of six months. Five months of symptoms does not satisfy this criterion, regardless of how compelling the presentation appears.
option_explanations.B: Correct. The DSM-5 requires a minimum symptom duration of six months for the diagnosis of gender dysphoria at all ages, including young children. Because this child's symptoms have been present for only five months, the duration criterion is not yet met, and a formal diagnosis cannot be assigned at this time.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. The DSM-5 does not establish a minimum age threshold for diagnosing gender dysphoria; the diagnosis can be applied to children of various ages. The barrier to diagnosis here is insufficient symptom duration, not the child's age.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. The DSM-5 does not differentiate duration requirements by developmental stage; the six-month minimum applies equally to prepubertal children, adolescents, and adults. There is no abbreviated or modified duration criterion for younger children.

questions.vignette: A licensed psychologist is consulting on a case involving a 16-year-old who strongly and consistently identifies as a gender different from their sex assigned at birth. The adolescent's discomfort with their primary and secondary sex characteristics is pervasive and is impairing academic performance and peer relationships. The parents indicate that these concerns emerged rather suddenly around four months ago following an online community the adolescent joined and question whether the presentation is socially influenced. The psychologist notes the adolescent's account is internally consistent, emotionally genuine, and free of psychotic features, but turns to the DSM-5 to evaluate whether the full diagnostic threshold has been reached.
questions.question: Based strictly on DSM-5 criteria, which factor most directly prevents a confirmed diagnosis of gender dysphoria at this time?

options.A: The suspected social influence from an online community raises concern that the symptoms may not reflect an authentic gender identity
options.B: The impairment in academic and social functioning is not severe enough to meet the clinical significance criterion
options.C: The adolescent's symptoms have been present for only four months, which does not yet satisfy the required minimum duration
options.D: The diagnosis requires corroboration from a second clinician before it can be assigned to an adolescent

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. While social influences are a legitimate clinical consideration in context, the DSM-5 does not include a criterion that excludes diagnosis on the basis of suspected social influence. The diagnostic criteria focus on symptom characteristics, duration, and functional impairment—not on etiology or presumed social contagion.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. The vignette explicitly describes impaired academic performance and peer relationships, indicating that the clinical significance criterion is likely met. The barrier to diagnosis is not the level of functional impairment but rather the insufficient duration of symptoms.
option_explanations.C: Correct. The DSM-5 requires that symptoms of gender dysphoria be present for a minimum of six months, regardless of the patient's age. This adolescent's symptoms have been present for only four months, meaning the duration criterion has not yet been satisfied. All other features described—pervasive discomfort, functional impairment, and internal consistency—may otherwise support the diagnosis once the duration threshold is met.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. The DSM-5 does not require corroboration from a second clinician or mandate a multi-clinician consensus for the diagnosis of gender dysphoria in adolescents. This option describes a procedural requirement that does not exist within DSM-5 diagnostic criteria.

questions.vignette: A 12-year-old child is evaluated by a psychologist after the child's school counselor raised concerns. For the past four and a half months, the child has been deeply uncomfortable using the restroom at school that corresponds to their biological sex and has persistently asked parents to use a different name and set of pronouns at home. The child tearfully states that they feel like a 'mistake' and that their body does not belong to them. The parents note that these feelings appeared to intensify after the child began watching a particular television series and spending time in a specific online forum, and they wonder if the child is simply mimicking what they have seen. The psychologist observes that the child's affect is genuine, the account is coherent across sessions, and there is no evidence of a thought disorder or mood episode driving the presentation.
questions.question: Based on the most precise application of the relevant diagnostic standard, which of the following most accurately reflects the child's current diagnostic status?

options.A: The child likely meets criteria for a depressive disorder given the tearful affect, statements of feeling like a 'mistake,' and reports of bodily alienation
options.B: The child does not yet meet criteria for the most fitting diagnosis because a specific minimum time threshold has not been reached
options.C: The child meets criteria for the most fitting diagnosis because the presentation is internally consistent and functionally impairing
options.D: The child's diagnosis is deferred pending further assessment of whether the online and media exposure accounts for the presentation

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. While tearful affect and statements suggesting bodily alienation could superficially suggest a depressive disorder, the specific content of the child's distress—focused on the mismatch between felt identity and biological sex, and on requests for different name and pronouns—most closely aligns with gender dysphoria rather than a primary mood disorder. A depressive diagnosis does not capture the identity-specific nature of the presentation.
option_explanations.B: Correct. The child's presentation—persistent discomfort with biological sex characteristics, desire for a different name and pronouns, and associated distress and impairment—most closely fits the criteria for gender dysphoria. However, the DSM-5 requires a minimum of six months of symptoms for this diagnosis to be assigned, and the child's symptoms have been present for only four and a half months. Therefore, despite the clinical validity of the presentation, the formal diagnosis cannot yet be confirmed because the required duration threshold has not been met.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. While internal consistency and functional impairment are necessary components of the diagnostic picture, they alone are not sufficient under DSM-5 criteria. The six-month minimum duration requirement must also be satisfied, and at four and a half months the child falls short of this threshold regardless of the clinical strength of the presentation.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. While the potential influence of media and online communities is clinically worth noting, the DSM-5 does not include a criterion requiring the clinician to rule out social or media influence before assigning a diagnosis. Deferring solely on this basis misrepresents the actual diagnostic barrier, which is the unmet duration requirement rather than any etiological uncertainty.

questions.source_summary: Dissociative amnesia is characterized by an inability to recall important autobiographical information that's often related to exposure to a stressful or traumatic event, and the DSM-5 identifies localized amnesia as the type of dissociative amnesia where the person is unable to recall events that happened during a limited period of time (e.g., for several weeks after the person experienced a traumatic event).
questions.subdomain: Trauma/Stressor-Related, Dissociative, and Somatic Symptom Disorders
questions.vignette: A 34-year-old woman is referred for evaluation after her family reports she cannot recall any events from the three weeks following a serious car accident in which her husband was killed. She has no neurological findings on medical workup, and her memory for events before and after this specific window is entirely intact. She describes the gap in her autobiographical memory as deeply troubling and says it feels 'like those weeks simply don't exist.' Her clinician notes that the memory impairment is confined to a discrete period tied directly to the traumatic event.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis and subtype most accurately describes this patient's presentation?

options.A: Dissociative amnesia, localized type
options.B: Dissociative identity disorder
options.C: Posttraumatic stress disorder
options.D: Dissociative amnesia, generalized type

option_explanations.A: This is correct. Dissociative amnesia, localized type, is characterized by inability to recall autobiographical information from a specific, bounded time period following a traumatic event, with memory intact outside that window — precisely what this patient demonstrates.
option_explanations.B: Dissociative identity disorder involves the presence of two or more distinct personality states and often includes amnesia across identity states, but this patient shows no evidence of alternate identities or personality disruption — only a bounded memory gap.
option_explanations.C: PTSD follows trauma and can include intrusive symptoms, avoidance, and negative cognitions, but its core feature is not inability to recall events from the immediate post-trauma period. The patient here shows no mention of re-experiencing or hyperarousal.
option_explanations.D: Generalized dissociative amnesia involves loss of identity and life history broadly — not just a limited time window. This patient's amnesia is confined to a specific three-week period, making the localized subtype the correct designation.

questions.vignette: A 28-year-old combat veteran presents to a VA clinic complaining that he cannot remember anything that occurred during the six weeks after he survived a roadside bombing that killed two of his unit members. He reports vivid memories of the bombing itself and clear recollection of events that occurred months later, but the intervening period is completely blank. Notably, he also endorses difficulty sleeping and occasional irritability, which his wife attributes to coming home from deployment. Neurological evaluation returns normal results.
questions.question: The veteran's inability to recall events confined to a specific post-traumatic period, in the absence of neurological pathology, is best explained by which DSM-5 diagnosis?

options.A: Posttraumatic stress disorder
options.B: Neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury
options.C: Dissociative amnesia, localized type
options.D: Dissociative amnesia, selective type

option_explanations.C: This is correct. Localized dissociative amnesia involves the complete inability to recall events from a circumscribed period of time following a traumatic event, without neurological cause. The veteran's blank six-week window following the bombing, with intact memory before and after, fits this subtype precisely.
option_explanations.A: PTSD is a plausible consideration given trauma exposure and symptoms like sleep difficulties and irritability. However, PTSD does not account for complete inability to recall an entire bounded post-trauma period — its memory feature involves difficulty recalling aspects of the trauma itself, not a subsequent time window.
option_explanations.B: Neurocognitive disorder due to TBI would involve memory deficits with an identifiable neurological basis, typically including other cognitive changes. The normal neurological evaluation and the specificity of the memory gap (bounded post-trauma period, not global cognitive decline) rule this out.
option_explanations.D: Selective dissociative amnesia involves inability to recall some, but not all, events within a specific period — the person has partial memory. This veteran reports the entire six-week period as completely blank, which is consistent with localized, not selective, amnesia.

questions.vignette: A 45-year-old woman is brought to an outpatient clinic by her daughter, who reports that her mother 'lost a month of her life' following a house fire in which she narrowly escaped but lost all her possessions. The woman appears calm and reports that while she remembers the night of the fire clearly, she has no recollection of the month that followed, despite family members describing her as 'functioning normally' during that time. She currently endorses mild low mood and says she sometimes feels numb when she thinks about the fire. A full neurological workup, including MRI and EEG, is unremarkable. The clinician notes the patient does not report intrusive memories, flashbacks, or active avoidance of fire-related stimuli.
questions.question: Which diagnosis best accounts for the core memory disturbance this patient is experiencing?

options.A: Depressive disorder with peritraumatic dissociation
options.B: Posttraumatic stress disorder with dissociative subtype
options.C: Dissociative amnesia, localized type
options.D: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood

option_explanations.C: This is correct. The defining feature here is complete inability to recall autobiographical events from a bounded post-trauma period (one month following the fire), without neurological cause. This is the hallmark of localized dissociative amnesia. The patient's calm affect (la belle indifférence) and normal neurological workup further support a dissociative rather than medical etiology.
option_explanations.A: Peritraumatic dissociation refers to dissociative experiences occurring during or immediately after a traumatic event, not a sustained month-long amnesia for the post-trauma period. Additionally, 'depressive disorder with peritraumatic dissociation' is not a formal DSM-5 diagnosis category.
option_explanations.B: PTSD with dissociative subtype involves depersonalization or derealization occurring alongside full PTSD symptom criteria, including intrusions, avoidance, and hyperarousal. This patient explicitly lacks intrusive memories, flashbacks, and avoidance, ruling out a PTSD diagnosis.
option_explanations.D: Adjustment disorder involves emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor but does not encompass complete amnesia for a post-trauma time period. The mild low mood could suggest this diagnosis, but it cannot explain the core memory gap.
