questions.vignette: A 33-year-old man voluntarily contacts a mental health clinic after reading an article about compulsive behavior. He reports that for the past ten months he has sought out environments where he will be physically pressed against other adults who are not aware of his intentions, and that these encounters produce the most intense feelings of excitement he has ever experienced. He describes spending hours each week imagining these situations and states that he has recently begun turning down social invitations so he can position himself in locations where these encounters are more likely. He adds that he feels significant shame and that his behavior has never involved attempts to cause pain or fear in others, and that he has no interest in exposing himself. His presentation is initially read by the intake coordinator as reflecting an impulse-control problem related to social anxiety avoidance.
questions.question: Which condition most accurately describes the phenomenon this man is experiencing?

options.A: Social Anxiety Disorder with behavioral avoidance
options.B: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
options.C: Frotteuristic Disorder
options.D: Exhibitionistic Disorder

option_explanations.A: Social Anxiety Disorder involves fear of social situations due to concerns about negative evaluation or embarrassment, leading to avoidance of social contact. This patient reduces social invitations not to avoid people but to redirect time and access toward specific environments for sexual arousal, a distinction that rules out Social Anxiety Disorder despite the surface resemblance of social withdrawal.
option_explanations.B: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder involves ego-dystonic intrusive thoughts and ritualistic behaviors aimed at reducing distress. Although this patient reports persistent and difficult-to-control ideation about specific scenarios, the experiences generate intense sexual excitement rather than anxiety, and the behaviors are organized around obtaining arousal from contact with unknowing others, not around neutralizing an unwanted thought, distinguishing it from OCD.
option_explanations.C: Frotteuristic Disorder is correct. The patient has a ten-month history of recurrent, intense sexual arousal derived specifically from physical closeness with unknowing adult strangers, accompanied by persistent sexual fantasies about these encounters, behavioral reorganization of his daily life to facilitate them, and significant associated shame and distress. He explicitly rules out arousal from pain-infliction or self-exposure, narrowing the diagnosis to Frotteuristic Disorder.
option_explanations.D: Exhibitionistic Disorder centers on sexual arousal from exposing one's own genitals to unsuspecting individuals. The patient explicitly states he has no interest in exposing himself, and his arousal is tied to physical proximity and contact rather than visual display, making Exhibitionistic Disorder inconsistent with his described experience.

questions.source_summary: There is growing consensus that no-suicide contracts are not an effective tool for preventing suicide.
questions.vignette: A licensed clinical psychologist is supervising a predoctoral intern who has just completed an intake with a patient presenting with suicidal ideation and a history of a previous attempt. The intern states she asked the patient to sign a no-suicide contract at the end of the session, believing it would serve as a protective measure. During supervision, the psychologist asks the intern to reflect on the empirical support for this practice. The intern reviews the current literature on suicide risk management and finds that no-suicide contracts have not been shown to reduce suicidal behavior or prevent suicide.
questions.question: Which of the following best describes the current professional consensus regarding no-suicide contracts as a suicide prevention tool?

options.A: No-suicide contracts are a well-validated, evidence-based intervention recommended in most clinical practice guidelines for managing acute suicidal ideation.
options.B: No-suicide contracts are primarily useful for patients with borderline personality disorder due to their high rates of impulsive suicidal behavior.
options.C: No-suicide contracts lack empirical support as an effective suicide prevention strategy and are not recommended as a standalone risk management tool.
options.D: No-suicide contracts are contraindicated only in inpatient settings but remain a first-line intervention in outpatient psychotherapy.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. Despite widespread historical use, no-suicide contracts have not been validated as evidence-based interventions. Research has not demonstrated that they reduce suicidal behavior, and leading professional organizations do not recommend them as a primary suicide prevention strategy.
option_explanations.B: This is incorrect. While no-suicide contracts have historically been used across various populations, including those with borderline personality disorder, there is no evidence that they are especially effective for any diagnostic group. The broader issue is their lack of empirical support across all patient populations.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. The professional and empirical consensus holds that no-suicide contracts do not have evidence supporting their effectiveness in preventing suicide. They may provide clinicians with a false sense of security and are not recommended as standalone risk management tools.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. The limitations of no-suicide contracts apply to both inpatient and outpatient settings. There is no credible evidence base supporting their use as a first-line intervention in any clinical setting, and the distinction between inpatient and outpatient contexts does not accurately characterize why they are discouraged.

questions.source_summary: There is growing consensus that no-suicide contracts are not an effective tool for preventing suicide.
questions.vignette: A psychiatrist in a community mental health center has been treating a 34-year-old man with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder, recurrent, with a history of one prior suicide attempt during a severe depressive episode. The patient reports passive suicidal ideation but denies a plan or intent at this time. At the close of the session, the psychiatrist asks the patient to sign a written agreement promising not to harm himself before their next appointment, which is in one week. The psychiatrist documents this agreement as the primary risk management strategy in the clinical notes. A consultant reviewing the case raises concerns about this approach.
questions.question: What is the most accurate clinical concern the consultant is likely raising about the psychiatrist's primary risk management strategy?

options.A: The one-week interval between appointments is too long for a patient with active suicidal ideation, and a more frequent contact schedule is the primary concern.
options.B: The written agreement asking the patient to refrain from self-harm is not supported by evidence as an effective suicide prevention tool and should not serve as the primary risk management strategy.
options.C: Relying on a written agreement as the primary intervention is inappropriate because it constitutes an informed consent violation when used without explaining its limitations to the patient.
options.D: The psychiatrist should have conducted a formal structured suicide risk assessment using a validated instrument before implementing any written agreement.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. While appointment frequency is a valid clinical consideration for high-risk patients, the consultant's primary concern is specifically about the written no-suicide contract being used as the main risk management tool. Appointment scheduling is a secondary issue and does not address the fundamental lack of evidence for the contract itself.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The written agreement the psychiatrist used is a no-suicide contract, which the empirical literature consistently indicates lacks evidence as an effective suicide prevention strategy. Using it as the primary risk management tool is the core clinical and ethical concern the consultant would raise.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. While transparency with patients about the limitations of any intervention is good clinical practice, no-suicide contracts are primarily criticized for their lack of empirical effectiveness rather than for constituting an informed consent violation. This option conflates two distinct clinical and ethical issues.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. Conducting a formal structured risk assessment is indeed best practice, but the prompt specifies that the consultant's concern is about the primary risk management strategy — the written agreement — not about the assessment process that preceded it. This distractor is clinically relevant but does not reflect the core problem identified.

questions.source_summary: There is growing consensus that no-suicide contracts are not an effective tool for preventing suicide.
questions.vignette: During a training workshop on evidence-based approaches to suicide risk management, a trainer presents two case vignettes side by side. In the first case, a clinician completes a collaborative safety planning intervention with a patient experiencing depressive episodes and passive suicidal ideation; the plan includes warning signs, coping strategies, social supports, and means restriction. In the second case, a different clinician asks a patient in similar circumstances to sign a written promise not to act on suicidal thoughts before the next session, and documents this as the risk management strategy. The trainer highlights the second case as a cautionary example and asks attendees to identify why it is problematic. Several attendees initially defend the second approach because it creates a formal, documentable record of patient commitment.
questions.question: Why does the trainer characterize the second clinician's approach as a cautionary example rather than an acceptable practice?

options.A: Written agreements are problematic primarily because they are difficult to document in electronic health records and create administrative burdens that distract from direct patient care.
options.B: The written promise is a no-suicide contract, which research has not shown to be effective in preventing suicidal behavior, and it may give the clinician a false sense of security while failing the patient.
options.C: The second clinician's approach is inappropriate because written agreements require dual signatures to be legally binding, and a unilateral patient promise does not meet the standard of care for risk documentation.
options.D: The second clinician should have combined the written promise with a formal risk rating scale, since standalone written agreements are only problematic when no structured assessment accompanies them.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. The criticism of no-suicide contracts is grounded in the absence of evidence for their clinical effectiveness, not in administrative or documentation logistics. This option misidentifies the nature of the concern and is not aligned with the professional or empirical literature on the topic.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The written promise described in the second case is a no-suicide contract. The professional consensus, supported by empirical literature, indicates that these contracts have not been shown to prevent suicidal behavior and may create a false sense of clinical security, thereby posing a risk to both patient safety and sound clinical practice.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. The concern about no-suicide contracts is not rooted in legal requirements around signatures or binding agreements. This distractor conflates clinical risk management with legal contract standards, which is not the basis for the trainer's concern. The issue is empirical effectiveness, not procedural legal sufficiency.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. Adding a structured risk assessment alongside a no-suicide contract does not render the contract itself effective. The empirical evidence against no-suicide contracts as a risk prevention tool is not conditional on whether a risk assessment was also completed. The contract remains unsupported regardless of what accompanies it.

questions.source_summary: There is growing consensus that no-suicide contracts are not an effective tool for preventing suicide.
questions.vignette: A researcher reviewing archival clinical records at a large outpatient psychiatric clinic notices a recurring pattern: clinicians often ended sessions with patients who expressed passive suicidal ideation by asking them to verbally or in writing affirm a commitment to return for their next appointment and not act on their thoughts in the interim. The researcher notes that clinic leadership had historically promoted this practice as a way to reinforce therapeutic alliance and increase patient accountability. However, follow-up data show no statistically significant difference in self-harm incidents or missed appointments between patients who made such affirmations and those who did not. The researcher recommends revising the clinic's training protocols, arguing that the practice confers no measurable protective benefit and may obscure the need for more active clinical intervention.
questions.question: The researcher's recommendation most directly reflects which established finding in the clinical literature on suicide risk management?

options.A: Therapeutic alliance is not a significant predictor of treatment engagement in patients with suicidal ideation, and interventions that emphasize relationship factors are generally ineffective.
options.B: Verbal and written agreements in which patients with suicidal ideation commit to refraining from self-harm have not been shown to reduce suicidal behavior and may substitute for more effective clinical risk management strategies.
options.C: Structured risk assessment tools administered at session termination are superior to unstructured approaches because they quantify risk level and guide treatment intensity decisions.
options.D: Patient accountability interventions are only effective when embedded within a broader cognitive-behavioral treatment protocol targeting hopelessness and depressive cognitions.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. The literature consistently identifies therapeutic alliance as a meaningful factor in treatment engagement and outcomes for suicidal patients. This option mischaracterizes the researcher's concern, which is not about alliance-based strategies broadly but specifically about the lack of evidence for commitment-based written or verbal agreements as a protective tool.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The affirmation practice described — whether verbal or written — constitutes a no-suicide contract. Research has consistently failed to demonstrate that such commitments reduce suicidal behavior, and the finding the researcher references is the well-established professional consensus that no-suicide contracts lack empirical support and can provide false reassurance in lieu of active clinical intervention.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. While structured risk assessment tools are generally considered superior to unstructured approaches, the researcher's critique is not about the method of assessing risk but about the use of patient commitment affirmations as a protective strategy. This distractor introduces a valid clinical concept that does not match the specific finding being invoked.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. Although embedding interventions within a broader evidence-based protocol like CBT is consistent with best practices, the researcher's argument is specifically that commitment affirmations lack independent protective value — not that they need to be supplemented with a particular theoretical modality. This option conflates the problem of the specific practice with a more general treatment integration argument.

questions.source_summary: There is growing consensus that no-suicide contracts are not an effective tool for preventing suicide.
questions.vignette: A training program director reviews session recordings from several trainees who are working with patients who have recently expressed thoughts of ending their lives. In one recording, a trainee concludes the session by asking the patient to verbally agree to call the crisis line and return for the next session, and the trainee documents this exchange as the primary protective step taken. In a follow-up peer consultation, other trainees argue that this approach should be praised because it actively engages the patient in treatment, creates a verbal record of the patient's stated intentions, and leverages the therapeutic relationship as a protective factor. The director, however, uses this recording as an example of a practice that feels clinically sound but has not been shown to actually reduce the outcome it targets. The director emphasizes that trainees should not allow the appearance of patient engagement to substitute for interventions that have demonstrated measurable benefit.
questions.question: The program director is using this recording to illustrate which specific clinical principle?

options.A: Crisis intervention techniques that rely on patient self-report of intent are inherently unreliable because patients in acute distress are prone to acquiescence and social desirability responding.
options.B: Verbal commitments made by patients with thoughts of self-harm at the close of a session lack empirical evidence as an effective protective strategy and should not replace evidence-based risk management approaches.
options.C: Trainees who prioritize therapeutic alliance as a primary risk reduction mechanism are applying an atheoretical approach that overlooks the cognitive and neurobiological factors underlying suicidal crises.
options.D: Documentation of patient verbal agreements is insufficient for legal risk management purposes and creates liability for clinicians who do not supplement it with a formal written record.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. While acquiescence and social desirability are real threats to the validity of self-report in distressed patients, the director's concern is specifically about the absence of evidence that verbal commitment agreements reduce suicidal behavior — not about the general unreliability of self-report in crisis contexts. This distractor is plausible but addresses a different construct.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The practice described — asking a patient to verbally commit to not acting on suicidal thoughts and to return for the next appointment — is the defining feature of a no-suicide or no-harm contract in verbal form. The director's point directly reflects the empirical literature showing that such agreements have not been demonstrated to reduce suicidal behavior and can give clinicians and trainees a misleading sense that protective action has been taken.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. Therapeutic alliance is actually an empirically supported predictor of treatment engagement and is not dismissed in the suicide literature. The director is not critiquing the use of relational factors broadly; rather, the concern is narrowly about the specific practice of using a verbal commitment agreement as a primary protective tool, not about the value of the therapeutic relationship itself.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. The director's concern is explicitly clinical and empirical — centered on whether the intervention reduces harm — not legal or administrative in nature. While documentation adequacy is a legitimate clinical risk management issue, it is not the principle the director invokes when saying the practice 'feels clinically sound but has not been shown to reduce the outcome it targets.'

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of anorexia nervosa does not require dieting or fasting to maintain low body weight.
questions.vignette: A 19-year-old female is referred for evaluation after her college athletic coach notices she has been losing significant weight. She reports an intense fear of gaining weight and describes her self-worth as almost entirely dependent on her body size. Although she does not diet or fast, she engages in six hours of compulsive exercise daily, which she reports is driven by the goal of maintaining a low body weight. Her BMI is 15.8, and she denies any compensatory purging behaviors. Her clinician considers whether her pattern meets criteria for anorexia nervosa.
questions.question: Which of the following best accounts for why this patient meets diagnostic criteria for anorexia nervosa despite not restricting food intake through dieting or fasting?

options.A: Anorexia nervosa requires caloric restriction through dieting or fasting as a core diagnostic criterion, so this patient does not qualify.
options.B: Anorexia nervosa criteria require the presence of purging behaviors alongside low body weight, making this presentation more consistent with bulimia nervosa.
options.C: Anorexia nervosa diagnosis requires only significantly low body weight, intense fear of gaining weight, and disturbance in how body weight or shape is experienced, and any behavior that persistently prevents weight gain — including excessive exercise — satisfies the weight-maintenance criterion.
options.D: This presentation is best classified as other specified feeding or eating disorder (OSFED) because excessive exercise rather than restriction is the primary maintaining behavior.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. The DSM-5 does not require dieting or fasting specifically; Criterion A requires significantly low body weight, and any persistent behavior that prevents appropriate weight gain qualifies, including excessive exercise.
option_explanations.B: This is incorrect. Bulimia nervosa is characterized by recurrent binge-eating episodes followed by compensatory behaviors; the patient denies purging and does not report binge eating, so bulimia nervosa does not apply.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. DSM-5 Criterion A for anorexia nervosa specifies significantly low body weight in the context of restriction of energy intake; this restriction can be achieved through multiple means, including excessive exercise that persistently prevents weight gain, not solely through dieting or fasting.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. OSFED applies when the full criteria for a named eating disorder are not met; here, the patient meets all three core criteria for anorexia nervosa (low BMI, intense fear of weight gain, body image disturbance), so a full AN diagnosis is appropriate.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of anorexia nervosa does not require dieting or fasting to maintain low body weight.
questions.vignette: A 17-year-old male presents to a sports medicine clinic with fatigue and stress fractures attributed to overtraining. He exercises intensely twice daily and reports feeling 'fat' despite being visibly underweight, reflecting a clear body image disturbance. He denies ever skipping meals and states he eats 'normally,' but his parents report his portions are very small and he refuses foods he considers 'unhealthy.' He has a history of anxiety, which the team psychologist notes could independently explain some of his rigid behaviors. His BMI is 16.1 and he has not had a menstrual cycle equivalent (low testosterone confirmed by labs).
questions.question: Which diagnosis most accurately captures this patient's presentation?

options.A: Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID), because the patient's food avoidance is driven by sensory sensitivity rather than weight-related fears.
options.B: Anorexia nervosa, because the diagnosis requires significantly low body weight, intense fear of weight gain or persistent behavior interfering with weight gain, and body image disturbance — none of which require dieting or fasting as the specific mechanism.
options.C: Bulimia nervosa, because his rigid food rules and intense exercise suggest compensatory behaviors following unacknowledged binge episodes.
options.D: Generalized anxiety disorder with somatic features, because his preoccupation with health and rigid exercise routines are better explained by his anxiety history.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. ARFID is characterized by avoidance of food based on sensory characteristics, fear of aversive consequences like choking, or lack of interest in eating — critically, it is not driven by fear of weight gain or body image concerns, which are present here.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The patient meets all three DSM-5 criteria for anorexia nervosa: significantly low BMI, behaviors that persistently interfere with weight gain (intense exercise, small portions, food avoidance), and body image disturbance. The absence of explicit fasting does not preclude the diagnosis.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. Bulimia nervosa requires recurrent binge-eating episodes followed by compensatory behaviors; there is no evidence of binge eating in this vignette, and the exercise appears to be a primary weight-control strategy rather than compensation for binges.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. While GAD can involve excessive worry and rigid behaviors, it does not account for the clinically significant low body weight, body image disturbance, or food-related behaviors that have a clear weight-control function — these point to a primary eating disorder diagnosis.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of anorexia nervosa does not require dieting or fasting to maintain low body weight.
questions.vignette: A 22-year-old woman is brought to a university counseling center by her roommate, who reports increasing concern about the client's rigid daily rituals and dramatic decline in weight over eight months. The client insists she eats 'enough' and describes her meals as balanced, which she documents in a detailed food journal showing adequate caloric entries — however, collateral information suggests she exercises covertly for four or more hours per day. She describes her body as 'soft and flabby' despite a current BMI of 15.2 and reports that she cannot imagine reducing her exercise because it is 'the only thing keeping her healthy.' She has no history of binge eating and denies vomiting.
questions.question: Which diagnosis best fits this presentation, and what is the most critical diagnostic principle it illustrates?

options.A: Obsessive-compulsive disorder, because her ritualistic food journaling and rigid exercise routines reflect ego-dystonic compulsions aimed at reducing anxiety.
options.B: Bulimia nervosa, binge-purge subtype, because her denial of symptoms and covert behavior suggest hidden compensatory exercise following unreported binge episodes.
options.C: Anorexia nervosa, illustrating that maintaining significantly low body weight through excessive exercise — rather than dieting or fasting — fully satisfies the diagnostic weight-maintenance criterion.
options.D: Other specified feeding or eating disorder (OSFED), because the patient reports eating adequate calories, preventing a full anorexia nervosa diagnosis.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. While OCD can co-occur with eating disorders and ritualistic behaviors are present, OCD does not account for the significantly low body weight or the body image disturbance tied specifically to weight and shape. The behaviors here are ego-syntonic (she views them as healthy), and the primary clinical picture centers on weight and eating, not intrusive obsessions.
option_explanations.B: This is incorrect. Bulimia nervosa requires evidence of recurrent binge eating, which is not supported by the vignette. Covert exercise is better understood as a primary weight-control strategy consistent with anorexia nervosa rather than as compensation following binges.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. The patient meets all three DSM-5 criteria for anorexia nervosa: significantly low BMI, persistent behavior (covert excessive exercise) that interferes with weight gain driven by fear of becoming fat, and distorted body image. The food journal creating the illusion of adequate intake is a red herring; the mechanism of weight maintenance does not need to be food restriction.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. OSFED is used when a full syndrome is not present; however, this patient meets all three core criteria for anorexia nervosa. The self-reported adequate intake is contradicted by collateral evidence and the objective low BMI, and DSM-5 does not require the mechanism to be caloric restriction through dieting or fasting.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of anorexia nervosa does not require dieting or fasting to maintain low body weight.
questions.vignette: A 25-year-old endurance athlete presents to a sports psychologist after her coach mandates an evaluation. She trains 25–30 hours per week and has always described herself as devoted rather than disordered. Her food logs, verified by a dietitian, show that she consumes approximately 2,200 calories per day — a figure the athlete emphasizes as proof she does not have an eating disorder. However, her total daily energy expenditure is estimated at over 4,500 calories, producing a sustained deficit that has driven her BMI to 15.6. She reports that she experiences extreme distress when she misses a training session and refuses to consider reducing training volume because she believes her body will 'balloon' if she stops. Psychological testing reveals no binge eating and no purging.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most accurately applies to this patient, and what is the principle that best supports it?

options.A: Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (RED-S), because the primary problem is an unintentional energy imbalance due to athletic demands rather than psychopathology driven by fear of weight gain.
options.B: Anorexia nervosa, because restriction of energy intake relative to requirements — maintained through excessive exercise that produces a severe caloric deficit — satisfies Criterion A, and her distress about reducing training reflects the intense fear of weight gain required by Criterion B.
options.C: Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID), because she avoids consuming sufficient energy without apparent fear of weight gain as the stated motivation.
options.D: Exercise addiction, because her compulsive need to train and distress when exercise is interrupted are the primary features, with low weight as a secondary consequence rather than a goal.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. RED-S is a physiological framework describing energy deficiency in athletes and is not a DSM-5 psychiatric diagnosis; it does not require or assess the psychological features present here, such as intense fear of weight gain and body image disturbance. The patient's distress about training reduction and belief that her body will 'balloon' indicate psychopathology beyond unintentional energy imbalance.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. DSM-5 Criterion A for anorexia nervosa specifies restriction of energy intake relative to requirements leading to significantly low body weight — not restriction of caloric intake in absolute terms. By maintaining exercise that creates a >2,000-calorie daily deficit, this patient restricts net energy intake. Her explicit fear that stopping exercise will cause weight gain satisfies Criterion B, confirming the diagnosis.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. ARFID involves avoidance of food based on sensory, aversive-consequence, or interest-based factors without concern about weight or shape. This patient's fear that her body will 'balloon' without exercise is a clear weight-gain fear, distinguishing her presentation from ARFID.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. While exercise addiction shares features such as compulsive exercise and distress upon abstinence, it is not a DSM-5 diagnosis and does not explain the significantly low body weight combined with explicit fear of weight gain and body image disturbance. The exercise here is purposefully weight-regulatory, consistent with anorexia nervosa.

questions.source_summary: The diagnosis of anorexia nervosa does not require dieting or fasting to maintain low body weight.
questions.vignette: A 20-year-old woman is referred to a psychologist after her primary care physician notes that she has lost 28 pounds over the past year and now weighs 94 pounds at 5'4". She tells the clinician she is proud of her fitness routine, which involves swimming two miles and cycling 20 miles every morning before work. She keeps a meticulous food diary and reports eating three structured meals per day, including what she describes as 'plenty of protein and vegetables.' When the clinician gently suggests she might consider eating more, she becomes tearful and says, 'If I stop moving this much, I'll look disgusting — I can see it already, I look puffy in the mirror.' She has no history of vomiting, laxative use, or episodes of eating large quantities of food in short periods.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis best applies to this patient?

options.A: Bulimia nervosa, non-purging type, because her intense exercise functions as a compensatory behavior following meals.
options.B: Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder, because her structured eating and extreme energy expenditure suggest a functional avoidance of adequate nutrition without explicit expression of weight-related fear.
options.C: Anorexia nervosa, because she maintains a significantly low body weight through a persistent behavior that prevents weight gain, accompanied by a distorted perception of her body and fear of weight increase.
options.D: Other specified feeding or eating disorder, because she eats structured meals with documented caloric intake and does not restrict food, precluding a full anorexia nervosa diagnosis.

option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. Bulimia nervosa, non-purging type, was removed from the DSM-5; more importantly, bulimia nervosa requires recurrent binge-eating episodes as a core feature, and there is no evidence of binge eating in this case. Exercise that functions to prevent weight gain rather than to compensate for a binge is a feature of anorexia nervosa, not bulimia.
option_explanations.B: This is incorrect. ARFID is characterized by food avoidance based on sensory aversion, fear of choking or vomiting, or lack of interest in eating, and critically does not involve fear of weight gain or distorted body image. This patient explicitly states she fears looking 'disgusting' and already perceives herself as 'puffy,' which are body image and weight-gain-fear features that exclude ARFID.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. The patient meets all three DSM-5 criteria for anorexia nervosa: (1) significantly low body weight (BMI approximately 16.1); (2) a persistent behavior — extreme daily exercise — that prevents appropriate weight gain, driven by fear of looking disgusting; and (3) disturbance in the way her body is perceived (seeing herself as puffy despite being severely underweight). DSM-5 does not require the mechanism of low weight to be dietary restriction.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. OSFED is used when the full criteria for a specific eating disorder are not met. Here, the patient meets all three core criteria for anorexia nervosa; the apparent consumption of structured meals is a red herring, because the diagnostic criterion concerns restriction of energy intake relative to requirements — not absolute food avoidance — and her enormous daily energy expenditure creates a severe deficit regardless of meal structure.

questions.subdomain: Trauma/Stressor-Related, Dissociative, and Somatic Symptom Disorders
questions.vignette: Edna, a 34-year-old office manager, presents to a psychologist describing persistent episodes in which she feels like a robot going through the motions of life, as though she is watching herself from outside her body. She also reports that familiar surroundings sometimes appear foggy or dreamlike, a classic sign of derealization. These dissociation experiences have caused marked distress and led her to resign from her job. A thorough medical workup and toxicology screen have returned entirely normal results. Edna's reality testing remains intact throughout — she knows she is not actually a robot.
questions.question: Which DSM-5 diagnosis best accounts for Edna's clinical presentation?

options.A: Dissociative identity disorder
options.B: Depersonalization/derealization disorder
options.C: Panic disorder
options.D: Acute stress disorder

option_explanations.A: Dissociative identity disorder (DID) involves the presence of two or more distinct personality states or identities that recurrently take control of behavior. Edna shows no evidence of identity fragmentation or amnesia between states; her symptoms are confined to feeling detached from herself and her environment.
option_explanations.B: Depersonalization/derealization disorder is characterized by persistent or recurrent experiences of feeling detached from one's mental processes or body (depersonalization) and/or of feeling like a detached observer of one's surroundings (derealization), with intact reality testing, causing significant functional impairment, and not attributable to substances or a medical condition — all of which match Edna's presentation precisely.
option_explanations.C: Panic disorder involves recurrent, unexpected panic attacks followed by persistent concern about future attacks or maladaptive behavioral changes. While panic can include transient depersonalization, Edna's symptoms are persistent rather than episodic, and she lacks the defining fear of recurrent panic attacks.
option_explanations.D: Acute stress disorder requires exposure to a traumatic event and is diagnosed within three days to one month post-trauma. The vignette describes no identifiable traumatic stressor, and there is no mention of intrusion, avoidance, or negative mood symptoms following a specific event.

questions.source_summary: Edna's symptoms of feeling like a robot, lightheadedness, and anxiety that led her to quit her job are characteristic of depersonalization/derealization disorder, assuming her symptoms are not due to substance use or a medical condition.
questions.subdomain: Trauma/Stressor-Related, Dissociative, and Somatic Symptom Disorders
questions.vignette: Maria, a 29-year-old graduate student with a longstanding history of generalized anxiety, reports that over the past eight months she has felt persistently detached from her own thoughts and body, as though she is observing herself from a distance. She mentions that loud environments at school can trigger waves of anxiety and make the world feel oddly unreal, though she knows intellectually that her perceptions are distorted. Her physician has ruled out thyroid dysfunction, seizure disorder, and drug use. The symptoms have become severe enough that she has withdrawn from her graduate program.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most accurately captures the primary disorder responsible for Maria's perceptual disturbances and functional decline?

options.A: Generalized anxiety disorder
options.B: Panic disorder with agoraphobia
options.C: Depersonalization/derealization disorder
options.D: Dissociative amnesia

option_explanations.A: Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is characterized by excessive, difficult-to-control worry about multiple domains with associated physical symptoms (e.g., muscle tension, fatigue). Although Maria has an anxiety history, GAD does not account for the persistent, primary experience of self-detachment and perceptual unreality that is causing her functional impairment.
option_explanations.B: Panic disorder with agoraphobia involves recurrent unexpected panic attacks and subsequent avoidance of situations where escape might be difficult. While Maria avoids loud environments and experiences anxiety, her core complaint is the continuous feeling of detachment from herself and her surroundings, not episodic panic attacks or fear of having them.
option_explanations.C: Depersonalization/derealization disorder is the correct diagnosis. Maria experiences persistent detachment from her own mental processes (depersonalization) and perceptions of unreality about her environment (derealization), maintains intact reality testing, has had medical causes excluded, and shows significant functional decline — fulfilling all DSM-5 criteria.
option_explanations.D: Dissociative amnesia involves an inability to recall important autobiographical information, usually of a traumatic nature, beyond ordinary forgetting. Maria describes no gaps in memory or inability to recall personal history; her dissociative experience is one of detachment rather than memory disruption.

questions.source_summary: Edna's symptoms of feeling like a robot, lightheadedness, and anxiety that led her to quit her job are characteristic of depersonalization/derealization disorder, assuming her symptoms are not due to substance use or a medical condition.

questions.vignette: Tomás, a 27-year-old software developer, was evaluated following a six-month period during which he has felt persistently strange and disconnected. He reports that his hands look foreign to him during work and that conversations feel as though they are happening behind glass. He also describes heart palpitations and lightheadedness when the sensations intensify, leading to two emergency department visits where cardiac and neurological causes were excluded. He has no history of trauma and denies drug or alcohol use. Despite knowing these perceptions reflect a sense of unreality rather than actual physical danger, Tomás has become increasingly isolated and has requested a leave of absence from work.
questions.question: What is the most accurate DSM-5 diagnosis for Tomás's presentation?

options.A: Panic disorder
options.B: Illness anxiety disorder
options.C: Somatic symptom disorder
options.D: Depersonalization/derealization disorder

option_explanations.A: Panic disorder is a plausible distractor given Tomás's palpitations, lightheadedness, and emergency department visits. However, panic disorder requires recurrent unexpected panic attacks as the primary feature, with persistent concern about future attacks or significant behavioral change driven by that fear. Tomás's primary and continuous complaint is the strange detachment and unreality about his body and surroundings, not episodic panic.
option_explanations.B: Illness anxiety disorder involves preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious illness, with high health anxiety even in the absence of somatic symptoms. While Tomás visited the ED, his distress is rooted in the perceptual experiences of detachment and unreality, not in a belief or fear that he has a serious physical disease.
option_explanations.C: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by one or more distressing somatic symptoms accompanied by excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to those symptoms. Tomás's complaints are primarily perceptual and dissociative in nature rather than somatic, and his distress stems from the strangeness of his perceptions, not disproportionate preoccupation with physical symptoms.
option_explanations.D: Depersonalization/derealization disorder is correct. Tomás experiences persistent unreality — his hands feel foreign (depersonalization) and the world feels as though it is behind glass (derealization) — with intact reality testing, no substance or medical etiology, and significant functional impairment over six months, satisfying all DSM-5 criteria for this diagnosis.

questions.vignette: Priya, a 31-year-old attorney, presents after reluctantly seeking help for what she describes as 'not feeling like herself' for the better part of a year. She explains that during stressful court proceedings she sometimes feels like a passive observer watching a competent stranger argue cases — yet she performs flawlessly and colleagues notice nothing unusual. She reports persistent lightheadedness and has twice left court recesses believing she was about to faint, prompting cardiology and neurology consultations that found no abnormalities. She denies any discrete period of amnesia, any history of trauma, and any substance use. Her primary care physician initially suspected a conversion reaction given the physical complaints, but Priya insists her greater distress is the eerie sense that the person in the courtroom is not quite her.
questions.question: Which diagnosis most precisely accounts for Priya's full symptom picture?

options.A: Functional neurological symptom disorder (conversion disorder)
options.B: Depersonalization/derealization disorder
options.C: Dissociative identity disorder
options.D: Persistent depressive disorder with anxious distress

option_explanations.A: Functional neurological symptom disorder (conversion disorder) involves one or more symptoms of altered voluntary motor or sensory function that are incompatible on neurological examination and not better explained by another condition. Although Priya has physical complaints and a physician considered this diagnosis, her defining and most distressing symptom is a perceptual alteration in her sense of self — not a neurological deficit — and her physical workup showed no incompatibility signs.
option_explanations.B: Depersonalization/derealization disorder is correct. Priya experiences persistent, ego-dystonic detachment from her own identity (feeling like a passive observer of herself) with intact functioning and intact reality testing, no medical or substance cause, and significant distress — precisely the hallmarks of this disorder. The physical complaints are common associated features that prompted medical workups rather than alternative diagnoses.
option_explanations.C: Dissociative identity disorder requires two or more distinct personality states that recurrently take executive control of behavior, often with associated amnesia. Priya does not report amnesia, a shift to a different identity with its own characteristics, or any loss of control over her behavior; she remains functional and continuous in her sense of personal history.
option_explanations.D: Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) with anxious distress specifier involves chronic depressed mood lasting at least two years with associated anxiety features. Priya describes no depressed mood, anhedonia, or neurovegetative symptoms; her core complaint is a perceptual disturbance about the self, which is not accounted for by a mood disorder framework.
