questions.vignette: A child psychologist is consulting on the case of a 6-year-old boy recently removed from his biological home and placed with a relative caregiver after a substantiated abuse report. The caregiver describes the child as argumentative, vindictive, and chronically non-compliant, behaviors that have persisted for at least seven months across home and school settings. A psychological evaluation confirms the child meets full diagnostic criteria for a disruptive behavior disorder. The consulting psychologist recommends against beginning individual play therapy with the child alone, arguing instead that the most efficacious approach is a dyadic, structured treatment in which the caregiver is coached live through an earpiece to alter the moment-to-moment quality of her interactions with the child. A trauma specialist on the team advocates instead for an intervention focused primarily on processing the child's trauma narrative.
questions.question: Which treatment is the consulting psychologist recommending?

options.A: Theraplay
options.B: Child-parent psychotherapy (CPP)
options.C: Parent-child interaction therapy (PCIT)
options.D: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)

option_explanations.A: Theraplay is a structured, dyadic, attachment-based play therapy that involves the therapist playing an active role in sessions with the caregiver and child. While it is dyadic and targets the caregiver–child relationship, it does not use live coaching via earpiece as its primary mechanism and is not specifically validated as a treatment-of-choice for ODD with maltreatment histories in the way PCIT is.
option_explanations.B: Child-parent psychotherapy is an attachment- and trauma-informed, dyadic intervention delivered jointly with caregiver and child, making it a highly plausible choice given the abuse history and relational focus. However, CPP does not use the live earpiece coaching of caregiver behavior in real time that the vignette specifically emphasizes, and its primary target is traumatic stress rather than ODD-specific disruptive behavior.
option_explanations.C: PCIT is uniquely characterized by the use of a bug-in-the-ear device through which the therapist coaches the caregiver in real time during observed play sessions—the specific mechanism described in the vignette. It is the validated treatment for young children with ODD and maltreatment histories, directly fitting the psychologist's recommendation against individual child therapy in favor of this structured dyadic coaching model.
option_explanations.D: TF-CBT is advocated by the trauma specialist in the vignette, making it a deliberate red herring. While TF-CBT does include a caregiver component, it is not dyadic in the sense of joint live-coached sessions, and its primary mechanism is cognitive-behavioral processing of trauma narratives rather than real-time reshaping of caregiver interaction patterns—a poor fit for the specific model the consulting psychologist describes.

questions.vignette: A treatment team is reviewing the case of a 6-year-old boy who was removed from his home after authorities confirmed that adults responsible for his care had repeatedly hurt him physically. The child has been placed with a relative who is motivated to help but overwhelmed by his persistent refusal to follow instructions, frequent angry outbursts, and occasional spiteful behavior toward younger children in the home—patterns present for at least eight months. One team member proposes beginning weekly individual sessions with the child focused on helping him talk through and make sense of the frightening things that happened to him. A second team member counters that, given the child's young age and the family context, a structured program in which the new caregiver is guided in real time by a professional watching from behind a one-way mirror would produce faster and more durable change in both the child's behavior and the quality of the new relationship.
questions.question: Which established treatment program is the second team member describing?

options.A: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
options.B: Child-parent psychotherapy (CPP)
options.C: Parent-child interaction therapy (PCIT)
options.D: Incredible Years Therapeutic Dinosaur School program

option_explanations.A: TF-CBT is designed to help children process traumatic events through structured cognitive and behavioral techniques and includes parallel sessions for caregivers—making it a plausible choice given the abuse history and the first team member's proposal. However, TF-CBT does not use live observation with real-time caregiver coaching behind a one-way mirror as its defining mechanism; its structure is primarily individual and psychoeducational rather than dyadic and moment-to-moment behavioral.
option_explanations.B: CPP is an attachment- and trauma-informed intervention delivered jointly with the caregiver and child, and it directly targets the relational disruption caused by maltreatment—features that fit the vignette's relational framing and abuse context well. However, CPP's core mechanism is not live coaching through a one-way mirror observation system; it relies on in-session reflective and interpretive techniques rather than real-time behavioral instruction to the caregiver.
option_explanations.C: PCIT is the treatment precisely described: a structured intervention for young children with disruptive behavior problems and maltreatment histories in which a therapist observes the caregiver–child dyad from behind a one-way mirror and coaches the caregiver in real time via an earpiece. This live coaching mechanism, combined with its evidence base for both ODD and physically abusive family contexts, makes PCIT the uniquely correct answer despite the vignette's emphasis on the trauma history as a red herring.
option_explanations.D: The Incredible Years Therapeutic Dinosaur School is a child group-based component of the Incredible Years program, designed to teach social skills and emotional regulation to young children with disruptive behavior. While it targets a similar population, it is a group child intervention rather than a dyadic caregiver–child coaching program, and it does not involve real-time observation and live caregiver coaching behind a one-way mirror.

questions.source_summary: Among respondents with major depressive disorder in the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions III, the largest percentage reported having had alcohol use disorder during their lifetimes.
questions.vignette: A researcher presents findings from the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions III (NESARC-III) at a grand rounds lecture on comorbidity in mood disorders. She reports that among individuals diagnosed with major depressive disorder, a substantial proportion also carried a lifetime diagnosis of a substance-related condition. When the audience asks which substance use disorder showed the highest lifetime comorbidity rate with major depressive disorder in that sample, the researcher refers to her data table. The pattern she describes reflects a well-documented co-occurrence that has been replicated across large epidemiological studies.
questions.question: Based on NESARC-III data, which lifetime co-occurring disorder was most prevalent among individuals with major depressive disorder?

options.A: Cannabis use disorder
options.B: Alcohol use disorder
options.C: Opioid use disorder
options.D: Stimulant use disorder

option_explanations.A: Cannabis use disorder does co-occur with major depressive disorder at meaningful rates, and cannabis is among the most widely used substances, making this a plausible distractor. However, NESARC-III data show that lifetime alcohol use disorder — not cannabis use disorder — was the most prevalent comorbid substance use disorder among those with MDD.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. NESARC-III data demonstrate that alcohol use disorder had the highest lifetime prevalence among individuals with major depressive disorder compared to other substance use disorders, reflecting alcohol's status as the most commonly misused substance and its well-established neurobiological and psychological links to depression.
option_explanations.C: Opioid use disorder is an important comorbidity with major depressive disorder, particularly given the opioid epidemic, and opioids are known to dysregulate mood-related neural circuits. However, opioid use disorder has lower overall population prevalence than alcohol use disorder, and NESARC-III data do not identify it as the most prevalent lifetime comorbidity with MDD.
option_explanations.D: Stimulant use disorder (including cocaine and amphetamines) can co-occur with depressive episodes, especially in withdrawal phases when stimulant-induced mood crashes resemble depressive symptoms. Nevertheless, stimulant use disorder has substantially lower lifetime prevalence in the general population compared to alcohol use disorder, making it a less common comorbidity with MDD in epidemiological surveys.

questions.vignette: A 42-year-old man is referred for a psychiatric evaluation after his primary care physician noted he had been treated for recurrent depressive episodes over the past decade. During the intake interview, he mentions that he has also had periods of heavy drinking that he now recognizes caused significant occupational and relationship problems. He smokes approximately half a pack of cigarettes daily and acknowledges occasional marijuana use on weekends. A resident reviewing his chart wonders which substance-related condition, if any, would statistically be the most commonly reported lifetime comorbidity among people with his primary diagnosis according to large national survey data.
questions.question: According to NESARC-III findings, which substance use disorder carries the highest lifetime comorbidity rate among individuals diagnosed with major depressive disorder?

options.A: Tobacco use disorder
options.B: Cannabis use disorder
options.C: Alcohol use disorder
options.D: Sedative use disorder

option_explanations.A: Tobacco use disorder is highly prevalent in the general population and is frequently comorbid with mood disorders, making it a tempting choice given this patient's smoking history. However, NESARC-III specifically identified alcohol use disorder — not tobacco use disorder — as the most prevalent lifetime substance use comorbidity among individuals with MDD, and tobacco is often analyzed separately from other substance use disorders in these studies.
option_explanations.B: The patient's weekend marijuana use introduces cannabis as a plausible answer, and cannabis use disorder does co-occur with MDD at meaningful rates. However, cannabis use disorder's overall lifetime prevalence is lower than that of alcohol use disorder in the general population, and NESARC-III data indicate alcohol use disorder is the more prevalent lifetime comorbidity with MDD.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. Despite the clinical details about tobacco and cannabis use in the vignette, NESARC-III data consistently show that alcohol use disorder represents the highest lifetime comorbidity rate among individuals with major depressive disorder. The patient's heavy drinking history is clinically consistent with this epidemiological finding.
option_explanations.D: Sedative use disorder (including benzodiazepines) can develop in individuals with mood disorders who are prescribed or self-medicate with sedatives for anxiety and sleep symptoms that often accompany depression. However, sedative use disorder has substantially lower lifetime prevalence in the general population than alcohol use disorder and is not identified as the top comorbidity with MDD in NESARC-III data.

questions.source_summary: Among respondents with major depressive disorder in the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions III, the largest percentage reported having had alcohol use disorder during their lifetimes.
questions.vignette: A clinical psychologist is reviewing an epidemiological study examining lifetime psychiatric comorbidities across different mood disorder diagnoses. The study reports that among individuals meeting criteria for a persistent, recurrent low mood condition accompanied by neurovegetative symptoms, one category of co-occurring substance-related condition stood out as markedly more common than all others across the entire national sample. Notably, the sample included a high proportion of individuals who also reported anxiety disorders, and several clinicians initially suspected that a sedative or anxiolytic-related substance diagnosis might emerge as the most frequent comorbidity given the anxiety overlap. However, the data told a different story, pointing instead to a substance whose social acceptability and legal status may contribute to its underrecognized relationship with mood disorders.
questions.question: In the epidemiological study described, which substance use disorder most likely emerged as the highest lifetime comorbidity among individuals with the described mood condition?

options.A: Sedative, hypnotic, or anxiolytic use disorder
options.B: Alcohol use disorder
options.C: Cannabis use disorder
options.D: Opioid use disorder

option_explanations.A: The vignette deliberately introduces a red herring by noting high anxiety comorbidity and the clinical suspicion that sedative use might be the top finding — making this a highly tempting distractor. Sedative, hypnotic, or anxiolytic use disorder does occur in mood disorder populations, partly because individuals self-medicate anxiety and insomnia. However, NESARC-III data identify alcohol use disorder, not sedative use disorder, as the most prevalent lifetime comorbidity among those with MDD.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The vignette's clue about a legally available, socially accepted substance with an underrecognized relationship to mood disorders points to alcohol. NESARC-III data show that alcohol use disorder has the highest lifetime comorbidity rate among individuals with major depressive disorder, even when anxiety disorders are prevalent in the same sample and might suggest sedative misuse.
option_explanations.C: Cannabis use disorder's increasing social acceptance and the growing recognition of its relationship to mood disorders make it a plausible answer, and the vignette's reference to social acceptability could be read as pointing toward cannabis. However, cannabis use disorder still has lower lifetime prevalence than alcohol use disorder in national epidemiological data, and it was not identified as the top substance comorbidity with MDD in NESARC-III.
option_explanations.D: Opioid use disorder has a well-established bidirectional relationship with depression, as chronic pain (often treated with opioids) is strongly linked to depressive episodes, and opioid withdrawal itself produces depressive symptomatology. Despite this, opioid use disorder has lower general population prevalence than alcohol use disorder, and NESARC-III data do not identify it as the most prevalent lifetime comorbidity with MDD.

questions.source_summary: Among respondents with major depressive disorder in the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions III, the largest percentage reported having had alcohol use disorder during their lifetimes.
questions.vignette: A researcher presents data from a large national household survey examining lifetime co-occurring conditions in adults meeting criteria for a mood syndrome characterized by persistent neurovegetative disruptions — including sleep architecture changes, appetite dysregulation, and psychomotor alterations — without any history of manic or hypomanic episodes. Counterintuitively, the data show that a substance whose consumption is often framed in social and cultural terms, rather than pathological ones, accounted for the largest share of lifetime co-occurring substance-related diagnoses in this group. The researcher notes that many clinicians underestimate this pairing because the substance is commonly used in the general population, leading to normalization even in clinical contexts. A senior consultant listening to the presentation remarks that these findings should shift how intake assessments are structured for patients presenting with the mood syndrome described.
questions.question: Based on the research findings described, which substance use disorder most likely represented the highest lifetime comorbidity rate among participants with the mood syndrome?

options.A: Cannabis use disorder
options.B: Opioid use disorder
options.C: Stimulant use disorder
options.D: Alcohol use disorder

option_explanations.A: The vignette's emphasis on social normalization and cultural framing of the substance could point toward cannabis, whose increasing legalization and social acceptance mirror that description. Cannabis use disorder is a real comorbidity with MDD, and the cultural normalization of cannabis could lead to underrecognition in clinical settings. However, NESARC-III data show alcohol use disorder — not cannabis use disorder — as the highest lifetime comorbidity with MDD, and alcohol's deeper cultural embeddedness more precisely fits the vignette's description.
option_explanations.B: Opioid use disorder is strongly linked to mood disorders, particularly because chronic pain (a neurovegetative-adjacent complaint) is both a risk factor for and consequence of depression. The vignette's focus on normalization in clinical contexts could also apply to prescription opioid misuse, which was often undertreated as a clinical problem for years. However, opioid use disorder's prevalence in the general population is substantially lower than alcohol use disorder, and it does not represent the highest lifetime comorbidity with MDD in NESARC-III data.
option_explanations.C: Stimulant use disorder shares a complex relationship with mood, as stimulants can temporarily alleviate depressive symptoms (leading to self-medication) before worsening them during withdrawal. The reference to psychomotor changes could superficially point toward stimulant effects. However, stimulant use disorder has considerably lower general population prevalence than alcohol use disorder and is not identified as the top comorbidity in NESARC-III findings.
option_explanations.D: This is correct. The phrase 'substance whose consumption is often framed in social and cultural terms rather than pathological ones' is a subtle but precise description of alcohol, which enjoys deep cultural normalization in most societies. The mood syndrome described — persistent neurovegetative disruptions without manic or hypomanic episodes — corresponds to major depressive disorder. NESARC-III data confirm that alcohol use disorder has the highest lifetime comorbidity rate among individuals with MDD, and the consultant's remark about restructuring intake assessments aligns with clinical recommendations to routinely screen for alcohol misuse in depressed patients.

questions.source_summary: Among respondents with major depressive disorder in the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions III, the largest percentage reported having had alcohol use disorder during their lifetimes.
questions.vignette: A public health team analyzing a nationally representative household interview dataset notices a striking pattern: among the subset of adults who reported experiencing extended periods of low energy, disrupted sleep, reduced interest in previously enjoyed activities, and feelings of worthlessness severe enough to impair daily functioning — but who had never experienced a week-long period of unusually elevated or expansive mood — the single most common additional lifetime condition involved a substance that is legally purchased in grocery stores, frequently given as gifts at celebrations, and rarely discussed in terms of dependency in primary care settings. The team also notes that this pairing was more prevalent than co-occurrence with any anxiety-related condition, despite the fact that the mood group had very high rates of what the team called 'worry-based presentations.' A consultant reviewing the findings initially assumed a sedating substance category would top the list given the sleep disruption and anxiety overlap, but the data did not support that assumption.
questions.question: Based on the pattern described in the dataset, which co-occurring lifetime condition most likely had the highest prevalence rate within this mood-affected subgroup?

options.A: A problematic pattern of use involving a prescribed sedating agent used to manage persistent worry and sleep disruption
options.B: A problematic pattern of use involving a fermented or distilled substance widely available in retail and social settings
options.C: A problematic pattern of use involving a plant-derived substance whose social acceptance has increased substantially in recent years
options.D: A problematic pattern of use involving a stimulating substance often consumed to counteract low energy and fatigue

option_explanations.A: This option is the primary red herring in the vignette. The detailed description of sleep disruption, worry-based presentations, and the consultant's initial assumption about sedating substances are all deliberately designed to make this option feel most plausible. Sedative, hypnotic, or anxiolytic use disorder does occur in populations with mood and anxiety comorbidities. However, NESARC-III data clearly show that alcohol use disorder — not sedative use disorder — is the most prevalent lifetime comorbidity among individuals with major depressive disorder, even in samples with high anxiety comorbidity.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The description of a substance 'legally purchased in grocery stores, frequently given as gifts at celebrations, and rarely discussed in terms of dependency in primary care settings' precisely and exclusively describes alcohol. The mood subgroup described — extended low energy, disrupted sleep, reduced interest, worthlessness, functional impairment, without elevated mood — corresponds to major depressive disorder. NESARC-III data confirm that alcohol use disorder is the most prevalent lifetime co-occurring substance use disorder in this population, consistent with alcohol's widespread availability and underrecognized clinical impact.
option_explanations.C: The reference to increasing social acceptance in the vignette is a secondary red herring designed to evoke cannabis, and a cannabis-related problematic use pattern does co-occur with the mood presentation described. Cannabis use disorder's growing normalization in legal and social contexts mirrors the vignette's language about a substance 'rarely discussed in terms of dependency.' However, NESARC-III data do not support cannabis use disorder as the top lifetime comorbidity with MDD — alcohol use disorder holds that position — and grocery store availability more precisely identifies alcohol.
option_explanations.D: The explicit mention of low energy and fatigue as features of the mood group creates a secondary red herring pointing toward stimulant use as a potential self-medication strategy. Stimulant use disorder (e.g., caffeine aside, cocaine or amphetamine misuse) can develop when individuals attempt to counteract depressive fatigue, and this self-medication pathway is clinically documented. However, stimulant use disorder has substantially lower lifetime prevalence in the general population than alcohol use disorder, and NESARC-III data do not support it as the highest comorbidity with major depressive disorder.

questions.source_summary: Family-based treatment for adolescents with anorexia nervosa takes an agnostic view of the disorder, consisting of three phases: parental control of the adolescent's eating, gradual return of control to the adolescent, and establishing age-appropriate independence in the adolescent.
questions.vignette: A 15-year-old girl is diagnosed with anorexia nervosa after losing 20% of her body weight over six months. Her treatment team recommends family-based treatment (FBT), explaining that her parents will initially take full parental control over all of her meals and snacks. The therapist emphasizes that FBT takes an agnostic view of the disorder, meaning the family is not blamed for causing the illness. Over subsequent phases, control over eating will gradually be returned to the adolescent, eventually leading to age-appropriate independence.
questions.question: The treatment approach described in this vignette is best characterized by which of the following sequences of phases?

options.A: Psychoeducation about nutrition, individual cognitive restructuring, and relapse prevention planning
options.B: Parental control of eating, gradual return of control to the adolescent, and establishment of age-appropriate independence
options.C: Medical stabilization, residential intensive treatment, and step-down outpatient therapy
options.D: Motivational enhancement, behavioral contracting, and maintenance of healthy weight

option_explanations.A: This sequence describes components of individual cognitive-behavioral therapy for eating disorders, not FBT. FBT does not begin with individual psychoeducation or cognitive restructuring; it externalizes the illness and places parents in charge of refeeding in Phase 1.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. Family-based treatment (the Maudsley approach) for adolescent anorexia nervosa proceeds through exactly these three phases: Phase 1 (parents control eating), Phase 2 (gradual return of control to the adolescent), and Phase 3 (establishing age-appropriate autonomy and independence).
option_explanations.C: This sequence describes a stepped-care medical model rather than a structured outpatient psychotherapy. FBT is typically delivered in an outpatient setting and does not inherently include residential treatment as a formal phase.
option_explanations.D: Motivational enhancement therapy (MET) and behavioral contracting are used in other eating disorder treatments and substance use interventions. While FBT may incorporate some motivational elements, its defining structure is the three phases involving parental control and graduated autonomy, not MET or contracting.

questions.source_summary: Family-based treatment for adolescents with anorexia nervosa takes an agnostic view of the disorder, consisting of three phases: parental control of the adolescent's eating, gradual return of control to the adolescent, and establishing age-appropriate independence in the adolescent.
questions.vignette: A therapist is presenting a treatment model to the family of a 14-year-old boy who has been losing weight rapidly and refusing meals, expressing intense fear of gaining weight. The therapist tells the parents that this approach takes an agnostic stance toward the causes of the illness, intentionally avoiding blame of the parents or the adolescent. The parents are instructed to take over all feeding decisions initially, which creates some tension as the boy insists he is capable of managing his own eating. The therapist notes that this initial discomfort is expected and that responsibility will be transferred back to the adolescent as he demonstrates weight restoration.
questions.question: Which evidence-based treatment model is most consistent with the approach described in this vignette?

options.A: Dialectical behavior therapy adapted for eating disorders
options.B: Cognitive-behavioral therapy for eating disorders (CBT-E)
options.C: Family-based treatment (Maudsley approach) for anorexia nervosa
options.D: Multifamily therapy groups for eating disorders

option_explanations.A: DBT adapted for eating disorders focuses on emotion regulation, distress tolerance, and mindfulness in the individual patient. While it can involve family skills training, it does not structure treatment around phased parental control of feeding and a non-blaming agnostic stance as its organizing framework.
option_explanations.B: CBT-E is an individual therapy that targets the cognitive maintaining factors of eating disorders (e.g., overvaluation of shape and weight). Although effective, it does not delegate feeding authority to parents or use an agnostic model; it works directly with the patient's cognitions and behaviors.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. Family-based treatment (FBT), also called the Maudsley approach, is defined by its agnostic stance toward etiology, non-blaming orientation toward the family, and its three phases beginning with full parental control over the adolescent's eating, followed by gradual return of autonomy, and finally establishing independence.
option_explanations.D: Multifamily therapy groups involve multiple families meeting together for psychoeducation and support and share FBT's systemic orientation. However, the structured three-phase model with parental takeover of feeding and an explicitly agnostic stance is specific to individual FBT, not the multifamily group format.

questions.source_summary: Family-based treatment for adolescents with anorexia nervosa takes an agnostic view of the disorder, consisting of three phases: parental control of the adolescent's eating, gradual return of control to the adolescent, and establishing age-appropriate independence in the adolescent.
questions.vignette: A clinical supervisor is reviewing a case involving a 16-year-old girl with a restrictive eating pattern, significant weight loss, and amenorrhea. The treating clinician has structured the intervention in distinct phases, starting by coaching the parents to take charge of all food-related decisions while explicitly telling them they did not cause their daughter's illness. The clinician has also noted the girl shows signs of depression and social withdrawal, which some team members argue should be the primary treatment focus. However, the supervisor emphasizes that the phased structure — prioritizing nutritional rehabilitation under parental oversight before addressing individual psychological concerns — is the defining feature of the chosen model.
questions.question: The supervisor's emphasis on the phased structure beginning with parental oversight of eating most strongly indicates that the treatment model being used is which of the following?

options.A: Structural family therapy adapted for eating disorders
options.B: Family-based treatment (Maudsley approach) for anorexia nervosa
options.C: Adolescent-focused individual therapy for anorexia nervosa
options.D: Integrative cognitive-affective therapy for eating disorders

option_explanations.A: Structural family therapy addresses dysfunctional family organization (e.g., enmeshment, disengagement, triangulation) and may involve parents in treatment. However, it does not organize treatment into the specific three phases involving parental control of feeding followed by graduated autonomy transfer; its focus is on restructuring family patterns rather than a phased refeeding model.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The defining hallmark of FBT (Maudsley approach) is its three-phase structure beginning with parents taking full control of the adolescent's eating, followed by gradual return of control to the adolescent, and finally establishing independence. The explicit non-blaming, agnostic stance and the prioritization of weight restoration over psychological exploration further confirm this model.
option_explanations.C: Adolescent-focused individual therapy (AFT) for anorexia nervosa is an individual treatment that addresses the adolescent's developmental and psychological needs directly, without delegating feeding control to parents. It does not follow the phased parental-control model described in the vignette.
option_explanations.D: Integrative cognitive-affective therapy (ICAT) for eating disorders targets emotion regulation and cognitive factors in individual sessions. It does not involve structured phases of parental feeding control or an explicitly agnostic stance toward etiology, and it is not specifically designed around family involvement in the way FBT is.

questions.source_summary: Family-based treatment for adolescents with anorexia nervosa takes an agnostic view of the disorder, consisting of three phases: parental control of the adolescent's eating, gradual return of control to the adolescent, and establishing age-appropriate independence in the adolescent.
questions.vignette: A 15-year-old is referred for treatment after her pediatrician documents severe underweight and cardiac irregularities secondary to severely restricted intake. Her parents report feeling guilty, believing they must have done something wrong to cause this. The therapist reassures them that the treatment model explicitly does not assign fault and works with the family as a resource rather than a cause. Early sessions focus entirely on the parents assuming executive authority over what and how much their daughter eats, while the daughter's protests and arguments about autonomy are acknowledged but temporarily set aside. The therapist notes that the degree to which individual autonomy is eventually restored will be titrated based on demonstrated progress.
questions.question: The therapist's approach of temporarily overriding the adolescent's autonomy while reassuring parents they are not at fault, with planned reinstatement of independence contingent on progress, is most precisely consistent with which treatment model?

options.A: Parent management training applied to feeding refusal in adolescents
options.B: Systemic family therapy with a collaborative, non-hierarchical stance
options.C: Family-based treatment (Maudsley approach) for adolescent anorexia nervosa
options.D: Behavioral family systems therapy for adolescent anorexia nervosa

option_explanations.A: Parent management training (PMT) focuses on teaching parents to use behavioral contingencies to modify oppositional or disruptive child behavior. While it does involve parental authority, PMT is not structured around an agnostic etiology stance, three formalized phases, or graduated return of eating autonomy tied to weight restoration progress in an eating disorder context.
option_explanations.B: Systemic family therapy typically maintains a non-hierarchical, collaborative stance that avoids placing parents in a directive authority role over the identified patient. This contrasts with FBT's Phase 1, which explicitly increases parental hierarchy and control over feeding — making systemic family therapy a poor fit for the described approach.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. FBT is uniquely defined by its agnostic, non-blaming stance toward the family, its temporary elevation of parental authority over the adolescent's eating in Phase 1, and its explicit plan to restore adolescent autonomy in graduated phases tied to weight restoration progress. No other family therapy for eating disorders combines all three elements in this structured sequence.
option_explanations.D: Behavioral family systems therapy (BFST) for adolescent anorexia nervosa also involves family members and addresses both behavioral and systemic factors. However, BFST does not emphasize the same non-blaming agnostic stance or the structured phased transfer of eating control back to the adolescent as its central organizing framework, making FBT the more precise match.

questions.source_summary: Family-based treatment for adolescents with anorexia nervosa takes an agnostic view of the disorder, consisting of three phases: parental control of the adolescent's eating, gradual return of control to the adolescent, and establishing age-appropriate independence in the adolescent.
questions.vignette: A therapist working with a teenage girl and her family describes a treatment plan in which the parents will, for a defined period of time, make all decisions about what the girl eats and ensure she consumes every meal — despite her strong objections. The therapist explicitly tells the parents that their previous parenting decisions did not create this problem, and that the goal is to get the girl's body to a healthy state before addressing any underlying thoughts or feelings she may have. The parents are warned the girl may resist, argue, and become very upset, but that this is expected and they should not yield. Over time, the therapist explains, the girl will gradually be given more say over her meals, and eventually the focus of sessions will shift toward helping her develop the skills she needs to function as an independent young adult.
questions.question: The structured treatment approach described in this vignette — with its specific sequence of parental authority, gradual transfer of responsibility, and developmental focus — is most precisely consistent with which of the following?

options.A: Contingency management applied within a family context to address food refusal in adolescence
options.B: Structural family therapy targeting enmeshment and cross-generational coalitions around food
options.C: Family-based treatment (Maudsley approach) for adolescent anorexia nervosa
options.D: Behavioral family systems therapy combining problem-solving communication training with refeeding

option_explanations.A: Contingency management uses reinforcement schedules to shape target behaviors and could superficially resemble the described approach in that parents enforce eating. However, it does not include an agnostic, non-blaming framing, does not follow three defined phases with a developmental endpoint focused on adolescent independence, and is not specifically structured for anorexia nervosa in the way described.
option_explanations.B: Structural family therapy would address the family's organizational patterns (e.g., boundaries, hierarchies, coalitions) and might involve shifting parental roles. However, it explicitly avoids placing parents in a directive feeding-authority role, focuses on family structure rather than weight restoration phases, and does not include an explicit developmental phase aimed at establishing the adolescent's independence as the terminal goal.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. The precise three-phase sequence — parents temporarily take full control of eating (Phase 1), responsibility is gradually returned to the adolescent as health improves (Phase 2), and sessions shift to establishing age-appropriate independence (Phase 3) — combined with the explicit non-blaming agnostic stance uniquely identifies FBT (Maudsley approach) for adolescent anorexia nervosa. No other treatment matches all these elements simultaneously.
option_explanations.D: Behavioral family systems therapy (BFST) for adolescent anorexia nervosa integrates behavioral refeeding with family systems communication training and problem-solving. It shares features with FBT including family involvement and focus on weight restoration, but its organizing framework centers on improving family communication and problem-solving rather than the three-phase structure of graduated transfer of eating authority with an explicit agnostic etiology stance.

questions.source_summary: Research has linked ADHD to smaller-than-normal caudate nucleus, putamen, and amygdala.
questions.vignette: A neuropsychologist presents grand rounds findings showing that children diagnosed with ADHD consistently display reduced volume in the caudate nucleus compared to age-matched controls. She explains that this subcortical structure plays a central role in motor control and the inhibition of automatic responses, and its reduction correlates with the pervasive inattention and impulsivity seen in affected children. She also notes that the putamen and amygdala are similarly smaller in these individuals. The research team concludes that these structural differences partly explain why behavioral inhibition is so difficult for children with this neurodevelopmental disorder.
questions.question: Which neuroimaging finding most specifically supports the neurobiological basis of ADHD as described in this research presentation?

options.A: Enlarged hippocampal volume bilaterally
options.B: Reduced volume of the caudate nucleus, putamen, and amygdala
options.C: Hyperactivity in the prefrontal cortex on fMRI during rest
options.D: Thinning of the corpus callosum and reduced interhemispheric transfer

option_explanations.A: Enlarged hippocampal volume is not a finding associated with ADHD; instead, hippocampal changes are more commonly linked to mood and anxiety disorders, as well as PTSD. This option does not fit the structural pattern described in the vignette.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. Research has consistently documented smaller-than-normal caudate nucleus, putamen, and amygdala in individuals with ADHD. These basal ganglia and limbic structures are involved in response inhibition, reward processing, and emotional regulation — all domains impaired in ADHD.
option_explanations.C: While prefrontal cortex dysfunction is implicated in ADHD (particularly in executive function deficits), hyperactivity at rest in the PFC is not the specific structural finding highlighted in ADHD neuroimaging research. The vignette specifically discusses volumetric (structural) reductions, not functional activation patterns.
option_explanations.D: Corpus callosum thinning has been studied in ADHD and some neurodevelopmental conditions, but it is not the primary or most replicated structural finding in ADHD research. The vignette specifically identifies the caudate, putamen, and amygdala as the key structures of interest.

questions.source_summary: Research has linked ADHD to smaller-than-normal caudate nucleus, putamen, and amygdala.
questions.vignette: A 9-year-old boy is referred for a neuropsychological evaluation after years of difficulty sustaining attention in school, frequent interrupting, and an inability to wait his turn during structured activities. His teacher notes that he is kind and well-liked but seems to 'run on a motor.' Although his parents mention that he had some speech delays in preschool, those resolved by age 5 with no current language concerns. Neuroimaging obtained as part of a research study reveals bilaterally reduced volume in basal ganglia structures compared to age-matched peers, consistent with findings in his neurodevelopmental diagnosis.
questions.question: Which neurodevelopmental disorder is most consistent with the behavioral presentation and neuroimaging findings described?

options.A: Autism Spectrum Disorder
options.B: Tourette's Disorder
options.C: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder
options.D: Intellectual Disability

option_explanations.A: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental condition that can involve basal ganglia abnormalities, but the core features include persistent deficits in social communication and restricted, repetitive behaviors — not the primarily inattentive and hyperactive/impulsive profile described. The child's social warmth and the absence of rigid behaviors argue against ASD.
option_explanations.B: Tourette's Disorder also involves basal ganglia dysfunction and can co-occur with ADHD, making it a plausible distractor. However, Tourette's requires the presence of multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic persisting for over a year — no tics are mentioned in this vignette. The primary presentation here is inattention and hyperactivity/impulsivity.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. ADHD is characterized by pervasive inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity and is classified as a neurodevelopmental disorder in DSM-5. Neuroimaging research has specifically linked ADHD to reduced volume in the caudate nucleus and putamen — key basal ganglia structures — consistent with the findings described.
option_explanations.D: Intellectual Disability involves significant limitations in intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior, not primarily inattention or motor hyperactivity. There is no mention of below-average intellectual functioning or adaptive skill deficits in this vignette, making this diagnosis inconsistent with the presentation.

questions.source_summary: Research has linked ADHD to smaller-than-normal caudate nucleus, putamen, and amygdala.
questions.vignette: A researcher studying pediatric brain development publishes data showing that children who struggle profoundly with behavioral inhibition, impulsivity, and emotional dysregulation demonstrate significantly smaller amygdala volumes compared to typically developing controls. Intriguingly, many of these children were initially referred due to explosive outbursts and mood lability, leading some clinicians to consider an early-onset mood disorder. However, the longitudinal behavioral data reveal that the difficulties are pervasive across home, school, and social settings — present well before age 7 — and are not confined to discrete mood episodes. Volumetric reductions in the caudate and putamen are also documented in the same sample.
questions.question: Which disorder most accurately explains the combination of neuroimaging findings and the clinical profile described in this research sample?

options.A: Pediatric Bipolar I Disorder
options.B: Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder
options.C: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder
options.D: Oppositional Defiant Disorder with callous-unemotional traits

option_explanations.A: Pediatric Bipolar I Disorder involves discrete episodes of mania and depression and is a strong distractor here given the mood lability and explosive outbursts described. However, the vignette explicitly states that difficulties are pervasive and not confined to discrete mood episodes — a key differentiator. Additionally, Bipolar I is not associated with the specific caudate/putamen/amygdala volumetric reductions linked to ADHD.
option_explanations.B: Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder (DMDD) is characterized by chronic irritability and severe temper outbursts, and it shares surface features with this vignette. However, DMDD is not associated with the specific pattern of caudate, putamen, and amygdala volumetric reduction that characterizes ADHD, and the vignette emphasizes behavioral inhibition deficits and impulsivity rather than chronic irritability as the primary feature.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. ADHD is associated with reduced volume in the caudate nucleus, putamen, and amygdala, precisely the structures implicated in this research. The pervasive, cross-situational nature of the deficits beginning before age 7, along with the behavioral inhibition and impulsivity profile, strongly support ADHD. The emotional dysregulation is consistent with ADHD's amygdala-related features rather than a primary mood disorder.
option_explanations.D: Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD) with callous-unemotional (CU) traits involves persistent defiance, irritability, and reduced empathy. While ODD frequently co-occurs with ADHD, CU traits are more closely linked to reduced amygdala reactivity associated with conduct disorder and psychopathy spectra — not the volumetric reductions across caudate, putamen, and amygdala that define ADHD's neurobiological signature.

questions.source_summary: Research has linked ADHD to smaller-than-normal caudate nucleus, putamen, and amygdala.
questions.vignette: A developmental neuroscientist presents findings from a longitudinal MRI study of children followed from age 6 to 16. She reports that children in the 'high behavioral concern' group — characterized primarily by difficulty regulating reward-seeking behavior, poor response inhibition, and heightened emotional reactivity to perceived failures — showed persistently reduced gray matter in the striatum and a limbic structure involved in threat and reward appraisal. At baseline, many clinicians had attributed the children's profiles to chronic exposure to chaotic home environments, and several had received mood-related diagnoses. Yet the volumetric reductions remained stable and were not correlated with trauma exposure scores, suggesting a neurodevelopmental rather than environmentally driven etiology.
questions.question: The neuroimaging pattern and clinical trajectory described in this study are most consistent with the neurobiology of which condition?

options.A: Reactive Attachment Disorder
options.B: Pediatric Posttraumatic Stress Disorder
options.C: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder
options.D: Conduct Disorder with childhood onset

option_explanations.A: Reactive Attachment Disorder (RAD) involves severely disturbed social relatedness stemming from pathological caregiving and is associated with early trauma and neglect — features that may seem relevant given mention of chaotic home environments. However, RAD is not associated with volumetric reductions in striatal structures or the amygdala specifically, and its core features center on disturbed attachment behavior rather than reward dysregulation and inhibition deficits.
option_explanations.B: Pediatric PTSD is a strong distractor because it can involve amygdala hyperreactivity and structural changes, and the chaotic home environment detail is designed to suggest a trauma etiology. However, the vignette explicitly states that volumetric reductions were not correlated with trauma scores, ruling out a trauma-driven explanation. PTSD neuroimaging research more commonly links hippocampal reduction than caudate/putamen reductions.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. The striatum (comprising the caudate nucleus and putamen) and the amygdala — the 'limbic structure involved in threat and reward appraisal' — are precisely the structures documented as smaller in ADHD. The behavioral profile of poor response inhibition, reward dysregulation, and emotional reactivity is consistent with ADHD, and the independence of findings from trauma exposure confirms a neurodevelopmental origin.
option_explanations.D: Conduct Disorder with childhood onset involves persistent violation of societal norms and others' rights, and it shares some neurobiological overlap with ADHD (particularly striatal involvement). However, the primary behavioral profile described — response inhibition deficits and reward dysregulation without mention of rule-breaking or aggression toward others — and the specific striatal plus amygdala volumetric pattern align more precisely with ADHD than Conduct Disorder.

questions.source_summary: Research has linked ADHD to smaller-than-normal caudate nucleus, putamen, and amygdala.
questions.vignette: A pediatric research team scans 200 children ages 7–12 who share a common profile: their parents describe them as 'always needing stimulation,' prone to grabbing things before thinking, and easily frustrated when they cannot immediately obtain what they want. Teachers consistently report that these children seem to know classroom rules but cannot seem to apply the brakes on their behavior in the moment. Brain scans reveal that, on average, two interconnected regions involved in coordinating movement initiation and suppression are measurably smaller than in a matched control group, as is a third region located deeper in the temporal lobe known to assign emotional significance to incoming stimuli. The findings hold even after controlling for family stress, socioeconomic status, and IQ.
questions.question: The neuroimaging profile described — involving two motor-regulatory subcortical structures and one limbic structure — most specifically implicates the neurobiology of which condition?

options.A: Tourette's Disorder
options.B: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder
options.C: Childhood-onset Conduct Disorder
options.D: Autism Spectrum Disorder, Level 1

option_explanations.A: Tourette's Disorder involves dysfunction in cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical circuits, and volumetric differences in the caudate nucleus have been reported. It is a strong distractor because the 'two motor-regulatory subcortical structures' could initially suggest Tourette's. However, Tourette's primary hallmark is motor and vocal tics — not the reward-seeking, response inhibition, and frustration profile described — and the specific triad of caudate, putamen, and amygdala reductions is the established ADHD signature, not Tourette's.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The two interconnected regions involved in movement initiation and suppression are the caudate nucleus and putamen (basal ganglia/striatum), and the third region assigning emotional significance in the temporal lobe is the amygdala. This exact triad of volumetric reductions has been documented in ADHD research. The behavioral profile — inability to apply inhibitory control despite knowing rules, reward-seeking urgency, and frustration intolerance — is the classic ADHD phenotype, and the findings being independent of SES and IQ support a neurodevelopmental rather than environmental cause.
option_explanations.C: Childhood-onset Conduct Disorder is a compelling distractor because it involves poor behavioral inhibition, reward sensitivity, and frustration leading to rule-breaking. Some research documents striatal and amygdala differences in Conduct Disorder, particularly in youth with callous-unemotional traits. However, Conduct Disorder's defining feature is persistent aggression and norm violation — not the motor-level 'cannot apply the brakes' inhibitory failure — and its amygdala findings are typically characterized by reduced reactivity rather than reduced volume across the specific triad cited.
option_explanations.D: Autism Spectrum Disorder Level 1 involves social communication challenges and restricted/repetitive behaviors and can include sensory-seeking behavior that superficially resembles 'always needing stimulation.' However, ASD's neurobiological signature does not center on caudate-putamen-amygdala volume reductions as a triad; ASD research more prominently involves atypical amygdala development in social processing contexts rather than the motor regulatory and inhibitory circuitry described here.

questions.source_summary: Patients with coronary heart disease have a high rate of comorbid psychiatric disorders, with major depressive disorder having the highest prevalence rate.
questions.vignette: A cardiologist refers a 58-year-old man to a psychologist for a psychiatric evaluation after he was recently diagnosed with coronary heart disease. The patient reports persistent low mood, anhedonia, and fatigue lasting more than two weeks, consistent with a major depressive disorder presentation. The cardiologist notes in the referral that she screens all her coronary heart disease patients for psychiatric comorbidities. A researcher reviewing the literature asks the consulting psychologist which comorbid psychiatric disorder is most prevalent among patients with coronary heart disease.
questions.question: Which psychiatric disorder has the highest prevalence rate as a comorbidity among patients with coronary heart disease?

options.A: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
options.B: Major Depressive Disorder
options.C: Panic Disorder
options.D: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder

option_explanations.A: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) does occur at elevated rates in cardiac populations and shares features such as worry about health and somatic complaints, but research consistently identifies major depressive disorder, not GAD, as the most prevalent psychiatric comorbidity in coronary heart disease patients.
option_explanations.B: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) has the highest documented prevalence rate among psychiatric comorbidities in patients with coronary heart disease, affecting roughly 20% or more of this population. MDD also worsens cardiac prognosis, making its identification clinically critical.
option_explanations.C: Panic Disorder is relevant in cardiac populations partly because panic attacks can mimic cardiac events, leading to frequent medical contact. However, it does not have the highest prevalence rate as a psychiatric comorbidity among coronary heart disease patients compared to major depressive disorder.
option_explanations.D: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder can occur following a myocardial infarction or other acute cardiac events and is a meaningful comorbidity, but its prevalence in coronary heart disease patients is lower than that of major depressive disorder.

questions.source_summary: Patients with coronary heart disease have a high rate of comorbid psychiatric disorders, with major depressive disorder having the highest prevalence rate.
questions.vignette: A 63-year-old woman with a recent angioplasty for coronary heart disease is referred for psychological consultation. She describes episodic sadness, loss of interest in her garden, sleep disturbance, and difficulty concentrating, but also mentions that she has had past periods of elevated mood and increased energy lasting about four days each, during which she required little sleep. Her cardiologist notes that psychiatric comorbidities are common in this population and asks the consulting psychologist to identify which disorder is most frequently found alongside coronary heart disease.
questions.question: Considering the available epidemiological data, which psychiatric disorder carries the highest prevalence rate as a comorbidity in patients with coronary heart disease?

options.A: Bipolar II Disorder
options.B: Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)
options.C: Major Depressive Disorder
options.D: Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood

option_explanations.A: Bipolar II Disorder involves hypomanic and major depressive episodes and could be suggested by the patient's history of brief elevated-mood periods. However, when examining population-level prevalence data for psychiatric comorbidities in coronary heart disease, Bipolar II Disorder ranks lower than major depressive disorder overall.
option_explanations.B: Persistent Depressive Disorder involves chronic, low-grade depressive symptoms lasting at least two years and shares many features with MDD in cardiac patients. However, it does not have the highest prevalence rate among psychiatric comorbidities in coronary heart disease populations; MDD holds that distinction.
option_explanations.C: Major Depressive Disorder is the most prevalent psychiatric comorbidity in coronary heart disease patients. The patient's elevated-mood history is a clinical red herring for this question, which asks about population-level prevalence data rather than this individual's diagnosis. MDD remains the most common psychiatric disorder in this cardiac population.
option_explanations.D: Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood is a common clinical response to medical diagnoses and could plausibly apply early after a cardiac event, but it is a time-limited, situational diagnosis and does not represent the highest prevalence psychiatric comorbidity across the broad coronary heart disease population.

questions.source_summary: Patients with coronary heart disease have a high rate of comorbid psychiatric disorders, with major depressive disorder having the highest prevalence rate.
questions.vignette: A psychology trainee is conducting a literature review on the psychosocial burden of cardiovascular illness. She notes that patients with blocked coronary arteries show high rates of emotional distress, with some studies reporting significant anxiety, hopelessness, and social withdrawal in this group. The trainee is asked to identify which condition the supervisor is referencing.
questions.question: Based on prevalence data for psychiatric comorbidities in patients with cardiovascular disease involving the coronary arteries, which condition does the supervisor most likely mean?

options.A: Illness Anxiety Disorder
options.B: Major Depressive Disorder
options.C: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
options.D: Somatic Symptom Disorder

option_explanations.A: Illness Anxiety Disorder involves persistent worry about having or acquiring a serious illness and could plausibly apply given the patient's fears about mortality. However, Illness Anxiety Disorder does not represent the most prevalent psychiatric comorbidity in coronary heart disease populations; it is far less common than major depressive disorder in this context.
option_explanations.B: Major Depressive Disorder has the highest documented prevalence rate among psychiatric comorbidities in patients with coronary heart disease. The vignette's mention of anxiety-spectrum disorders and mortality fears serves as a red herring; epidemiological data consistently places MDD above anxiety disorders in this cardiac population.
option_explanations.C: Generalized Anxiety Disorder is plausible given the description of emotional distress and worry about prognosis in cardiac patients. While GAD is indeed elevated in coronary heart disease populations, multiple large-scale studies confirm that major depressive disorder has a higher prevalence rate in this group.
option_explanations.D: Somatic Symptom Disorder involves distressing physical symptoms with excessive cognitive and behavioral responses, which could overlap with cardiac symptom reporting. However, Somatic Symptom Disorder does not hold the distinction of being the most prevalent psychiatric comorbidity in coronary heart disease patients compared to major depressive disorder.

questions.source_summary: Patients with coronary heart disease have a high rate of comorbid psychiatric disorders, with major depressive disorder having the highest prevalence rate.
questions.vignette: A 55-year-old man undergoes a routine cardiac catheterization that reveals significant atherosclerotic blockages, and he is subsequently enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program. During intake screening, he endorses anhedonia, reports waking at 3 a.m. most nights, and describes feeling 'empty' rather than sad, which the intake coordinator notes could reflect an adjustment response to a frightening diagnosis. He also describes intermittent chest tightness and shortness of breath that his cardiologist attributes entirely to his cardiac condition. A medical educator preparing a training module states that among all psychiatric disorders studied in this cardiac population, one diagnosis consistently tops prevalence rankings, and the patient's intake profile exemplifies why routine screening for it is essential.
questions.question: The medical educator is most likely referring to which psychiatric disorder as having the highest prevalence rate in this cardiac population?

options.A: Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood
options.B: Persistent Depressive Disorder
options.C: Somatic Symptom Disorder
options.D: Major Depressive Disorder

option_explanations.A: Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood is strongly suggested by the scenario framing — a new frightening diagnosis, emotional emptiness, and an intake coordinator's comment about adjustment. However, Adjustment Disorder is a time-limited, situational diagnosis and does not represent the most prevalent or clinically significant psychiatric comorbidity in the coronary heart disease population at the epidemiological level. The anhedonia and neurovegetative features (early morning awakening, emptiness) point beyond an adjustment response.
option_explanations.B: Persistent Depressive Disorder involves chronic, low-grade depressive features that could explain the 'empty' affect and sleep disturbance, and it is a meaningful consideration. However, when population-level prevalence data for psychiatric comorbidities in coronary heart disease are examined, Persistent Depressive Disorder does not outrank major depressive disorder.
option_explanations.C: Somatic Symptom Disorder might be considered given the chest tightness and shortness of breath alongside emotional distress. However, the cardiologist attributes the somatic symptoms to the cardiac condition itself, and the question explicitly concerns which psychiatric disorder holds the top prevalence ranking in this population — a distinction belonging to MDD, not Somatic Symptom Disorder.
option_explanations.D: Major Depressive Disorder is the most prevalent psychiatric comorbidity in patients with coronary heart disease. The anhedonia, early morning awakening, and emotional emptiness are core neurovegetative and affective features of MDD. Despite the scenario's framing that these may reflect an adjustment response, epidemiological data and the presence of cardinal MDD features make this the correct and most clinically significant answer.

questions.source_summary: Patients with coronary heart disease have a high rate of comorbid psychiatric disorders, with major depressive disorder having the highest prevalence rate.
questions.vignette: A hospital quality improvement team reviews intake records from a cardiac unit and finds that a significant proportion of patients admitted for arterial blockages in the heart also score positively on a standardized screening tool that asks about persistent low energy, reduced interest in activities, changes in sleep and appetite, and difficulty concentrating. The team notes that anxiety-related complaints — including excessive worry about the future and physical tension — are also common in this group, and some team members argue these are the more clinically visible presentations. However, when aggregated across all positive screens, one category of emotional disturbance accounts for the largest share. A health outcomes researcher reviewing the team's data states this pattern is consistent with decades of literature on this population.
questions.question: Which psychiatric condition does the health outcomes researcher most likely identify as having the highest documented prevalence in this patient population?

options.A: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
options.B: Major Depressive Disorder
options.C: Panic Disorder
options.D: Adjustment Disorder with Mixed Anxiety and Depressed Mood

option_explanations.A: Generalized Anxiety Disorder is strongly suggested by the vignette's emphasis on anxiety-related complaints being 'more clinically visible' and the mention of worry and physical tension in the cardiac unit. GAD is indeed elevated in cardiac populations. However, the screening tool described — asking about low energy, reduced interest, sleep changes, appetite changes, and concentration difficulties — maps directly onto depressive rather than anxiety criteria, and GAD does not hold the top prevalence ranking in coronary heart disease populations.
option_explanations.B: Major Depressive Disorder is the most prevalent psychiatric comorbidity in patients with coronary artery disease. The screening items described — persistent low energy, reduced interest in activities, sleep and appetite changes, concentration difficulty — are core DSM-5 criteria for MDD. The vignette uses anxiety as an active red herring to draw attention away from the depressive screening data, but the researcher's conclusion aligns with decades of epidemiological literature identifying MDD as the most common psychiatric disorder in this cardiac population.
option_explanations.C: Panic Disorder is clinically relevant in cardiac settings because panic attacks can mimic cardiac events and patients with heart disease may experience somatic distress. However, Panic Disorder is characterized primarily by recurrent unexpected panic attacks rather than the persistent low-energy and interest-loss features described in the screening tool, and it does not rank as the most prevalent psychiatric comorbidity in this population.
option_explanations.D: Adjustment Disorder with Mixed Anxiety and Depressed Mood might appear to explain the combined emotional picture — anxiety complaints alongside depressive features — in patients who have received a serious cardiac diagnosis. However, Adjustment Disorder is a time-limited, stressor-specific diagnosis and does not represent the disorder with the highest prevalence rates across the broad coronary heart disease population in epidemiological research.

questions.source_summary: Community reinforcement and family training (CRAFT) aims to help the concerned significant other (CSO) influence the individual with the substance-use problem to seek treatment and teach the CSO procedures to help reduce the individual's substance use, but it does not involve the CSO adopting "loving-detachment" from the individual.
questions.vignette: A licensed psychologist is working with the wife of a man who has alcohol use disorder. The man refuses to enter treatment. The therapist describes an intervention approach in which the concerned significant other learns behavioral strategies to reward the husband's sobriety, communicate more effectively, and recognize windows of opportunity to suggest treatment entry. The therapist explicitly tells the wife that she will not be taught to emotionally distance herself from her husband, but rather to remain engaged and strategically influence his behavior. This approach is rooted in operant principles and has been empirically validated for situations where the individual with the substance use disorder is unwilling to seek help independently.
questions.question: Which intervention is the therapist describing?

options.A: Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT)
options.B: Al-Anon facilitation therapy
options.C: Johnson Intervention
options.D: Behavioral Couples Therapy (BCT)

option_explanations.A: Correct. CRAFT is specifically designed to train concerned significant others (CSOs) to use behavioral reinforcement strategies and communication skills to reduce a loved one's substance use and motivate treatment entry, without employing the loving-detachment philosophy central to 12-step family approaches.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Al-Anon facilitation therapy teaches family members to accept the limits of their control over the person with addiction and encourages emotional detachment ('loving detachment'), which is the opposite of CRAFT's active engagement approach.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. The Johnson Intervention is a structured confrontation model in which family members collectively confront the individual about their substance use in an emotionally direct way; it does not systematically train the CSO in reinforcement strategies or communication skills over time.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Behavioral Couples Therapy (BCT) involves both the person with the substance use disorder and their partner attending treatment together; it is not designed for situations where the individual with the disorder refuses treatment and therefore does not apply here.

questions.source_summary: Community reinforcement and family training (CRAFT) aims to help the concerned significant other (CSO) influence the individual with the substance-use problem to seek treatment and teach the CSO procedures to help reduce the individual's substance use, but it does not involve the CSO adopting "loving-detachment" from the individual.
questions.vignette: A 45-year-old woman presents to a community mental health clinic reporting significant distress about her adult son's methamphetamine use disorder. Her son has repeatedly declined any form of treatment, and she mentions that she has tried 'tough love' approaches in the past without success. She also discloses a history of generalized anxiety, though it is currently well-managed with medication. The clinician decides to teach her a structured set of skills including positive communication, natural consequences, and timing-based strategies to create opportunities for her son to enter treatment, while keeping the therapeutic focus on her active involvement rather than emotional withdrawal.
questions.question: The clinician is most likely implementing which evidence-based approach?

options.A: Al-Anon facilitation with 12-step integration
options.B: Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT)
options.C: Motivational Enhancement Therapy (MET)
options.D: Unilateral Family Therapy (UFT)

option_explanations.B: Correct. CRAFT directly addresses the scenario in which a concerned significant other seeks to influence a treatment-refusing individual with a substance use disorder. It teaches positive communication, rewarding non-using behavior, and identifying optimal moments to suggest treatment — all while maintaining active engagement rather than detachment.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Al-Anon facilitation centers on the concept of powerlessness over the addicted individual and teaches emotional detachment and self-care; it does not include skills training for strategically influencing treatment entry, which is the defining feature described in this vignette.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Motivational Enhancement Therapy (MET) is a client-centered intervention delivered directly to the person with the substance use disorder, not to a family member; it would not be applicable when the individual refuses treatment and is not present in sessions.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Unilateral Family Therapy (UFT) is an older approach that also works with family members of treatment-refusing individuals, but it emphasizes detachment and setting limits rather than actively training the family member to use behavioral reinforcement to influence substance use and treatment entry.

questions.source_summary: Community reinforcement and family training (CRAFT) aims to help the concerned significant other (CSO) influence the individual with the substance-use problem to seek treatment and teach the CSO procedures to help reduce the individual's substance use, but it does not involve the CSO adopting "loving-detachment" from the individual.
questions.vignette: A therapist is working with the long-term partner of a man who has been drinking heavily for years and refuses to attend any counseling. The partner feels guilty, exhausted, and unsure how to help without making things worse. The therapist spends several sessions teaching the partner to identify specific moments when the man is sober and receptive, to withdraw attention and support during intoxicated episodes as a natural consequence, and to frame conversations about treatment in a way that is positive and non-confrontational. The partner expresses surprise when the therapist discourages adopting an attitude of emotional distance, noting that several friends in similar situations were told by their support groups to 'let go and let God.'
questions.question: The therapeutic approach the therapist is using is best characterized by which of the following?

options.A: An approach that teaches the partner to accept powerlessness and practice self-protective detachment from the individual's drinking behavior
options.B: An approach that trains the partner to use behavioral reinforcement strategies and communication skills to reduce substance use and facilitate treatment entry without emotional withdrawal
options.C: An approach that guides the partner to organize a structured confrontation with the individual in the presence of trained professionals
options.D: An approach that involves both the partner and the individual attending joint sessions focused on commitment contracts and relationship enhancement

option_explanations.B: Correct. This description maps precisely onto CRAFT, which trains concerned significant others to use reinforcement principles (rewarding sobriety, applying natural consequences to use), non-confrontational communication, and strategic timing to facilitate treatment entry — explicitly rejecting the loving-detachment model.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. This describes the Al-Anon or 12-step family model, which emphasizes accepting powerlessness over the addicted person and emotional detachment. The vignette explicitly states the therapist discourages this attitude, ruling out this approach.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. This describes the Johnson Intervention model, which uses a planned, emotionally confrontational group meeting. The vignette describes the opposite tone — non-confrontational communication — and there is no mention of organizing a group confrontation event.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. This describes Behavioral Couples Therapy (BCT), which requires both partners to participate and includes sobriety contracts and relationship skill-building. The vignette specifies that the individual with the drinking problem is not in treatment, so a joint-session model is not applicable.

questions.vignette: A supervisor is consulting with a trainee about a case in which a woman has been attending weekly therapy for three months. Her presenting concern is distress related to living with a partner who drinks excessively and denies having a problem. The trainee reports using operant techniques to help the woman selectively reinforce her partner's sober behavior through positive interactions and to allow natural consequences to follow drinking episodes rather than shielding him from them. The supervisor, however, notes that the trainee made a conceptual error by also instructing the woman to begin emotionally detaching from her partner and reducing her investment in the relationship, framing this as consistent with the model being used. The supervisor clarifies that this instruction actually contradicts the framework the trainee claims to be using.
questions.question: Which therapeutic model did the trainee incorrectly apply by including the instruction to emotionally detach?

options.A: Unilateral Family Therapy (UFT)
options.B: Al-Anon facilitation therapy
options.C: Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT)
options.D: Behavioral Couples Therapy (BCT)

option_explanations.C: Correct. CRAFT uses operant principles to train CSOs to reinforce sober behavior and allow natural consequences for use, precisely as the trainee did. However, CRAFT explicitly does not endorse emotional detachment from the individual — the trainee's instruction to reduce emotional investment directly contradicts CRAFT's model of active, engaged influence.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Unilateral Family Therapy does incorporate some degree of detachment and limit-setting as part of its model, so instructing emotional withdrawal would not be inconsistent with UFT. The vignette describes the use of operant techniques for selective reinforcement, which is characteristic of CRAFT, not UFT.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Al-Anon facilitation therapy explicitly endorses loving detachment and acceptance of powerlessness, so the instruction to detach would be consistent with that model, not a contradiction of it. The trainee's error lies in mixing CRAFT's operant techniques with Al-Anon's philosophy.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. BCT involves both partners in joint treatment, and the vignette describes work with only one partner whose partner is not in treatment. While BCT does use behavioral principles, the scenario of working solely with the CSO of a treatment-refusing individual is specific to CRAFT.
